title: Art:
description: With more than 400 works by Sargent in its bins, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has chosen about one in 10 for an exhibition of watercolors (and a few drawings) that show how a fashionable portrait painter relaxed. When he grew weary of pleasing the customers (Portraiture is a pimp's profession), Sargent's watercolor box became his best campanion. With only himself to please, he set down his responses to a world governed by light and color rather than money and influence. Images of bits and pieces of cities and landscapes seemed to flow effortlessly through his brush onto the paper, and their fluidity must be part of the reason why the majority of his finest watercolors are of Venice, where water, light and color are naturally fused.

title: G.I.'s and O.J.'s In Vietnam
description: The space measured about 5 by 10 feet, contained two stacked bunks, a makeshift small chair and plain boards arranged as shelves. A thin wood and cloth partition about 5feet high provided only a little privacy from the rest of the barracks, which housed about 40 men. One of the men whose space this was had invited me in to rap about the Army in Vietnam and how E.M.'s (enlisted men) deal with the nonwar war. Others had anecdotes to add, and shortly 10 men had crowded into the space. As the discussion be came more animated, one man pulled out a cigarette and began to roll it between the thumb and forefinger of his left hand. After a while, I began to recognize this as a characteristic gesture. With his right hand he pulled from his pocket a small, greenish vial filled with white pow der and poured it into the partially emptied cigarette. He lit up, took a deep puff and passed the O.J. (opium joint) around. Most of those in the group took a hit, but two or three, including Tom, the 20yearold host who had recently gotten himself off a 15vialaday habit, said, No.

title: Music
description: THOSE who go to conservatories and professional music schools are much like students at medical schools. They are there for one purpose, to learn a particular skill, in their case, the art of per forming or composing. Medical students, however, have passed the college level and can concentrate on their field to the exclusion of other subjects. At conservatories, the budding musicians are normally at college level and required to take standard liberal arts courses. Since be coming a pianist, violinist, singer, or what have you, takes so much dedication and time, these students are apt to resent the other areas of learning, finding them irrelevant. The Manhattan School of Music is trying to do some thing about this, and they have instituted this fall a Unified Academic Program. It is an interdisciplinary program, already used in regular colleges and univer sities but, as far as David Simon, Manhattan's dean, knows, is new to music schools. We have a great abundance of talent here, Simon says, and with that talent goes a great deal of intel ligence. While the students are superior, they lack motiva tion. In trying to find what would most motivate them, we have changed the traditional role of the instructor. He doesn't tell the students what has to be learned any more. He meets with them and lets them about themselves, society, education. The instructor does not attempt to answer the ques tions, but suggests readings all kinds and lots of it, in cluding explosive literature. The students write papers and they go on field trips to hospitals, ghettos and similar places. We do not feel the program is experimental, but we do look on it as a safety device.

title: A Conversation [Pause] With Harold Pinter
description: ONCE, years ago, in answer to the ritualistic question, what was his work about, Harold Pinter casually answered, The wea sel under the cocktail cabinet. To his amazement, what Pinter consid ered a totally meaningless remark uttered only to frustrate this line of inquiry was enshrined in criticisms and theses as the very essence of Pinter, the ultimate comment of the man on his work. At 41, on the basis of the body of that workfour fulllength plays (The Birthday Party, The Care taker, The Homecoming and Old Times), 12 short plays, a number of sketches and poems, seven filmsPinter is regarded by many as the most significant and durable playwright now writing in the English language. At the same time that he has won the majority of critics as partisans, he continues to mystify. Who did what with whom and when? Every Pinter playand most of his movies  is filled with puzzles, including Old Times, his newest play which is currently delighting and confus ing audiences at the Billy Rose Theater.

description: Miss Barbara Klein and Morris L. Kramer, lawyers, plan to be married next month. Their engagement has been announced by Dr. Je rome C. Klein, a plastic sur geon, and Mrs. Klein of New York and Westhampton Beach, L. I.

title: Rare Salamander Is Saved on Coast
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Dec. 4 A very rare variety of sala mander known to exist only around one small pond here was saved from possible early extinction this week when the Santa Cruz County Board of Supervisors voted against turn ing the habitat into a trailer park.

title: Edwin Morgens, Mrs. van Gerbig Marry in Darien
description: DARIEN, Conn., Dec. 4 Mrs. Linda Hicklin van Gerbig and Edwin Huffman Morgens of New York were married here this morning in the Noroton Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Law rence McColl Horton.

title: CUBAN CHIEF ENDS HIS VISIT TO CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 4 Perhaps our visit has served as a stimulus for those who want to create difficulties for the popular government, and it may have sharpened some problems.

title: Franco Buries All Hopes for Liberalization During His Lifetime
description: MADRID, Dec. 4  Every thing is tied down  well tied down, Generalissimo Francisco Franco told the Span ish Parliament when he opened its new session last month.

title: VATICAN SHUFFLES SPAIN'SHIERARCHY
description: ROME, Dec. 4The Vatican today announced a shuffle of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in Spain.

title: H. E. W. Withholding Payments To Columbia in Inquiry on Bias
description: The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has temporarily withheld at least $688,000 in Federal contract funds from Columbia Univer sity and is considering suspend ing $1,994,643 more because of the university's alleged failure to comply with H.E.W. minor ityhiring guidelines.

title: Penn State Beats Cornell
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Dec. 4 (AP)Four Penn State play ers scored in double figures to night as the Nittany Lions beat Cornell, 9975, for their third, straight victory.

title: Smith Tennis Victor; Richey Is Defeated
description: PARIS, Dec. 4Stan Smith and Ilie Nastase scored victo ries as the $50,000 round robin Pepsi Masters Grand Prix tennis tournament be gan today.

title: China and U.S.: The Importance of Face
description: China and U.S.: The importance of Face

title: Miss Warnecke of Barnard to Wed
description: SYRACUSE, Dec. 4The Rev. Alexander Warnecke, pastor of SS. Peter and Paul (Eastern Orthodox Catholic Church of America) here, and Mrs. Warnecke have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Daria Warnecke, to Christopher York, son of Prof. David York and Mrs. Marion York, both of Princeton, N. J.

title: SOVIET WORKING TO RESTORE LAKE
description: SEVAN, U.S.S.R., Nov. 30 When Lenin used the slogan Communism equals Soviet power plus electrification of the whole country, he fostered an almost mystical Soviet faith in electric power projects as

title: BAN ON REGRUITING BY MILITARY ENDS
description: The oncampus recruitment of students by military person nel resumed without incident at Queens College last week after a fiveyear lapse.

title: Husbands Told to Give Wives Gift of Equality
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (UPI) A women's libera tion group is offering hus bands a chance to give their wives an unusual Christmas gift for $1legal equality in handling the family finances.

title: The Nation
description: Dr. Earl L. Butz became the new Secretary of Agriculture last week. But the Senate vote for confirmation was close, 51 to 44, and it was wide ly interpreted as an indication that the traditionally Republican folks down on the farm are unhappy with the Administration. Farm prices have been falling, farm costs have been rising and many farmers seemed to view the nomination of Dr. Butz, a 62yearold former Purdue Univer sity dean and adviser or official of several large agribusiness companies, as an unfriendly act.

title: D. B. Carm Scores
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 4 (UPI) D. B. Carm established himself as a key candidate for the $100,000 California Juvenile Stakes later this month by scoring a 5length victory to day in the $25,000 added San Mateo Stakes at Bay Meadows.

title: Yorty Planning Tour
description: CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 4 (UPI)Mayor San Yorty of Los Angeles, a contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination, is planning a three day tour of New Hampshire this month. Mr. Yorty is scheduled to arrive Dec. 13 and visit Con cord, Exeter, Doxer and Hamp ton.

title: News of the Rialto
description: MAYBE the situation isn't as desperate as it appeared to be after the curtain went up on Broadway's 197172 season. Maybe, in deed, things are going to be O.K. after all. This incipient euphoria, born with the ar rival of such as Harold Pinter's Old Times, Neil Simon's The Prisoner of Second Avenue and George Furth's Twigs, could be further nourished by the news this morning of two poten tially attractive goodies.

title: Italy Is Reforming Family Laws To Bar Dowries, Child Marriage
description: ROME, Dec. 4The Chamber of Deputies this week approved a reform of family law that pro claims full equality of the sexes and is bound to have a pro found impact on the Italian way of life.

title: In Industrialized West Germany, a White Collar Still Counts
description: COLOGNE, West Germany In the German steel and con struction industries, foremen, supervisors, engineers and ordi nary workmen wear protective helmets of different colors to denote their rank.

title: Soap Maker Quits Miami Area Over Phosphate Ban
description: MIAMI, Dec. 4Procter & Gamble announced yesterday that it would withdraw its laun dry products from Dade County in Florida when a local ordi nance banning phosphate deter gents becomes effective on Jan. 1. Another leading soap manu facturer indicated it would fol low suit.

title: Dance
description: BALANCHINE and Bejart are two men separated by more than the At lantic Ocean. They stand worlds apartchoreog raphers very possibly repre senting the two most polar ized views of what choreog raphy and ballet are about. Balanchine sees choreography as an art. Bjart on the other hand, sees it as a pop medium for the transmission of pop ideas, moral homilies about peace, forbearance and revo lution, and theatrical homage collages to fashionable dead art, such as Wagner, Baude laire or Richard Strauss. Bal anchine, I suppose, is also very RussoAmerican in his thoughts and sensibilities, while Bjart is presumably

title: SCOTT SAYS POWELL WON'T BE OPPOSED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 The Senate spent three and half hours today discussing Ptesident Nixon's Supreme Court nomination of Lewis P. Powell Jr., without any mem ber declaring opposition to the nomination.

title: Sailing on 33Foot Yawl: Object Matrimony
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I.David Sloane has credentials to prove his prowess in philoso phy and sailing but denies that he has earned them in matchmaking.

title: Jersey Inherits G.M. Pollution Problem
description: Last October, in a settlement that was highly praised by the United States Attorney's office here, an agreement was reached on the controversial water pol lution case involving the Gen eral Motors plant at North Tar rytown in Westchester County.

title: Roseland Resounds To Latin Variations Of Tito Puente Jazz
description: Roseland Ballroom, which will celebrate its 53d anni versary New Year's Eve, is no longer the home of name bands that it once waswhen Fletch er Henderson's orchestra was the house band 40 years ago and when the great names of the swing era paraded across its bandstand. In recent years the huge ballroom on 52d Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue has concen trated on a rotating group of sweet bands, all playing in more or less the same Mickey Mouse style.

title: WASHINGTON
description: The IndianPakistani tragedy brings us back again to the fatal flaw in the organization of world politics: There is simply no effective world instru ment for enforcing peace or compell ing nations to settle their disputes by peaceful means.

title: COURT BARS CURBS ON SCHOOL PAPERS
description: Administrators of statesup ported colleges on Staten Is land have been ordered not to carry out their threats to sup press the publication of at tacks against religion in stu dent newspapers, in a ruling handed down by the Appellate Division, Second Department.

title: TorridShooting Knicks Trounce Braves, 130 to 90
description: An 8point burst following the opening tipoff mushroomed in to a 40point margin of victory last night at Madison Square Garden as the Knickerbockers rode wildly over the Buffalo Braves, 13090, before a capac ity crowd of 19,588.

title: CONNECTICUT TOPS YALE'S FIVE, 6664
description: STORRS, Conn., Dec. 4 (AP) Gary Custick, a sophomore, scored with three seconds left in the game tonight and gave the University of Connecticut a 66.64 victory over Yale in bas ketball.

title: Costly Phone Call
description: RENO, Nev., Dec. 4 (UPI) When Joyce Farrell went to her parked car, she discovered someone had stolen an electric typewriter she had left on the seat. She telephoned the police and came back to the car to find a thief had returned in her absence and taken her bowling ball, bag and shoes.

title: Sports of The Times
description: A Flame Grew in Brooklyn

title: ALLHUNTER SHOW AT FOUR SEASONS
description: Four Seasons Farm in Read ington, N.J., will hold the sec ond of its winter indoor horse show series next Saturday, but things will be different this time.

title: BANKER HONORED AT VIRGINIA FETE
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Dec. 4  A 90yearold New York City lawyerbanker, Ar thur J. Morris, was honored at a dinner here tonight in conjunc tion with the announcement of his gift of $350,000 to the Uni versity of Virginia law library.

title: New York's Neediest Cases
description: The New York Times today launches its sixtieth annual campaign on behalf of the city's Neediest Cases. These cases are selected by a group of major welfare organ izations. Their stories, detailed in Section 2, both typify and personalize the type of trouble which public generosity at this season of the year can help to alleviate.

title: Radioactive Fallout in West; Red China Seen as Source
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4The Atomic Energy Commission an nounced today that radioactive fallout had been detected in eight Western states, evidently coming from a recent nuclear test on the China mainland.

title: Miss Julie Elizabeth Berghold Fiancee of James W. Sykes Jr.
description: Miss Julie Elizabeth Berg hold and James Ware Sykes Jr. will be married in Feb ruary.

title: Citing Conflict, Scribner Blocks $100,000 in School Contracts
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has blocked the award of three contracts totaling $100, 000 to a concern with which the school system's recently retired chief researcher is now associ ated.

title: Miss Finley Wed Upstate
description: GLENFORD, N. Y., Dec. Miss Patricia Dixon Finley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John William Finley of Glen ford and New York, was married here this afternoon to John Blaise Pellegrini, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerardo Pellegrini of Leominster, Mass. The Rev. Robert Lof tus, a Roman Catholic priest performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: In the summer of 1950, when the lowpriced Timex watch had been on the mar ket about a year, Joakim L. Lehmkuhl, founder and then president of the U. S. Time Corporation, would leave his Middlebury, Conn., home en route to his New York office and start at the back of the New Haven Railroad train, walk slowly through each car, and estimated the number who wore Timex wrist watches. Nine times out of 10, he would find none, but if his courage lagged, his Scandinavian poise wouldn't allow him show

title: Miss Commers Fiancee
description: CATHEDRAL CITY, Calif., Dec. 4Mr. and Mrs. Don ald Commers, formerly of Minneapolis, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Donna Commers, to Robert John Voigt, son of Fire Chief and Mrs. John R. Voigt of the Bronx, New York.

title: Hannah Biddulph Is Bride Of Michael Bruce, Bank Aide
description: Miss Hannah Harding Bid dulph was married here yes terday afternoon to Michael Robert Bruce, assistant sec retary at the Bankers Trust Company in New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George Jackson, a Methodist minister, at the Carlyle.

title: The Christmas
description: BY the end of this month, Postal Department willing, 50 million American families will have sent one another approximately 2.5 billion Christmas cards, according estimates made by the National Asso ciation of Greeting Card Publishers. That works out to 50 cards per family, although, of course, Christmascard sending is not that evenly distributed throughout the population. Some peo ple send fewer than a dozen, or none at all, whereas President Nixon mails out about 37,000 a year, dutifully handaddressed by a volunteer corps of Republican women.

title: BellagioA Quiet Alternative to the Modern, Brash Resort
description: BELLAGIO, ItalyThe drive from Milan is ordinary until you pass Lecco, but then the urban aspect disappears as Lake Como and the surrounding mountains come promi nently into view. Then you reach this enchanting little town at the point of the peninsula dividing the lake and you gaze across the water at several little vil lages, dwarfed by the gray mass of the mountainsa spectacular view by any standards.

title: I can make it now, I know I can
description: Wanda is 25; her friend Elizabeth 23. Both are mentally retarded. Wanda is attractive, but Elizabeth's face droops on one side because of a birth defect. Until they were 16, both at tended special classes for the retarded. After that Wanda, an only child, was kept at home. Elizabeth, who has three younger sisters, found several menial jobs but was always let go because she was too slow. Early this year, Wanda and Elizabeth were referred to the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service by the State Office of Vocational Rehabilitation.

title: Sabich Wins at Vail, Colo., In Pro Giant Slalom Race
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 4 (AP). Spider Sabich won $2,500 today for a firstplace finish in the giant slalom, the first of two races in the Samsonite ski com petition.

title: Trim Trimmings for Christmas
description: Gardens

title: Donna V. Machcinski Is Affianced
description: RYE, N. Y., Dec. 4Mr. and Mrs. Charles Machcinski have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Donna Victoria Machcinski, to Scott William Petersen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter William Petersen of Mount Prospect, Ill. A January wedding is planned.

title: Houses, Inside and Out
description: They will still be called pic ture books. But the term is no longer entirely apt, applied to this year's more restricted crop of handsomely illustrated volumes on historic buildings and the extraordinary objects that once filled them.

title: Nixon's Tree Is Cut
description: CROSSNORE, N. C., Dec. 4 (AP)President Nixon's Christ mas trees, a 21foot Fraser fir, was cut yesterday in the snow covered mountains of north western North Carolina. It will he delivered to the Blue Room of the White House Wednesday.

title: Lynne Lucas Is Betrothed
description: BOONTON, N. J., Dec. 4 The engagement of Miss Lynne Lucas to William P. Rice of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anton H. Rice Jr. of Irvington, N. Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph R. Lucas of Boonton.

title: Miss Desmarais to Wed
description: DRACUT, Mass., Dec. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Ernest M. Des marais have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Priscilla Desmarais, to Howard Epstein, son of Mr, and Mrs. Abraham Ep stein of Flushing, Queens, New York. A Jan. 15 wed ding is planned.

title: A Troubled Business School
description: Just before the recent Thanksgiving holiday, Dean George F. James of the Co lumbia Graduate School of Business announced his re tirement next June.

title: Movies
description: THE house looks like the sort in which callers are received by live in maids, but Paula Prentiss opens the door herself, wearing a suggestion of a shirt and hot pants, and says in a curious muted scream, Hi, I burned the bacon, don't tell Dick! The bacon was for Sunday breakfast; Dick is Richard Benjamin, also Paula's husband; the house, in Coldwater Can yon, is only rented, while Dick finishes the film of Portnoy's Complaint and Paula plays the startling pothead of the movie of Last of the Red Hot Lovers.

title: David Mazza, Ph.D. Candidate, To Wed Deborah L. Simpkins
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 4  Miss Deborah Lee Simpkins and David Law rence Mazza plan to be mar ried. The prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Roy Simpkins, have announced their engagement. Mr. Mazza is a son of Mrs. Clara D. Mazza of Darien and the late Domonick Lawrence Mazza.

title: SOVIET TO WIDEN STUDIES ON CHINA
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 4The So viet Union, displaying growing alarm over the turn of events in China, announced this week a broad program of scholarly research on all aspects of po litical, economic and cultural life in that country.

title: News of The Camera World
description: NEW Dual 8mm movie projector (it takes both Super 8 and regular 8mm film) recently in troduced by the DeJurAmsco Corporation, Northern Boule vard and 45th Street, Long Island City, N.Y. 11101, offers several interesting features at a comparatively modest priceand one feature that this writer has seen on no other projector in this price range (although it is avail able on more expensive models). This feature is the ability to stop action and show single frames without any loss in brilliance (100 per cent illumination). The special optical system that permits this, also permits this kind of still projection for as long as desired without any danger of burning the film.

title: LANDFILL OPPOSED FOR FLUSHING BAY
description: Backed by piles of affidavits and photographs made by resi dents of the College Point sec tion of Queens, a civic organiz ation and an Assemblyman from that area called yesterday upon the State Attorney General and United Staes Attorney's office to halt a landfill operation cov ering about eight acres of Flushing Bay.

title: Chiefs Face Jolters Dec. 19 In Roller Derby at Garden
description: The Chiefs, Madison Square Garden's entry in the Interna tional Roller Derby League, held second place after play last week, which included a victory at the Garden on Sun day.

title: June Wedding Set by Debby Freedman
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 4  Warren Freedman, counsel and assistant secre tary for the BristolMyers Company in New York, and Mrs. Freedman have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Debby Freedman, to Michael Stiebel, son of Mr. and Mrs, Abner Stiebel of Richmond.

title: Partisan Principles
description: President Nixon was all set, as a matter of principle, to veto a major revenue bill because it contained a tax checkoff plan for financing Presidential campaigns. Al though that plan has been all but gutted by a conference committee, the same basic principle to which Mr. Nixon objectedletting taxpayers earmark $1 of their income tax for such campaignsstill remains in the bill. Yet the President's press secretary now clearly indicates that Mr. Nixon will sign it.

title: Auction of Salvaged Treasure This Week
description: Coins

title: Banfield, Harvard Professor, Gets Pennsylvania U. Post
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4Dr. Edward C. Banfield, a professor of urban government at Har vard, has been appointed the first William R. Kenan Jr. Pro fessor at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: The World
description: Turning Eastward

title: Vaughan and Kellner Reach Squash Racquets Semifinal
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Dec. 4 Ed Vaughan and George Kell ner, both from the University Club of New York, advanced to the semifinals today in the eighth annual suburban invita tion Class B squash racquets tournament.

title: Mrs. King Gains Final
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zea land, Dec. 4 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Cal if., and Francoise Durr of France won semifinal matches today in an international women's tennis tournament.

title: Congress Council
description: Stamps

title: Catherine E. Kinsey Is Affianced
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 Miss Catherine Elizabeth Kinsey, a student at the Uni versity of California at Los Angeles, and Stephen John Stephanou, a graduate of the university, plan to be mar ried here in July.

description: To the Editor:

title: Queens Residents Hire a Private Security Patrol
description: The twotoned green pa trol car driven by a man in a green uniform wound through the hilly, treelined streets of Jamaica Estates on the first day of a private security patrol paid for by 600 residents at an assess ment of $5 a month.

title: University Expands Courses in Navajol
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Dec. 4To meet the increasing de mands of both Indian and non Indian students, the University of New Mexico has expanded its Navajo language teaching program.

title: Midtown for the People In Vienna Traffic Test
description: VIENNA, Dec. 4 (Reuters) Pedestrians loved it but motorists tooted their horns in anger when an experiment aimed at giving the heart of the city back to the people was launched here.

title: 2 Die in Crash of Plane Snagged by jet
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 4 (AP) A singleengine plane collided in the air today with an Eastern Air Lines jetliner, got caught in the big plane's undercar riage, then dropped to the ground in flames, killing its two occupants. The jetliner landed safely.

title: Brooklyn's Chelsea Theater Is Successful, but Unspoiled
description: Four weeks after announc ing its first subscription sea son, the Chelsea Theater Cen ter, the resident theater com pany of the Brooklyn Acade my of Music; is completely sold out.

title: The Brooklyn Theatre Fire: 300 Died 95 Years Ago Today
description: Kate Claxton, in the role of a poor blind girl, lay on a straw pallet. In the drama's action, Mrs. Mary Farren savagely pulled her hair back. Then Miss Claxton saw the little tongues of flame lick ing through the canopy of the stageset boathouse.

title: Letters:
description: NIGHT SKIING

title: Vin Ordinaire Et Formidable
description: In 1724 a certain Dr. Shaw wrote of wine that, drunk in moderate quantities, it has the power to give sudden refreshment, to warm the stomach, gently stimulate its fibres, promote digestion, raise the pulse, rarefy the blood and add to its ve locity, open all obstructions, forward excretions, greatly promote insensible perspiration, increase the natural strength, and enlarge the faculties both of body and mind. While the same reasons for its consumption might not be given today, in recent years the virtues of wine have be come apparent to more and more Americansfor some as a status symbol, for others as a necessary accompaniment to a pleasant meal. In the 15 years between 1951 and 1966 American consumption of wine increased by more than 50 per cent, and it has kept on growing. Books on wine have proliferated too.

title: New York
description: In a cluttered office across the street from City Hall, a muscular man sporting a mustache sits behind a littered desk flanked by four telephones and a twoway radio that can put him in instant contact with John V. Lindsay. His name is Sid Davidoff, and his office is the nerve cen ter Mr the closest thing Mr. Lindsay has to a political organizationThe John V. Lindsay Associations, an amorphous assort ment of supporters across the city who raise funds, organize campaigns and dis pensepatronage for the Mayor.

title: Paraje Wins 2 Mile Display by HalfLength
description: Paraje made a convincing case for himself as a distance runner at Aqueduct yesterday. He was the weaker part of the entry representing Sigmund Sommer in the 17th running of the 2mile Display Handi cap, his stablemate being the seasoned campaigner, Hitch cock.

title: Advisory Letters Find Profit In Controls
description: WASHINGTONIn what ever guise Phase Two of President Nixon's new eco nomic policy appears to other industries, to the busi nessletter advisory industry it has been a glorious oppor tunity.

title: Jane Holland Wed to Douglas Hardin
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Dec. 4 Miss Jane Maxwell Holland was married here this after noon to Douglas Ray Hardin, a former champion distance runner for Harvard Univer sity. The Rev. Wood Carper, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Green brier Hotel.

title: Karen Schpeiser to Wed
description: NEWTONVILLE, Mass., Dec. 4Miss Karen Leigh Schpeiser and Paul Duncan Fairbank of Geneva, graduates of Washington University in St. Louis, will be married Jan. 1. Mr. and Mrs. Marvin B. Schpeiser of Newtonville have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mrs. Ruth Bis bee of Honolulu and Edward Fairhank, an architect of Geneva,. Ill.

title: I Guess My Children Aren't So Different After All
description: One day each week from noon until 2 P.M., a small group of mothers gathers around two large tables in the comfortable basement lounge of the parish rectory. After finishing sandwiches and coffee prepared in the kitchen, they watch a film devoted to child rearing. Afterward, as they sew inexpensive curtains for their apartmentsone of a series of group projectsthey discuss their common problems. All of them are struggling to raise families without the help of their husbands. Widowed or deserted, burdened by bitter personal ex periences and trying to make ends meet on public assistance or meager Social Security benefits, all had reached the limit of endurance when they first sought help from the New York Catholic Charities.

title: Miss C. Corvan Vermont Bride
description: WEST DOVER, Vt., Dec. 4 Miss Constance Lee Cor van, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Philip Corvan Jr., for merly of North Stamford, Conn., was married today to Nicholas Woods Noon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore W. Noon Jr. of Short Hills, N.J. The ceremony was performed in the West Dover Congrega tional Church by the Rev. John P. Morgan.

title: Waterfront Panel Scored For Seeking More Power
description: Efforts by the Waterfront Commission of New York Har bor to extend its jurisdiction to the metropolitan area's airports have triggered the heaviest bar rage of criticism against the agency in its 18year history.

title: SYNANON SIGNS UP 550 CITY ADDICTS
description: In the last five weeks the controversial California  based Synanon drug program has taken 550 addicts off the streets of New York and sent them, at their own expense, across the country for rehabilitation. It hopes to recruit 1,500 more by next June.

title: Stewart's Warning to Tracks Pointed Up by Siffert Tragedy
description: About Motor Sports

title: Space
description: There is a system in the solar sys tema pattern of spacing and rotation that tells us a good deal about how our world, the other planets, their moons and the sun were formed.

title: PEKING NOTE IMPLIES MOVE TOWARD I.L.O.
description: GENEVA, Dec. 4The Peking Government has implied that it is considering accepting the seat offered it in the International Labor Organization, a United Nations specialized agency. It would replace the Nationalist Chinese regime of Taiwan.

title: VOLS WIN BY 3111
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 4 Penn State was undefeated and the nation's most prolific scor ing team until it committed four mistakes and ran into Tennes see's excellent defense today. The result was a 3111 upset on the final day of the regular col lege football season.

title: India MIG's in 8 Raids Against Dacca Airport
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 4 Indian MIG21 fighterbomb ers struck inside East Paki stan today in a series of bombing and strafing raids.

title: Alexandra Holt Plans Nuptials
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Philetus Havens Holt 3d have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alex andra Foster Holt, to Paul Eugene Schaffner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Blain Schaff ner of Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

title: WinstonSalem to Oppose Howard in a Benefit Game
description: WinstonSalem (N. C.) State University's basketball team will face Howard University's at the Louis D. Brandeis High School gymnasium in Manhat tan in a benefit game on Sun day afternoon, Dec. 19.

title: LACROSSE HONORS ATHEY AND MORAN
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 4  More than 300 college and high school coaches, officials and club representatives have wound up the threeday 89th annual convention of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: In 1949 the only ad agency recruiting on the Syracuse University campus was Phila delphia's N. W. Ayer & Son.

title: CLAIRE R. SCHULMAN
description: Claire R. Schulman, an in structor in earlychildhood edu cation at William Paterson Col lege in Wayne, N.J., since 1963, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 43 years old and lived at 60 West 10th Street.

title: Deans Say Lag in U.S. Aid Hinders Graduate Schools
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4The quality of many of the coun try's leading graduate schools is being seriously threatened by the loss of millions of dollars in Federal fellowships and other support, according to deans of those schools.

title: Awkward Time for China
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 4The war between India and Pakis tan has caught China at an awkward time, In the opinion of analysts here.

title: Television
description: A FEW months ago, over a casual lunch, a tele vision executive of fered the argument that the networks were sell ing their own future short by steadily cutting back on primetime news and public affairs programing. As the executive was connected with a TV news department, the argument may have lacked complete objectivity.

title: Mrs. End Has Daughter
description: A daughter was born here on Nov. 23 to Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Gotthard End of CrotonONHudson, N. Y., at the University Hospital. The child has been named Allison Rebecca. Mrs. End is the former Miss Andrea Moss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Moss of New York. Mr. Moss, the actor, is cur rently appearing in Follies. Mr. End is a copy editor with Ogilvy & Mather, the adver tising agency.

title: No Survivors in Crash
description: SAIGON, Dec. 4 (UPI)Mili tary searchers today reached the wreckage of a United States Army Chinook helicopter that crashed on a jungled mountain last Sunday and reported there were no survivors among the 33 Americans aboard, the Unit ed States command announced.

title: Margaret Geismar Bride of Ad Man
description: Miss Margaret Cecilia Geis mar, administrative assistant to the director of New York operations for Albert jay Rosenthal & Co., Chicago advertising agency, was mar ried here yesterday afternoon to Charles Abner Buck Jr., assistant director of person nel for the Doyle Dane Bern bach advertising agency here. The Rev. Vincent F. Blehl performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: Albatross, Speedy Crown Voted Top Harness Horses
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 4 UPI) Albatross, winner of 25 of 28 starts, has been selected as the nation's top 3yearold pacing colt and Speedy Crown as the top 3yearold trotter, the Unit ed States Trotting Association announced today.

title: Mills Sees No Way He Can Receive the Presidential Nomination
description: Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said yesterday he saw no way of his getting into the 1972 Democratic Pres idential primaries and no way a nonprimary contestant would he presented with the nomination.

title: Big Air Defense Center in Colorado to Be Enlarged
description: DENVER, Dec. 4 Wort, is expected to begin next month on enlarging the huge under ground command center that is carved from the heart of a granite mountain southwest of Colorado Springs.

title: Son to the Bauchners
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 4A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Burton Bauchner Nov. 13 in the Bridgeport Hospital. title: The Games Some People Play
description: Like millions of other sports enthusiasts, with our misguided sense of priorities, I spend un told hours observing our athletic pastimes, and pride myself on an ability to recog nize good and bad perform ances as well as nuances. Which is why it drives me to distraction to hear Page an nounced as the tackler when know it was Eller; or hear an announcer say, As the instant replay clearly shows it was a charge, when the replay clearly shows it was a block. But such gaffes are no tougher to take than wading through the plethora of 1971 sports books that have been strewn about my AstroTurf living room carpet for months now; it is no easier to abide with mis representations in print than it is to hear them.

title: Brandt: A Time for Listening
description: BERLIN,, Dec. 4  Willy Brandt is known as a good listener, and when he goes to Florida between Christ mas and the New Year to see President Nixon he will undoubtedly try to do more listening than talking on topics of bilateral and inter national interest.

title: Village Light Opera Presents Twin Bill
description: Trial by Jury and The Sorcerer were the second and third works on which Gilbert and Sullivan collaborated. They were so successful in their day that they became a kind of preface to the list of master pieces that the pair turned out. A preface they remain today, good enough in themselves but not on a par with the works that followed. The brief, far cical Trial is still performed, frequently, but The Sorcerer is relatively neglected. They were staged as a double bill on Friday night by the Village Light Opera Group. They made a somewhat long, unwieldy evening, but the chance to hear The Sorcerer was not to be missed, and the company is to be thanked for its enter prise in giving it.

title: The Dance in All Its Variety
description: Criticism of any art is an act revealing the man, his times, or an energetic blend of both. Since hardly anyone to my knowledge ever aspires to be a critic (most being fans or failed professionals), it is amazing that some do so well. Lincoln Kirstein I suppose is a an but has elevated advocacy into the realm of scholarship. His MOVEMENT AND META PHOR (Praeger, $17.50) is a passionate survey tracing the development of ballet through an examination of 50 histor ically and creatively important productions.

title: Grandma Visits Her Hippies
description: I WANTED to be there when my grandchild was born. Marilyn urged me to come for the birth. After all, she said, you'll be a help. You've had three children. Who me? I knew only about hospitals, doctors and nurses. I took care of babies after the nurse left, but I really couldn't recall giving birth. I relegated that to the proper authori ties. I'd be scared to death to take care of the birth of a baby.

title: The Nation
description: More than 18 months have passed since the May, 1970, riots at Kent State University that left four students dead and nine others wounded. But the recriminations and attempts to fix blame continue almost unabated. There have been studies by groups public and private, state and Federal. There have been calls for action against the National Guardsmen who fired upon the students. But the only legal action has been taken by a special Potage County, Ohio, grand jury: It refused to indict any of the guardsmen while handing down indictments against 25 students, faculty members and outsiders for alleged crimes com mitted during Kent's days of trouble.

title: Santa Sobersides
description: A reflection perhaps of the clouds on the economic horizon, there is a perceptible soberness to Christmas merchandising as merchants try again this year to sep arate millions of consumers from their accumulated savings. Amid many of the usual sights and sounds of holiday selling, consumers seem to be taking a more conservative approach compared with other years as they shop the stores.

title: Television
description: PLEASE do not under stand me too quick ly, Andre Gide once implored. Is there any reason why one civiliza tion shouldn't expect a simi lar courtesy in its dealings with another? Calcutta, an extraordinary documentary by Louis Malle that Chan nel 13 /WNET will broadcast Tuesday night at 8:30, is gal lantly restrained in its inter pretations of an alien culture, and it comes as a great relief after years of officious, know itall documentaries and trav el films which did little more than reflect the preconcep tions of the filmmakers.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONRichard Nixon has always seemed to believe that the surest road to the White House lies through the capitals of the world. He traveled often during his Vice Presi dential years under Dwight Eisenhow er. And back in 1966 and 1967, when he was starting his political comeback, he braved the yawns of the press and the hostility of more than one foreign government in order to tour the globe and bolster his credentials as a statesman.

title: Will Texas Rangers Do Better Than Texas Whales?
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Dec. 4 The porpoises and the whales at Seven Seas out number the baseball players at adjacent Arlington Stadium these days and when they both open next April the por poises and the whales un doubtedly will display more talent. But the baseball, play ers are stirring more interest because they've brought the rapidly growing DallasFort Worth area its own major league baseball team.

title: Men on the Moon
description: An instrument left on the moon by Apollo 15 has detected much more heat under the lunar surface than scientists had anticipated. This and other recently ob served phenomena, including the relatively large amount of radioactivity found in the soil samples that the Apollo astronauts have returned to earth, suggest that existing theories on formation of the moon and the planets may have to be revised. Earlier this year instruments left by Apollo astronauts reported water vapor on the moon and indicated that hundreds of miles under the lunar surface there exist conditions producing the moon's equivalent of earthquakes. The evidence is that the moon is a far more complex and mysterious body than had been suspected before the Apollo landings.

title: Art
description: AT 59, Tony Smith is one of the most impressive of contemporary sculp tors. Originally an ar chitect, designer and paint er (he worked for a time with Frank Lloyd Wright), Smith began producing sculpture relatively late in his career. The large mockup structures derived from geometric forms and constructed of plywood painted black, which Smith began exhibiting in the mid sixties, however, clearly es tablished him as an important figure in American art, an artist with a talent for sculp ture that was monumental in scale and environmental in. ambitions.

title: America May Be in Its Last Phase of Adolescence
description: IN 1926, Lincoln Steffens, the progressive American journalist whose disillusionment with American life had turned him into student of the Russian Revolution, returned from a visit to the Soviet Union with the announcement that he had seen the future, and it worked. What I have seen of Com munism was crude, cruel, backward, reactionary in the worst sense  a forbidding future. I fled my native Hungary, which had been conquered by the Russian Army and was to be gradually Sovietized, earlier than most displaced persons; before the full freeze of the cold war, I had the good fortune of being admitted to the United States in the fall of 1946, exactly 25 years ago.

description: HONG KONG, Nov. 4 (Reu ters)  China's Acting Foreign Minister, Chi Pengfei, de nounced India today for what he described as her continued expansion of armed aggression against Pakistan and implied that India was acting with the support and encouragement of the Soviet Union.
