description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Dec. 12 Six teenagers were killed here this afternoon when the station wagon in which they were riding struck a tree and overturned. Two others are in serious condition at local hospitals.

title: Giel Given Minnesota Post After Dispute Is Settled
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 12 (AP) Paul Giel patched up his differences with the University of Minnesota administration today about authority for hiring coaches, and will become the next Gopher athletic director.

title: Success Story: The Fulbright Scholarships
description: WASHINGTONAmid all the questioning about the international commitments of the American Government abroad, it is good to find a pioneering program from 1946 that still remains both popular abroad and relevant to current American needs: the educational exchanges that began with the Fulbright Act just a quartercentury ago. The ironic and perplexing fact is that the American people, who originated and continue to subsidize the program, seem to be almost the only major people, in the Western world not to appreciate fully the extraordinary nature of this program.

title: Morgan Guaranty in Shift
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company announced over the weekend plans to transfer the assets of the Morgan Guaranty International Banking Corporation to the Morgan Guaranty International Finance Corporation.

title: ECONOMIC POLICY ABROAD ATTACKED
description: A group of 18 leading economists attacked the Administration's international economic policy yesterday, and warned that the world could be sliding into a new mercantilism.

title: PENN AIDE FORESEES SOME KIND OF R.O.T.C.
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 Col. George F. Sawyer, professor of military science at the University of Pennsylvania, issued a statement today expressing the possibility that military and naval science programs could be maintained in some form on the Penn campus.

title: David Sarnoff of RCA Is Dead; Visionary Broadcast Pioneer
description: David Sarnoff, the harddriving broadcasting pioneer who rose from a $5.50aweek office boy to chairman of the RCA Corporation, died yesterday morning. He was 80 years old.

title: Midtown Traffic Reshuffling Proposed
description: Drastic reshuffling of midtown traffic patterns  to convert three streets and four avenues to express arteries without midtown entry or exitis part of a new city plan for meeting Federal air quality standards, Robert N. Rickles, Commissioner of Air Resources, said yesterday.

title: W. A. HARDENBERGH, ENGINEEREDITOR, 83
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 12 Col. William A. Hardenbergh, Army Reserve retired, former editor and publisher of Public Works Magazine and president of the Public Works Journal Corporation from 1947 to 1965, died today in Valley Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 153 Foster Terrace.

title: And Why Not the Press?
description: A conference committee of House and Senate is scheduled to meet this morning to iron out differences between the two versions of the bill extending the President's power to control wages and prices to April 30, 1973. The measure is needed to give the Administration sufficient time and authority to follow through with some hope of success on its undertaking to control inflation and restore confidence in the nation's economy.

title: 2 More Ballots Inconclusive In Italy's Presidential Vote
description: ROME, Dec. 12The 1,008member electoral assembly in two ballots today failed for the fourth day to choose a new president of Italy.

title: ANDREW J. SIOTKA
description: Andrew J. Siotka of 16710 Crocheron Avenue, Flushing, Queens, a retired fur manufacturer, died Saturday of a heart attack. He was 78 years old.

title: Community Boards Draw Growing List of Applicants
description: During a recent public hearing by a Bronx community board, a resident who opposed the controversial home for wayward youths under discussion stomped up to the microphone to demand, How do I get on this board?

title: PEKING DELEGATES HOSTS TO CHINESE
description: The Chinese delegation to the United Nations played host to the Chinese community here over the weekend for the first time since the delegates arrived more than a month ago to replace the ousted Nationalists.

title: Record TaxExempt Slate Finds Bond Market Ready
description: Buoyed by the Federal Reserve's decision Friday to cut the discount rate and full of hope that an international currency settlement will be reached this week, the credit markets are confident that they can handle all the financing that is scheduled.

title: DR. PAUL KLEIN
description: Dr. Paul Klein, an obstetrician and gynecologist, died Friday at his home, 6861 Yellowstone Boulevard, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 79 years old.

title: Miss Goolagong Victor
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 12 (Reuters)  Evonne Goolagong won the Queensland women's singles grass court tournament today when she beat Helen Gourlay, 62, 76, in an allAustralian final.

title: Foreign Evacuees Tell of Bengalis' Flight From Dacca as Indian Troops Advance
description: CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 12Pakistan relented today on letting foreigners leave Dacca, and the evacuees arrived in India saying that the Bengali population was fleeing the East Pakistani capital in droves as Indian troops moved in on the city.

title: OIL GIANTS BESET BY RASH OF WOES
description: LONDON, Dec. 12An American oil man in London was asked the other day to comment on the nationalization of the British Petroleum Company's assets in Libya.

title: Secondary Trading Spurts As New Eurobonds Coast
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 12Calm has overtaken the newissue side of the Eurobond market while secondary trading activity has picked up and prices for straight dollar debt continue to hold firm.

title: New RadioTV Network To Reach All of Greece
description: ATHENS, Dec. I 2 The European subsidiary of the Northrop Corporation has installed a $12.5million radiotelevision network for the Greek Government that will link the whole country for the first time to the staterun broadcasting system and enable it to beam shortwave radio programs to any part of the world.

title: GEORGE W. GRIMM JR., LAWYER FOR UTILITY
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 12George W. Grimm Jr., retired general counsel of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, died today in Riverview Hospital, Red Bank. He was 73 years old and lived in Leisure Village here.

title: NEUTER GARGOYLES DANCED IN PREMIERE
description: The Cliff Keuter Dance Company presented four works by Mr. Keuter Saturday night at the American Theater Lab, 219 West 19th Street, under the auspices of Choreoconcerts Choreographers Theater. The program included a premiere, Gargoyles, and a recent piece Wood.

title: Stranded Ship Is Freed
description: BUZZARDS BAY, Mass., Dec. 12 (AP)  The Norwegian freighter Tagaytay was pulled free today from the bank of the Cape Cod Canal, where she ran aground yesterday. The ship continued through the canal and on to Boston.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Release Fecteau bat Keep Downey in Prison
description: HONG KONG, Monday, Dec. 13One American held prisoner in China since 1952 crossed into Hong Kong today and Peking announced that the sentence of another had been reduced.

title: Scott Defeats Leathers
description: Jeff Scott of the Columbia Club captured the Heights Casino Limited A Division squashracquets tournament yesterday by beating John Leathers, 153, 815, 415, 1613, 155.

title: New City Jail Plan Scored
description: A new cityordered plan for a second Men's House of Detention in Manhattan  to house 1,200 inmates on a site adjacent to the present jail in lower Manhattan  has conic under attack from some penal experts and public officials who oppose the building of any large new facility now.

title: HEALTH CARE GAIN SOUGHT BY BLACKS
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 12 A black woman from IowaDon't use my name; I took some sick time to come here called to her fellow passengers not to hurry as they got off the bus that had shuttled them from meeting rooms of conference on black health care to a cafeteria for lunch.

title: BACH MARATHON LASTS 4 HOURS
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonia will probably not know for sure if marathon concerts are a good idea until its season of four of them ends next spring, but it and Lukas Foss, its new musical adviser and conductor, have now made it safely through the first one and can begin their assessment of the concept.

title: Attack by Saigon Against Chup Plantation Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 13 (AP)  Six thousand South Vietnamese troops opened a land and nir assault today against the Chup rubber plantation, a major North Vietnamese divisional headquarters in eastern Cambodia, military spokesmen announced.

title: Chess: Spassky Is Seeing Action In Alekhine Memorial Play
description: The Alekhine Memorial Tournament, now in progress in Moscow, brought together the chess champion of the world, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, and his compatriot, Mikhail Tal, a former world titleholder. The antagonisti employed a Sicilian Defense, the line of which is a favorite with Bobby Fischer, the American chess genius who is slated for a title match with. Spassky some time before June, 1972.

title: MRS. ROBERT N. SHELLI
description: Mrs. Victoria Milea Shelli, wife of Robert N. Shelli, chief court reporter at the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, died of cancer yesterday in ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 52 years old and lived at 33 North Road, Bronxville, N. Y.

title: Robbers Slay Policeman
description: LINCOLN, Calif., Dec. 12 (UPI)Fleeing robbers, armed with a military M16 and other guns, killed one policeman and seriously wounded another today in a blazing exchange of fire and then sped away in a policeman's private automobile. Patrolman Lester Schellbach was reported fatally shot.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 12 (UP) Negotiators for the Boeing Company and the International Association of Machinists reached agreement today on a new threeyear contract covering 20.000 hourly workers. Details were not made public.

title: Iraq National Oil Company Nears Desert Production
description: NORTH RUMAILA, IraqAbout 18 months ago, there were only snakes and wild lizzards moving across this vast desert expanse, which is world's richest oilfields.

title: H.E.W. Study Says Most States Shun Birth Control Role
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI)Most states are shirking their legal responssibility to provide birth control information and devices for lowincome women under the Federal Government's illegitimacy prevention program, a Government study said today.

title: INDIAN FORCES PRE ARING FOR BIG ATTACK ON DACCA;
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 12  Indian troops in East Pakistan resumed their advance on Dacca today and reached the little town of Narsingdi, 22 miles northeast of the capital, Indian spokesmen said.

title: COURT PLEA MADE BY MAD BOMBER
description: George P. Metesky, who attained notoriety as the mad bomber in the nineteenfifties, is one of several mental patients challenging the constitutionality of their confinement in Matteawan State Hospital.

title: Miss Gould Cots 0:18.6 From FreoStyle Mark
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 12 (AP)Shane Gould, the 15yearold Australian swimmer, added a fifth world record to her collection today, clocking 17 minutes 0.6 seconds in the 1,500meter freestyle.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The Hackensack Giants, New Jersey's idols of tomorrow, stopped Roger Staubach and the other Dallas Cowboys cold for three plays yesterday but from that point on their fortunes declined. Shaking off the effects of their discouraging start, the defending champions of the National Football Conference produced a 4214 victory as an encore to their recent 5210 conquest of the New York Jets.

title: Poll Says Nixon Leads Rivals
description: President Nixon, as of last month, would defeat any of the four leading Democratic Presidential contenders, but Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Edmund S. Muskie of Maine would give him a close race, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

title: CORNELL BOYCOTT TO FACE INQUIRY
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 12 Officials at Cornell University announced today that a fiveman committee would be set up to study what is now a twogame boycott of the basketball team by six black varsity players. The committee will be given decisionmaking powers.

title: Screen: The Decameron
description: The Decameron, which opened yesterday at the Festival Theater, was shown at the ninth New York Film Festival. The following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared on Oct. 5, 1971, in The New York Times:

title: Nastase Beats Smith for $ 15,000 Tennis Prize
description: PARIS, Dec. 12  In a climactic match that had been anticipated all week, Ilie Nastase of Rumania defeated Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., tonight to win the $15,000 first prize in the Pepsi Masters tennis tournament.

title: Hazard in Central Park
description: Cyclists were dismayed last Saturday to find that Central Park, normally closed to vehicular traffic on weekends, had been invaded by automobiles. The ban had been lifted without prior public notice for Dec. 11 and to relieve congestion on East Side avenues during the two main Christmas shopping weekends.

title: EDWARD E. SCHWEGLER
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Dec. 12 Edward E. Schwegler, who retired 10 years ago as financial vice president of the New Jersey Zinc Company, died yesterday in Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 15 Alan Drive.

title: JACKSON BACKED AT NEGRO PARLEY
description: A number of nationally known black leaders, including Carl B. Stokes, the former Mayor of Cleveland, and Richard G. Hatcher, the Mayor of Gary, Ind., agreed at a meeting here yesterday, to help the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson to form a new black economic development organization.

title: READY TO BUDGE, MRS. MIR SAYS
description: Israeli Premier Golda Meir reiterated last night her nation's desire to sit down for direct negotiations with the Arab states to seek a lasting peace in the Middle East.

title: New Type of Macaroni Embroils the F.D.A. in a Controversy Over Its Label
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  At a time when holiday menus with exotic courses are catching the attention of most foodminded Americans, the Food and Drug Administration is acting as an mmost unwilling mediator In a dispute over a far more prosarc product, macaroni.

title: U.S. AIDE DEFENDS POLLUTION DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, denied today that there had been a slackening of the Nixon Administration's commitment to clean up the nation's air and water, as several environmental groups have charged.

title: Manhattan School Presents Smetana's The Kiss
description: With Tristan and Isolde groaning out their frustration and universeshaking consummation in the Metropolitan Opera's Brobdingnagian production of Wagner's masterpice, it was a pleasure yesterday afternoon to take a charming trip to operatic Lilliput. Frustration and satisfaction also are the themes of Smetana's The Kiss, which had two performances over the weekend at the Manhattan School of Music by the John Brownlee Opera Theater.

title: Officers in Dacca Think Indians Will Reach the City in 48 Hours
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 12Indian troops were advancing on Dacca from three directions tonight and senior Pakistani officers predicted they would reach the East. Pakistani capital within 48 hours.

title: JAPAN TO REMOVE SOME TRADE BARS
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 12Japan made major concessions here today at the close of two days of trade talks with the United, States. The negotiations were aimed at paving the way to a realignment of international currencies when the Group of 10 major currency countries meet Friday and Saturday in Washington.

title: Bridge: Old World Champions Defeat The New World Titleholders
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 12 The Old World champions, appropriately from Italy and representing the Old World, decisively defeated the new world champions, of course from the New World, in the $15,000 challenge match that ended here last night.

title: Lyne Wins Cowboy Crown
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 12 Phil Lyne of George West, Tex., won the world champion allround cowboy title tonight at the national finals of the Rodeo Cowboys Association. Lyne, who won the calfroping event, earned $49,244 this year. Bob Berger of Norman, Okla., had a total of $46,746.

title: Miss Cassls Loses Final
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 12 (AP)Kerry Melville of Australia defeated Rosemary Casals of San Francisco, 64, 60, to win the women's singles final of the New Zealand open today.

title: India Denies Pakistan Land Is Sought
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12The Foreign Minister of India said in an interview today that his Government had no territorial designs in East Pakistan and did not want to destroy Pakistan.

title: Advertising:
description: In a further effort to turn its assets into cash, Lennen & Newell has sold its Pacific division to employes.

title: MARTIN CAPTURES POWERBOAT FINAL
description: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 12 (AP)Bill Martin, a 29yearold furniture dealer from Clark, N. J., captured the Americas Cup power boat championship today, roaring aeross.the finish line five miles ahead of Vincenzo Balestrieri of Rome.

title: Phase 2 Is a Struggle For Burdened System
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12One month after it officially went into operation, Phase Two of the President's economic stabilization program is a bureaucracy still struggling to be born.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Sugarman Assails State Aide's Criticism of Welfare as Political and Misleading
description: Jule M. Sugarman, the city's Human Resources Administrator and Commissioner of Social Services, charged yesterday that the sstate's Welfare InspectorGeneral, George F. Berlinger, was engaged in a political attack on welfare.

title: BRONX THUGS INJURE OFFDUTY POLICEMAN
description: An offduty policeman suffered a skull fracture and head lacerations early yesterday when attacked by two men in an apparent mugging outside his son's home in the Bronx, the police reported.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Crisis Concerts To Help Library
description: Betty Comden and Adolph Green are giving up a night to save a heritage. They want exactly 933 people to join them.

title: Kentucky Gets Message: Indiana Bears Watching
description: I College basketball has taken some funny early bounces and the ranking teams have taken some unexpected detours.

title: Rightist Ulster Senator Slain by Gunmen in Home
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 12Gunmen shot a hardline Protestant Senator tonight, then wrecked his country mansion with a bomb. His body was buried under tons of rubble.

title: Britain and the Market Agree On Fishing, Last Big Dispute
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 12Britain and the Common Market reached agreement early this morning after a night of talks on commercial fishing, the last major issue to be resolved in Britain's move to join the sixnation bloc.

title: What's Lindsay to Lose?
description: First of all, said Mayor Lindsay to the assembled members of the City Hall press corps, in the departure of Dick Lewisohn from the Office of Deputy Mayor...

title: Fashions to Be Matchedor Mixed Up
description: Scott Barrie's spring fashion show was well along before the first skirt appeared, and that was a long one. Up to then, it was pants. Earlier in the week, Ralston remarked at his own show that most of the women he knew wore pants all day, and often at night. So much for the fashion establishment's putdown of skirts. Barrie doesn't have anything against skirts, not even kneelength ones. But he didn't feel compelled to make any because he thinks the long ones look more romantic.

title: War Summary
description: NEW DELHIIndia reported that her troops had resumed their advance on Dacca and had reached a town 22 miles northeast of the East Pakistani capital.

title: 500MILE TEXAS RACE CAPTURED BY PETTY
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Dec. 12 (UPI)  Richard Petty, completing the greatest year of any driver in NASCAR history, captured the $80,000 Texas 500 by half a lap from Buddy Baker of Charlotte, N.C., in a Dodge. It was Petty's 21st victory in 1971.

title: DR. MILDRED GROHT, TEACHER OF DEAF, 81
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Dec. 12Dr. Mildred A. Groht, who retired in 1960 as academic principal of the Lexington School for the Deaf in New York, died last night in an Ossining nursing home. She was 81 years old and lived here.

title: Flyers' Fast Start Brings 41 Victory Over Canadians
Excerpts From Text of Interview With Sadat
description: CAIRO, Dec. 10Following are excerpts from a transcript of an interview with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt by C. L. Sulzberger:

title: Celtics Set Back Royals, 96 to 83, As Havlicek Stars
Carrier Leaves Vietnam, May Sail to Dacca Area
description: SAIGON, South. Vietnam, Dec. 12  The United States Navy's nuclearpowered aircraft carrier Enterprise and task force of several amphibious ships and destroyers left Vietnamese waters Friday heading toward the Indian. Ocean for a possible rescue of American citizens from the East Pakistani capital of Dacca.

title: SARAH E. CADOO
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Dec. 12 Sarah E. Cadoo, a former dean of women at Rutgers University's summer school and retired principal of the Franklin School here, died yesterday at her home, 26 Locust Drive. Her age was 82.

title: Fashions to Be Matchedor Mixed Up
description: Scott Barrie's spring fashion show was well along before the first skirt appeared, and that was a long one. Up to then, it was pants. Earlier in the week, Ralston remarked at his own show that most of the women he knew wore pants all day, and often at night. So much for the fashion establishment's putdown of skirts. Barrie doesn't have anything against skirts, not even kneelength ones. But he didn't feel compelled to make any because he thinks the long ones look more romantic.

title: 22 BODIES FOND IN BLAST IN TUNNEL
description: PORT HURON, Mich., Dec. 12The death toll climbed to 22 today in the gas explosion in a water tunnel being built under Lake Huron, and Federal and state investigators began seeking the cause of the disaster.

title: 4th Newton Trial Weighed After 3d Ends in Deadlock
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 12 (UPI)District Attorney Lowell Jensen pondered today whether to try the Black Panther leader Huey P. Newton for a fourth time on charges of killing an Oakland policeman in 1967.

title: Central Bankers Meet
description: BASEL, Switzerland, Dec. 12 (Reuters)  Western central bank governors met here this weekend for their monthly monetary discussions. Informed sources said the talks were routine, serving as background for the Group of 10 finance ministers' meeting in Washington next weekend.

title: A Tradition Aids the Neediest
description: Among the contributors to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday was a couple who have continued a custom of annual donations begun just before their wedding in December, 1966.

title: High Ideal Sold for $500,000
description: LONDON, Ontario, Dec. 12 (AP)High Ideal, one of North America's top 3yearold pacers, has been sold for $500,000 to a Kentucky stable where he will he put out to stud.

title: Congress Appears Willing To Raise Gold Price a Bit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12Congress appears to be no serious obstacle to a small, technical increase in the official price of gold if this is deemed necessary by President Nixon and the Secretary of the Treasury, John B. Connally, to achieve an international monetary agreement in major negotiations to take place here next weekend.

title: Postscript to the FlatFoot Epidemic: A Story of Conquest
description: In his recent letter Dr. Seymour Frank writes that the Podiatry Society of New York, of which he is president, submitted a detailed plan to the city two years ago to prevent abuses of unjustified prescribing of orthopedic shoes. The City Health Department, he alleges, rejected our recommendation out of hand.

title: Teacher Stabbed to Death
description: Walter L. Clarke, a 41yearold French teacher at the Louis D. Brandeis High School, was found stabbed to death yesterday in his bachelor apartment at 1494 Second Avenue, between 77th and 78th Streets. He had been knifed in the chest, the police said. They added that he and another man had entered the apartment at 11:30 P.M. Friday. Just before he was killed, five hours later, a loud argument broke out between the two, the police said.

title: New Montpelier Pavilion Is Rebuilt Image of Past
description: MONTPELIER, Vt.  They used to refer to the building here as the reconstructed Pavilion Hotel, but slowly the word hotel was dropped.

title: JOHN R. MARKHAM, M. I. T. PROFESSOR
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 12 John Raymond Markham, professor emeritus of aeronautical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a leading authority on wind tunnels, died today in Sancta Maria Hospital. Professor Markham, who was injured in a fall last month, was 76 years old and lived in Belmont.

title: Cooperating in Space
description: There have been so many remarkable space accomplishments since Sputnik I went into orbit in 1957 that the tendency is to be blas about even spectacular new advances. That probably explains the lack of excitement when Moscow revealed that it had successfully softlanded a capsule on Mars and had received data train the Martian surface early this month.

title: Leaseway Raises Dividend
description: The board of the Leaseway Transportation Corporation announced in Cleveland this weekend a 3 per cent stock dividend payable in midJanuary to holders of record Dec. 23; an increase in the quarterly dividend to 13 cents a share from 12 cents a share, payable in early February to holders of record Jan. 6, 1972, and a 3for2 split in the form of a 50 per cent common stock dividend, payable in early February to holders of record Jan. 6.

title: A 30Year Plan for PollutionFree Energy Sources
description: HARTFORDThe goal: an electric power supply essential to man's harmonious relationship to his physical environment and necessary to his future social wellbeing. To achieve such a supply may require as much as thirty years of intense research effort. The search for such an energy supply should, therefore, be a central purpose for the electric utility industry and the nation over the next generation.

title: U.S. Steel's Price Rise Inspires Industry to Look for an Upturn
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 12Steel producers were looking for rising prices and orders last week.

title: Fireman's Pay Boost
description: Neither imminence of fiscal disaster nor introduction of Federal antiinflation controls seems to have diminished the city's prodigality at the bargaining table.

title: Motorcycle Stuntman Hurt
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 (UPI)Joe Einhorn, a motorcycle stuntman, succeeded in leaping over 14 parked cars with his motorcycle last night, but was injured when he smashed into a bale of hay while trying to stop inside the Cow Palace. The 23yearold motorcyclist sustained a broken nose and a concussion.

title: State and City Officials Oppose Proposal for U.S. Rent Controls
description: State Housing Commissioner Charles J. Urstadt strongly opposed yesterday a proposal passed by the House of Representatives that would place rents in the city and state under Federal economic, stabilization guidelines.

title: Cleveland Editor Retiring
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 12 (UPI) William M. Ware, executive editor of the Cleveland Plain Dealer, will retire Dec. 31, it was announced today. Mr. Ware, 60 years old, has been associated with the newspaper for nearly 38 years.

title: Books of The Times
description: If you haven't chosen your Christmas presents by now, you might have to give books. And you could do worse Though books have somehow acquired the reputation of being unimaginative gifts, this amounts to a contradiction in terms. When properly chosen, they are among the most imaginative. And though convention holds them to be impersonal as well, this too doesn't stand up under analysis; For example, in traditional Japanese culture, bride used to be given a book of pornographic drawings, showing her how to please her husband.

title: Lillian Lesh Married
description: Miss Lillian Rita Lesh, daughter of Irving Lesh of New York and the late Mrs. Lesh, was married here last evening to Richard Michael Heidcnberg. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Jack A. Heidenberg of Englewood, N. J. Rabbis Theodore L. Adams and Joseph Wermuth officiated at the ceremony in the St. RegisSheraton Roof.

title: U.S. CALLS ON U.N. TO ACT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Monday, Dec. 13The United States urged the Security Council last night to call upon India to accept forthwith a ceasefire and a mutual withdrawal in the IndianPakistani war.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Dec. 12Record of an imaginary press briefing in New Delhi by the Prime Minister's mythical foreign affairs adviser, Dr. Kishan Jha:

title: HOTA ELEVEN WINS, 10, TO GAIN FINAL
description: New York Hota and the GermanHungarians, two of the best soccer teams in the area, reached the New York final of the United States Challenge Cup yesterday by posting 10 victories over the GreekAmericans and Eintracht, respectively.

title: Tobin Leaving Port Body Alter 30 Years as Chief
description: Austin J. Tobin, who has been the executive director of the Port of New York Authority for nearly 30 years, announced yesterday that he would retire at the end of March to allow for the orderly transfer of executive responsibility to other hands.

title: 49ers Top Falcons, 243, To Gain Ground on Rams
Kate Aitken, Radio Star In Canada, Is Dead at 81
description: TORONTO, Dec. 12 (AP) Rate Aitken, whose radio show on homemaking was a popular attraction in Canada for almost a quarter century, died in a hospital here yesterday. She was 81 years old.

title: Advertising:
description: J. Walter Thompson is moving toward its first acquisition since going public a year ago.

title: OTB PLAY STARTS ON FLORIDA TODAY
description: Despite the threat of a Federal injunction, the Offtrack Betting Corporation will go ahead today with plans to take wagers on thoroughbred races at Tropical Park in Florida.

title: Goalby Takes Bahamas Open, Beating Archer by One Stroke
CHIEFS TAKE TITLE AND OUST RAIDERS
Pakistan Cites Indian Death Threat at Comilla
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 12A Pakistani spokesman said tonight that Indian forces in East Pakistan had warned Pakistani defenders that if they did not surrender, they would be turned over after the war to guerrillas to be butchered.

title: HardPressed Homeowners in Spring Valley Fear Reassessment Program
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Dec. 12  Listening to people here, a visitor would almost think that someone was stalking the streets, sowing horror and destruction.

title: 10,670 Greeks Elect a Consultative Body
description: ATHENS, Dec. 12A selected group of Greeks voted today to elect 60 members of a consultative committee on legislation, an advisory body the Government has promoted as training ground for a new kind of politician.

title: Bright Musical Package Is Tied With Stokowshi Craftsmanship
description: A New York first, a nostalgic reunion and a world premiere were among the special attractions of the American Symphony Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, with the podium magnetism of Leopold Stokowski further emphasizing the sense of occasion. The premiere was Mantrajana by Matthias Bamert, a work completed this year in honor of the American Symphony's 10th anniversary; the local debut presented four Holiday Pieces by Charles Ives, Stokowski taking the composer's hint that they may be lumped together as a symphony and, after many years of individual engagements, the brothers RicciRuggiero and Giorgiofinally made their first joint appearance here as soloists in the Brahms Double Concerto.

title: Elliott Proposes a Screening of Forest Hills Project Tenants
description: Donald H. Elliott, chairman of the City Planning Commission, suggested yesterday that an advisory committee including representative Forest Hills residents might work with the City Housing Authority to screen tenants for the controversial lowincome housing project planned for the middleincome community.

title: Talks in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (Reuters) Mr. Dhar, the Indian Foreign Ministry official, had preliminary, lowlevel talks today with Soviet officials after arriving last night, an Indian source said.

title: Nixon in Azores for Pompidou Talks Beginning Today
description: LAJES FIELD, the Azores, Dec. 12  President Nixon arrived here shortly before 10 P.M. (6 P.M., Eastern standard time) today for two days of crucial conferences with President Pompidou of France on monetary and trade relations between the United States and the European Economic Community.

title: Boston Wins in Squash
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12Boston rallied today to defeat New York, 43, in the finale of the twoday intercity squashracquets Class A tournament. Anil Nayar won the deciding match from Tay Nelson, 515, 158, 1512, 1511.

title: French Conductor, 29, Achieves Mitropoulos Victory and $5,000
description: Jacques Delacote, a 29yearold Frenchman, won the $5,000 first prize last night in the finals of the 10th Dimitri Mitropoulos International Competition, one of the world's most prestigious conducting contests. Mr. Delacote, a handsome bachelor who now lives in Vienna, was awarded the Gold Medal over two other finalists after each contestant had conducted a symphony orchestra at Philharmonic Hall in three pieces.

title: A Reference to Cuba And Air Rider Is Held
description: A Washington man who was described by some fellow passengers as drunk allegedly made a vague hijacking threat to a stewardess on a New Yorkbound Braniff airliner yesterday and was arrested when the plane landed at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Arts Abroad
description: LONDONSaturday afternoon in the north of England. One by one the men walk into the bleak locker room. They greet Harry, a sour, taciturn cleaner, and tease him about his obsession that the Communists are enveloping Europe. One of the men has been with a girlfriend; another one fusses with his tool kit; a third smokes a cigar with bravura and speaks with nervous humor. Within moments the room is crowded and noisy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am utterly appalled at this latest instance of the depths to which U.S. foreign policy ha's fallen. The Times reported on Nov. 21 and 22 that, in addition to the $100 million in military and economic aid that the U.S. will dole out to Turkey this year, the State Department had agreed to give Turkey $35 million to pay its peasants not to grow opium poppies. Even worse, it was reported that a Turkish Cabinet minister asserted that the $35 million was only onetenth of the amount required to do the job. The whole, shameful exercise remiiads me of the tribute demanded by the Barbary pirates in the early eighteenhundreds.

title: United to Back T.W.A. Bid For a 2.8% Rise in Air Fare
description: United Air Lines this week plans to file a motion with the Civil Aeronautics Board in support of a 2.8 per cent fare increase sought by Trans World Airlines and which was turned down on technical grounds.

title: Support Called Key To Effort to Screen SickleCell Anemia
description: A series of recommendations for mass screening programs for sicklecell anemia are published in this week's Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Pakistani Forces Take Ghost Town in Kashmir
description: CHHAMB, Kashmir, Dec. 12 This village in the Indian section of disputed Kashmir is a shattered ghost town once more, and the earth around it is scorched by battle.

title: JAMES F. O'CONNOR OF POSTGAZETTE, 69
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 12James F. O'Connor, vice president and business manager of The Pittsburgh PostGazette, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: DOBERMAN IS BEST AT CAMDEN SHOW
description: PENNSAUKEN, N. J., Dec. 12 The third topwinning dog in America for 1971, a Doberman pinscher, Ch. Dolph von Tannenwald, was named best of 1,277 dogs at the 39th annual show of the Camden Kennel Club at Ivy Stone Inn today. Dolph is owned by Sheila and George West of Muttontown, L. I.

title: Her Court Is on Arctic Shores, Her Cause Is Eskimos' Rights
description: BARROW, AlaskaIt was four below zero and the wind was taking fierce nips at the carcasses of eight caribou stowed on the roof of the twostory green frame cottage a couple of hundred yards from the awesome, icedover Arctic shore.

title: CounterOriented Fund Explains Objectives
description: Ralph P. Coleman Jr., 48. runs the Over  The  Counter Securities Fund, a small but successful mutual fund that concentrates its portfolio in unlisted stocks. Based in Oreland, Pa., the fund is rounding out its 15th year. Mr. Coleman offers some helpful pointers for investors who want to pick their own overthecounter stocks. He also has some harsh words for big institutions that rush inand then rush out  of holdings in the unlisted market.

title: An Appraisal
description: David Sarnoff was the tough and determined Mr. DoIt of broadcasting, a man whose influence in one way or another touched on two generations of listeners and viewers. He belonged to the old school of autocratic tycoon, the absolute monarch of all he surveyed in the kingdom or the Radio Corporation of America. But his relentless drive, even his insatiable vanity, was an undeniably important factor in introducing the country to the mixed blessings of the 20th century's electronic culture.

title: Lakers Set N.B.A. Mark By Taking 21st in Row
If Panic Sets in: Gift Ideas
description: There are still 11yes, 11shopping days left till Christmas, and the countdown is beginning.

title: Advertising:
description: After a more than pleasant 45year relationship with Edwin Bird Wilson, Inc., the Bowery Savings Bank is moving its advertising account to Ogilvy & Mather.

title: U.S. Says Soviet Moves Vessels to Indian Ocean
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Senior Administration officials said today that the Soviet Union appeared to be reinforcing its naval strength in the Indian Ocean. They said that they believed that the move was connected with the IndianPakistani war.

title: MRS. WALTON STORM
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., Dec. 12Mrs. Helen Battin Storm, widow of Walton Storm, a cotton broker, died today in a convalescent home. She was 84 years old and lived at 43 Meadow Road.

title: Stafford Captures Final
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 12 David Stafford of the host club won the annual Bronxville Field Club invitation squash tennis tournament today by defeating Joe Holmes of the Yale Club in th.e final, 157, 1115, 1813, 158.

title: Bhutto Vows Fight to End In Talk to Pakistanis Were
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12Foreign Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan told a cheering throng of Pakistanis today, We are not cowards, we will fight to the last man if it has to be.

title: Hijackers Are Routed From Jet in Costa Rica
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 12 (AP)Costa Rican national guardsmen used tear gas today to get three hijackers out of a commandeered Nicaraguan jetliner, that had stopped here for fuel. One hijacker was shot fatally, the authorities said.

title: Ghulam Mohammed Sadiq, 59, Kashmir Chief Minister, Dies
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 12 (AP)Ghulam Mohammed Sadiq, the Chief Minister of Kashmir, died of a heart attack today as Indian and Pakistani troops battled in his state. He was 50 years old.

title: FRANK WOLFF DIES; SCREEN ACTOR, 43
description: ROME, Dec. 12 (AP)  Frank Wolff, an American movie actor, was found dead today in his room at a hotel here. The police said he had slashed his throat. The body of the 43yearold actor was found by a chambermaid.

title: JOE URI, OWNED PARIS NIGHTCLUB
description: HILLSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 12Joe Zelli, who operated the popular Paris nightclub the Royal Box in Montmartre after World War I and brought it to New York in the early nineteenthirties, died today at his home here. His age was 82.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Talk of New York
description: Until September, there was little except two flag poles to distinguish the welfare center on 13th Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas from the other nonresidential buildings on the block, which are mostly warehouses.

title: Levitt Says Study Shows State's Intelligence Agency, With Data on 4 Million People, Is a Peril to Rights
description: Controller Arthur Levitt assailed the state's intelligence agency yesterday, saying it inadequately protected individual rights, gave thousands of employes all over the state access to its confidential files on four million people, and provided slipshod security of its own premises.

title: Justice Department on Trial
description: Under the Voting Rights, Act of 1965 it is the Justice Department's responsibility to certify the nondiscriminatory nature of any state legislation that affects voting procedures. The question of discrimination against minority groups, was clearly at issue when the Arizona Legislature passed a law that purged the state's voting rolls by requiring all voters to reregister at tenyear intervals. As many of Arizona's Indians, MexicanAmericans and Negroes live in isolated rural areas, the effect of the new law was to lower the percentage of reregistrants among those segments of the populationand this was surely its intention. Yet Attorney General Mitchell approved the law. Instead of protecting minority voting rights, the Justice Department appeared to be acting against the spirit of the Federal statute.

title: Theater: In Its Nihilism, a Strength
description: Life is crammed with unlikelihoods. The two most ambitious theatrical productions in New York during 1971 happened not on Broadway, not even off Broadway, but at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The first was Robert Wilson's Deafman Glance, which started in Brooklyn and then went on to carry the new glory of the American avantgarde theater throughout Europe. And now we have the American premiere of Jean Genet's The Screens, which lasts for 5 hours, has 17 scenes and employs 43 actors.

title: Reinapping of State Will Start At a Special Session Tomorrow
description: The state's 207 legislators will convene In Albany tomorrow to reapportion the Legislature for the 1972 elections amidst charges and denials of secret gerrymandering.

title: City Hall Notes
description: A sparsely furnished corner office at Madison Avenue and 48th Street is the place where major City Hall decisions are being made these days.

title: High Soviet Official Discusses Bang la Desh With Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 12 (Reuters)Vasily V. Kuznetsov, the Soviet First, Deputy Foreign, Minister, held talks on the In dianPakistani war with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi shortly after his arrival today.

title: What Is a Woman?: I
description: LONDONA woman is a woman before she is born. The hands that knit in pink or blue, the midwife's tone of voice, the joy or disappointment of the parents, tell the fetus or newborn infant what it is to expect from life. Or rather, what life is: its destiny, masculine or feminine. Each of these social responses seems to those performing them, original, replete with individual variation, innocent of all stereotypes. Yet, they are precisely the first manifestations that the newborn baby receives of all the accumulated customs, conventions and ideas of our society.

title: Two Small Quakes on Coast
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 12 (UPI)Two small earthquakes shook the San Francisco Bay area yesterday. Residents in the OaaklandSan Leandro hills reported feeling the temblors, but there was no serious damage.

title: Pioneer in Physics Sees Few Hidden Discoveries
description: Dr. Werner Heisenberg, one, of the few survivors among those whose discoveries laid the foundations of modern physics, believes that, in a sense, the ultimate has probably been reached in probing the innermost sanctum of matter.

title: 2 ON AMEX ELEVATED TO EXECUTIVE POSTS
description: The apopintments of James W. Walker Jr. and Winsor H. Watson Jr. as executive vice presidents of the American Stock Exchange have been announced by Paul Kolton, president. Both men formerly were senior vice presidents.

title: Joan Creamer Is Bride
description: EAST ISLIP, L. I., Dec. 12 Miss Joan Frances Creamer, a supervisor with the New York Telephone Company, was married in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here today to Harold Stanley Scott, who is with the Suffolk County Department of Health as director of the Rodent Control Unit. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. James Alda Creamer of East Islip and Rowland Scott, councilman in the Town of Babylon, and Mrs. Scott. The ecumenical ceremony was performed by he Rev. William P. Henesy, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Calvin Gray of the First Presbyterian Church in Babylon.

title: Screen: From Therapy to a Sad and Comic Marriage
description: They meet at group therapy. He wants to expiate his guilt for all the broken female hearts and near-miss suicides that trail behind him like clouds of glory in his search for a right relationship. She would also like to escape her past. "A failure in everything, in art as in life," after 10 years in group, she is still trying. She is Pandora Gold and he is Giggy Pinimba, both in their 30's, and on the grounds of emotional instability, intellectual incompatibility, and religious unsuitability (for starts) it should be clear that they are made for each other.At least, that is the premise of their movie, "Made for Each Other," starring Renee Taylor as Panda and Joseph Bologna as Gig, written by Miss Taylor and Mr. Bologna, and directed by Robert B. Bean. It is the story of how two New Yorkers meet each other (or, more properly, fail to avoid each other), hurt each other, horrify each other's parents, and ultimately blunder their way into marriage. It is also comedy, uncomfortable comedy of a fairly unusual sort in that it locates the sources of everybody's vulnerability and does not disguise the misery of anybody's pain. Miss Taylor and Mr. Bologna ("Lovers and Other Strangers") are a very serious comic team, and though their work virtually cries of warm humanity there are times when it seems somewhat closer to the clinic than to the heart.There are flashbacks from Panda's childhood and Gig's childhood, scenes from their previous affairsa pair of life histories that are often funny in detail but ultimately forbidding in mass. In a sense, we come to understand too muchso much that Panda and Gig lose some of the crucial element of surprise that really humanizes comic characters and take on a kind of rational complexity that by explaining, only seems to humanize them.Sometimes the aims of analysis and comedy work together perfectly, as in the nightclub act that Pandora has prepared for her artistic comeback, which she stages as an identity crisis. The audience is supposed to decide who she should be; she does a marvelously awkward rendition of "Falling in Love Again" from "Der Blaue Engel" (her German, not mine) and the audience loves her and decides she should be Rita Hayworth. This is a moment of real theater and a triumph for Pandora (and Miss Taylor), but such moments are more the exception than the rule.Nevertheless, "Made for Each Other" contains enough good writing for half a dozen better movies, and its performances do everyone proud. This includes all the parents, but especially Helen Verbit and Louis Zorich as Pandora's mother and her pandering dad, Norman Shelly as the doctor leading the marathon group, and Joseph Bologna as Gig, who finally chooses Pandora because with his other girls he's become impotent.But the film belongs to Renee Taylor, an intelligent actress and a fine comedienne who has mastered the art of seeming both ugly and beautiful at the same time, which is much of what her role and her movie are really all about.

title: Nitschke, Brockington Have Their Day as Packers Win
SOVIET AID TO INDIA ASSAILED BY PEKING
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 12India was depicted as virtually a vassal state of the Soviet Union in a commentary from Peking received here today through Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency.

title: City Finds a Diet Drink Chock Fall O' Calories
description: An analysis of the calories In the socalled diet freeze served by one store in the Chock Full O' Nuts restaurant chain has disclosed that it contained 126 calories instead of 60 as advertised, Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myersort reported. yesterday.

title: SENATE APPROVES WIDER U.S. CURB ON RENTS IN CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The Senate approved tonight legislation that would continue authority for economic controls and bring all rent  controlled apartments under Federal guidelines.

title: STOPGAP AID PLAN IS SENT TO HOUSI
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 Congress took a tentative step toward breaking the adjournment impasse over foreign aid tonight when a House committee prepared a compromise stopgap financing plan designed to will reluctant Senate support.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
U.S. PURCHASES CORN TO HELP RAISE PRICE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) Starting a Government move to increase prices that some farmbloc legislators hope eventually will take up to 600 million bushels of corn off a glutted market, Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz announced today the purchase of 1.425 million bushesl of corn in Middle Western markets.

title: Market Place: A Comparison Of Investments
description: There are comparisons and comparisons  and none is completely adequate. But here is a selfserving one from the. Investment Company Institute that is, at least, interesting.

title: Baltimore's Consumers Uneasy About Phase 2
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 13Consumers in this key city Chesapeake Bay are cautious and even troubled today. They say it in various ways, but the refrain is the sane: They are irked by stillrising prices and disturbed by the lack of definition of the latest phase of President Nixon's economic policy. They want to know what it all means to them, their jobs and their income.

title: Donor to Neediest Reminds Friends
description: According to a contributor to the Neediest Cases Fund recorded yesterday, the pleasure of seeing an article about her donation last year was quickly tempered by the reactions of her friends.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Everything seemed to bounce right for us last year, said Tom Landry, and it kept bouncing right for us from midseason into the Super Bowl. Then it stopped bouncing.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation raised an indicated $29.2million yesterday with the competitive sale of 1.4 million new common shares. A White, Weldled syndicate bid $20.859 for the stock and reoffered it at $21.50, or  point higher than the closing; price on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Harlem Dance Theater Comes of Age
description: Arthur Mitchell is an overachiever of the nicest kind. Three years ago he founded the Dance Theater of Harlem and now, together with his associate director, that exceptional teacher Karel Shook, the company has progressed so far that it demands to be judged at a very high level.

title: Redskins Win, 3824, to Gall Playoffs
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13George Allen brought his Wash. ington Redskins, including eight exRams, back to Los Angeles tonight on a memorable scalping party. The Redskins tommyhawked the Rams, 3824, and clinched a National Football Conference playoff spot.

title: Knicks Obtain Faulk From Bulls
description: The Knicks, in an attempt to strengthen their front court while Willis Reed is recuperating from tendonitis of his left knee, obtained, Charlie Paulk, a 6400t9inch forward, yesterday from the Chicago Bulls. The Knicks gave up cash and their secondround pick in the 1973 college draft.

title: A Plan and a Policy
description: The proposal for a Madison Avenue mall, tied to a larger traffic plan for midtown Manhattan, is being greeted as pie in the sky by a public that has been fed little else by politicians in the past.

title: E.E.C. TRUST RUE HITS U.S. CONCERN
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 13The Executive Commission of the Common Market, in the first decision of its kind, has told the Continental Can Company of the United States that its purchase last year of a Dutch company was a breach of antitrust rules in the sixnation European Economic Community.

title: News Analysis
description: BONN, Dec. 12The language, the music and the very idea of America are still deeply embedded in the life of West Germany, and popular as well as official dependence on American protectionand troopsremains obsessive.

title: NEW HARASSMENT CHARGED IN ATTICA
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Dec. 33Two inmates of the Attica Correctional Facility testified before a Federal magistrate inside the prison today that no sooner had they left an interview with newsmen last month in which they complained about harassment and abuse by guards than they were subjected to new threats and mistreatment.

title: Campus Trend: Objective News
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 College newspapers, many of which took a sharp swing toward radical journalism during the campus turmoil of the late nineteensixties, appear, for the most part, to have made a conscious move back to objective news coverage.

title: The Talk of Clary, Ind.
description: GARY, Ind., Dec. 13  For the first time in a decade, the skies over Gary these days are clean and crisp. It is now possible to breathe deeply without coughing and see clearly from the lower reaches of Broadway northward to the Indiana Tollway overpass.

title: Nassau Agency Makes Public a Controversial 1517 ear Master Plan for County
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 13A comprehensive plan for the development of Nassau County, the first in the 73year history of the county, was made public today by the county Planning Commission.

title: Firm soviet Backing of India Is Said to Irk Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The Soviet Union's unswerving support of India in the war with Pakistan has caused irritation and disquiet in the Nixon Administration, State Department officials sale today.

title: Dacca in Brief: Swarming, Dusty, Beleaguered City
description: Beleaguered Dacca, 150 miles northeast of Calcutta, India, on the Burhi Ganga River, has beenin recent, more tranquil timesa city where a visitor could briefly imagine himself removed from the past.

title: Packard Charges Politics Bars Big Defense Savings
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Savings of at least 31billion a year might be realized if political constraints did not prevent the closing of various military bases around the country, David Packard said today as he stepped down as Deputy Secretary of Defense.

title: Notes on People
description: Mrs. Pamela Digby Churchill Hayward Harriman, the English born third wife of W. Averell Harriman, stepped before Federal Judge Thomas F. Croake to take the oath of allegiance to the United States.

title: Senior Executive Is Named By InterAmerican Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The Inter  American Development Bank has announced the appointment of Henry J. Costanzo as executive vice president, replacing I. Graydon Upton. Mr. Costanzo has been United States executive director of the bank. By tradition, a Latin American has been president and United States citizen executive vice president.

title: Rockefeller to Disclose New Tax Plan
description: ALBANY, Dec. 13Governor Rockefeller will disclose tomorrow the specifics of his proposal to levy $425million in new taxes as part of his plan to meet a $1.5billion budget deficit he says the state faces in the next 15 months.

title: Test for Commodity Dealers
description: All new commodity dealers employed by member firms of the Chicago Board of Trade or the Chicago Mercantile Exchange will be required to pass a new certification test beginning in February that is expected to satisfy requirements for commodity dealers in California and those of the New York Stock Exchange for memberfirm commodity brokers. Thus, it could represent a national certification examination for commodity dealers.

title: O'BRIEN AND G.O.P. CLASH OVER I. T. & T.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP)  The Democratic national chairman, Lawrence F. O'Brien, challenged the Administration today to explain an antitrust settlement with a company that reportedly pledged $400,000 through a subsidiary to help finance the Republican National Convention in San Diego next summer.

title: Saturdays Mother
description: Ma?

title: White House Glitters for Christmas and Reunion
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP)President Nixon and his family are planning a gala turkey dinner at the White House Christmas day with all of their inlaws and former First Lady, Mamie Eisenhower, as guests. The President has promised, besides, to take his family on an outing to New York to attend Dr. Norman Vincent Peale's Marble Collegiate Church, where Julie and David Eisenhower were married, go out for dinner andsee a play. But no date has been set.

title: City Center's Board Elects 5 Members and 2 Officers
description: The board of directors of the City Center of Music and Drama elected five new members and two new officers at a special meeting last week.

title: Cambodia Hopes to Erase Army's Paper Battalions
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 13 (UPI)Premier Lon, Nol announced a crash program today to clean corruption out of the Cambodian Army by cracking down on paper battalions.

title: Judge Enjoins Phone Union From Respecting Picket Line
description: United States District Court Judge Edmund L. Palmieri enjoined Local 1190 of the A.F.L.C.I.O. Communications Workers of America yesterday from continuing to respect the picket lines of fellow craftsmen in 23 other C.W.A. locals striking the New York Telephone Company throughout the state.

title: Atlantic Airlines Approve Pact; New Fares Effective on April 1
description: GENEVA, Dec. 13The International Air Transport Association announced today that the basic agreement on reduced fares reached in Honolulu last month by the major airlines that ply the North Atlantic has been completed and formally approved to take effect April 1.

title: Some Butler Votes Barred
description: Paul S. Dopp, former chairman of the Butler Aviation International, Inc., was barred yesterday by a Federal Court here from voting a portion of the shares he owns in the company at the annual meeting to be held tomorrow.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Saigon, reads the dateline, and part of the story goes as follows:

title: PAKISTANIS CONTINUE MEETINGS IN PEKING
description: PEKING, Dec. 13 (Reuters)Pakistani diplomats continued their contacts with Chinese officials today over the IndianPakistani war, Pakistani sources reported.

title: U.S.Japan Split Continues
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 13 Chances for a realignment of international currencies before the year's end appear poor, judging from the tone of the closed twoday trade negotiations here between the United States and Japan, which ended yesterday.

title: Credit Market Rates Fall;
description: Interest rates were lowered throughout the credit markets yesterday in the wake of the Federal Reserve Board's discountrate reduction and the cut in the prime rate by two large New York banks.

title: I.R.A. Concedes Killing Ulster Senator
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 13 (UPI)The Irish Republican Army said today that it was responsible for shooting Senator John Barnhill to death and blowing up his home yesterday, but said that the assassination was unintentional.

title: Use of Police Decoys Scored in Detroit
description: DETROIT, Dec. 13  The Michigan Civil Rights Commission said today that the Detroit Police Department should stop using patrolmen as decoys to fight street crime, contending that the tactic had led to the fatal shooting of nine persons in the last 11 months without reducing crime.

title: Bandits Get $100,000
description: Burglars made off with between $100,000 and $120,000 from a night deposit vault of a Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company branch in Queens over the weekend, the police said yesterday. The theft was discovered when employes opened the branch at 8120 Northern Boulevard.

title: Laotians Hold Firm
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 13 (Agence FrancePresse)  Several units of the proGovernment special forces were holding on to a 20milewide eastwest front in the eastern part of the Boloven Plateau in southern Laos, an informed western military observer said today.

title: Foreign Minister Ivan H. Bashev Of Bulgaria Dies in Ski Accident
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria Dec. 13 (UPI)  Foreign Minister Ivan Bashev was killed in a weekend skiing accident on a mountain near here, the Foreign Ministry said today. Ho was 55 years old.

title: Appeals Court Throws Out Rule Sending Little Leaguer to Bench
description: Arnold Paglia was ordered reinstated yesterday as a second baseman for the Richmond Funeral Home baseball team of the Staten Island Little League.

title: GERSTAD TO STAGE PLAY ON SUBURBS
description: All the Girls Came Out to Play, a new comedy by Daniel Hollywood and Richard T. Johnson, has been earmarked for Broadway production during the week of Feb. 21.

title: G.M. LEADER SEES GAINS IN ECONOMY
description: DETROIT, Dec. 13James M. Roche, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, predicted today that the economy would expand more vigorously in 1972 than it had this year and that there would he some progress in reducing inflation and unemployment.

title: Season of Light
description: It is so easy to turn away from an outstretched hand, to close the ears to a plea for help, and say, not callously but carelessly, Charity begins at home. But home is neighborhood as well as hearth. Your light shines lonely in the dark; it glows merrily when it is one of the myriad lights that make a city sparkle.

title: Bell Helicopter Elects
description: E. J. Ducayet has been named chairman and James F. Atuins has been made president of Textron's Bell Helicopter division, effective Jan. 1. Mr. Atuins, an executive vice president since 1960, succeeds Mr. Ducayet, who has served as president for the last 11 years.

title: Lakers Hope Streak Means Title
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 The next stop for the recordbreaking Los Angeles Lakers is tomorrow night at Portland against the Trail Blazers, the team with the worst record in the National Basketball Association.

title: DR. JAMES KREUZER, A DEAN AT LEHMAN
description: Dr. James R. Kreuzer, dean of the faculty at Herbert H. Lehman College, where he was also professor of English and vice presidentdesignate, died of a heart attack yesterday in his office in Shuster Hall. He was 58 years old and lived at 2945 214th Place, Bayside, Queens.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON A WIDE FRONT
description: Stock prices forged ahead yesterday an a broad front. Gains in the popular stock averAges were not spectacular, but the breadth of the market's advance was impressive.

title: 7,000 FLEE BLAZE IN FINANCIAL AREA
description: Fire that raged out of control for more than five hours enveloped two 19thcentury buildings in Manhattan's crowded financial district yesterday, forcing the evacuation of about 7,000 people from nearby office towers and snarling street and subway traffic throughout the lateafternoon rush period.

title: Clashes With Agencies Expected as Price Panel Acts to Tackle Inflation in Regulated industries
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The Price Commission will begin to come to grips this week with inflation in the regulated industriesthe gas, electric and telephone bills that account for 4 per cent of the consumer price index, airline anc transit fares and freight rates, which affect indirectly the cost of almost everything.

title: Manson Given Life Term
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 (UPI) Charles Manson was sentenced today to life in prison for the slayings in 1969 of Gary Hinman, a musician, and Donald Shea, a ranch hand. Manson, 89 years old, already is under sentence of death for the murders of Sharon Tate, an actress, and six other persons.

title: Xerox Appoints Chairman and President
description: The board of the Xerox Corporation named Archie R. McCardell as president yesterday, succeeding C. Peter McColough, who was named chairman.

title: Toward Bipartisanship Abroad
description: Under the Constitution, only the Congress can declare war and pay American troops. But the President, as Commander in Chief, can commit the armed forces to combat on his own. In an era of undeclared wars, this ambiguity has led inevitably to executive encroachment on Congressional prerogatives.

title: Hogan Looking Into Persico Connection, if Any, With Witnesses
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office has begun an investigation to detefmine whether Carmine J. Persico, who was acquitted last week of usury charges, wab responsible for the disappearance of the man the state had planned to present as its star witness against him.

title: Cater Directing New Program To Act on Major Media Issues
description: A program to Identify and provide effective action on major issues relating to the communications media is being established by the Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies in cooperation with the Academy for Educational Development.

title: Guard Critically Wounded In Supermarket Robbery
description: An unarmed guard was critically wounded yesterday by a gunman outside a supermarket in the Woodside section of Queens while an armed accomplice of the gunman stole $1,356, mostly in coins, from the store's safe but overlooked $8,000 more.

title: Bridge:
description: Several morals might be drawn from the decisive victory of the Italian Blue Team over the world champion Aces in Las Vegas last week. Some will suggest that the 84point victory in a match of 140 deals reinforces the claim of the Blue Team to be regarded as the greatest team the game has ever known.

title: 4 Quit at Binghamton
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 13 (AP)State University at Binghamton's four black varsity basketball players quit the team today without citing any reason for the walkout, according to their coach Frank Pollard.

title: U.N. Extends Cyprus Force
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13The Security Council voted 14 to 0 today to extend until June 15 the mandate of the United Nations force keeping peace between Greek and Turkish Cypriots. It would have expired Wednesday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 46 Aliens Seized in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (UPI)Investigators from the United States Department of Immigration and Naturalization rounded up 46 illegal immigrants who were going to or leaving their jobs at O'Hare International Airport early today. Robert Germain, chief of investigators for the department, said that the aliens were from Mexico, Peru and Ecuador.

title: Merger News
description: Sir Alan Wilson, chairman of the Glaxo Group, Ltd., said yesterday in London that the company had requested the British Monopolies Commission to investigate the ctinsequences of a take  over bid made for Glaxo earlier this month by the Beecham Group, Ltd. Beecham offered to acquire Glaxo for stock valued at about $737million, making it one of the biggest British takeover bids in years. Both British companies are in the pharmaceutical field, and Glaxo also makes baby foods. Sir Alan said at the ahnual meeting of the company that, we firmly believe that the bid is against the public interest.

title: Vikings and Chiefs Hosts In Dec. 25 Playoff Games
description: The Minnesota Vikings and the Kansas City Chiefs will be the home teams when the National Football League's postseason playoffs begin on Christmas Day, Commissioner Pete Rozelle announced here yesterday.

title: LYRICIST'S CRAFT IS LERNER'S TOPIC
description: The opportunity to hear some of the musical theater's lyricists discuss their craft in the Lyrics and Lyricists series last winter proved so rewarding, and so popular, that the music department of the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. has organized a second series, which began Sunday night with Alan Jay Lerner. This season each of the monthly presentations will be given twice, on Sunday and on Tuesday night.

title: FARM PRICE RISE IN EUROPE IS SEEN
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 13Western Europe will increase farm prices 4 to 6 per cent after a multinational currency realignment, thereby reducing the competitive advantages to be gained by the United States from any dollar devaluation. Sicco Mansholt, the chief farm specialist on the Common Market's Executive Commission, predicted today.

title: LuCretia Ferre, Soprano; Sang With Mormon Choir
description: LuCretia Fevre, a lyric soprano, died yesterday of an aneurysm in Bellevue Hospital. She was 46 years old and lived at 317 West 87th Street.

title: They Reach Hawaii
description: HONOLULU. Dec. 13 (UPI) Mr. Fecteau and Miss Harbert arrived here today en route from Hong Kong to an undisclosed destination.

title: SQUIRES TRIUMPH AS SCOTT NETS 43
description: NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 13 (AP) Charlie Scott scored 43 points tonight to lead the Virginia Squires to a 123115 American Basketball Association victory over the Floridians.

title: PRICES ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: It was anything but a blue Monday on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market yesterday as most stocks In both markets made gains in moderate trading.

title: Red Cross to Aid Wounded, Prisoners of Both Sides
description: GENEVA, Dec. 13The International Committee of the Red Cross announced today that it would assist the wounded and prisoners of both sides in the IndianPakistani war. A committee spokesman said that India and Pakistan had agreed to accept Red Cross help.

title: 23 Former Heroin Addicts Work As Tellers in One OTB Branch
description: The man behind the window at an Offtrack Betting Corporation office is rarely an object of scrutiny for the eager bettor standing impatiently in line, hopefully clutching his Morning Telegraph, his scratch sheets and dollar bills.

title: Girl's Parents Had Given Up
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 13 (AP)The father of Mary Ann Harbert, who was released from prison by China, said today that he and his wife had given their daughter up for dead three years ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 Alarmed by evidence that his rightwing supporters were turning against him, President Nixon asked Attorney General Mitchell, his political philosopher, to suggest a program for holding the right wing, so to speak, to the fuselage. After studying Mitchell's proposals, the President asked for a conference, the transcript follows:

title: Pakistan Expected To Fight to Finish
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 13With Indian troops massing for assaults on Dacca in East Pakistan, there were irwreasing indications here today that Pakistan's general staff had decided to dig in and fight India to the bitter end.

title: SEAGRAMS SETS QUARTER RECORDS
description: Distillers Corporation  Scagrams, Ld., registered the highest sales and earnings for any quarter in its 44year history in the three months ended Oct. 31, it was reported yesterday by Edgar M. Bronfman, president.

title: Polish Reforms Give a Private Farmer Hope and Title to Land
description: BIELAWKI, Poland, Dec. 4Boleslaw Babala is a 27yearold private farmer, one of 3.5 million in Poland. He has finally received clear title to his 25acre spread.

title: Mild Weather Allows Seaway to Stay Open
description: The mild weather that warmed the eastern edge of North America in recent days has provided unexpected relief for skippers of ocean  going ships racing to leave the St. Lawrence Seaway before ice bottles them up for winter.

title: OTB Falters on Tropical Betting
description: Despite a court action in Florida and some costly inaction here by its own computers, the Offtrack Betting Corporation managed to handle $46,657 worth of wagers yesterday on Tropcal Park's thoroughbred races.

title: A.E.C. Names Safety Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The Atomic Energy Commission appointed today its first highlevel official responsible for environmental and safety affairs. The appointee, Julius H. Rubin, was named assistant general manager for environment and safety. He has been serving as special assistant to the commission chairman, Dr. James R. Schlesinger.

title: Foes Balk as Brandt Submits Treaties
description: BONN, Dec. 13The Government of Chancellor Willy, Brandt sulmitted its 1970 gooawill treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland to Parliament today, starting the complex ratification process, and immediately ran into a quarrel with the Opposition on procedure.

title: Theater: Joan Returns
description: What would happen if St. Joan lived today? As Al Carmines sees her in his new musical, Joan, she would be a bombthrowing young New York radical, buffeted by friends and enemies, each using her for his own particular purpose. And she would die tomorrow.

title: Stare Sales Advance
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The Department of Commerce reported today that departmentstore sales for the week ended Dec. 4 were an estimated $1,280,000,000, an increase of 10 per cent from the $1,160,000,000 sales for the corresponding week of last year. Total retail sales for the latest week were an estimated $8,982,000,000, an increase of 11 per cent from $8,082,000,000 in the 1970 period.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Wields Power Firmly
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 13That womanas the Pakistani President, Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, has several times described Prime Minister Indira Gandhiseems assured and comfortable in the role of national wartime leader.

title: Waza Roman Aqueduct Surprise
description: Waza Roman proved sturdy enough to defeat the oddson entry, representing Sigmund Sommer, in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Toy Cannon Kills Boy, 8
description: HAMILTON, Ohio, Dec. 13 (UPI)An 8yearold boy was killed last night when a toy cannon he and another youngster had loaded with gunpower exploded at his grandmother's home here. Roy Philpot was killed when bits of shrapnel pierced his chest and body. The blast also tore a hole in the floor, sending metal fragments into a downstairs room. The other boy was not hurt, but two other children and an adult were hospitalized for cuts.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Drop at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Bulgari Opens Jewelry Boutique With Lunch, Tea or Dinner
description: Mrs. Lillian Groueff stabbed her fork into her spinach at a luncheon at the Hotel Pierre yesterday and exclaimed: If I get an emerald in my spinach, I'm going to be very angry!

title: CROATIA PARTY SHIFT SAID TO CAUSE RIOT
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Tuesday, Dec. 14 (Reuters)  Seventy  six people were arrested when disturbances broke out in the main square of Zagreb, capital of Croatia, last night. Several policemen and rioters were slightly injured, Tanyug, the official press agency, said today.

title: Rights Body in Suttolk Charges Police Shun Brutality Complaint
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Dec. 13The Suffolk Human Rights Commission charged today that the county's Police Department had refused to investigate nearly 40 cases of alleged police brutality this year, including half a dozen cases in the last two weeks.

title: Cable TV OwnerProducer Curb Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 The Nixon Administration's Cabinet committee on cable television is expected to recommend regulations to the President next month that would prohibit cable system owners from producing their own programs.

title: FINE LIEDER SINGING BY SUSAN PAMPANINI
description: At her debut recital last March, Susan Pampanini revealed a voice and temperament ideally suited to German lieder. The soprano returned to Tully Hall Sunday night, with Thomas Booth at the piano, to reinforce the impression with a program of songs by Schumann, Brahms, Wolf and Joseph Marx.

title: RIGGING REACHING NEW JET PLATEAU
description: When John Rigging got his first look at New York last February he was impressed.

title: City Traffic Chief Terms Rickles's Plan Simplistic
description: Theodore Karagheuzoff, the city's Traffic Commissioner, charged yesterday that traffic proposals offered by Robert N. Rickles, the city's Air Resources Commissioner, were simplistic and would create more, not less, congestion and pollution.

title: Racial Tension Closes Berea A Week Before College Holiday
description: BEREA, Ky., Dec. 13Berea College, founded by abolitionists in 1855 and dedicated to the education of mountain youth, was closed down for the Christmas holiday a week early today because of racial tension.

title: DOWDY ON STAND; DENIES BRIBERY
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 13Representative John Dowdy, Democrat of Texas, took the witness stand in Federal District Court here today and denied taking a $25,000 bribe to divert a Justice Department investigation into a home improvement company.

title: Musicus Seeks $174Million
description: The Municipal Services Administration yesterday requested an increase of $19.4million in submitting a $174.3million expense budget for 197273. Administrator Milton Musicus told the city's budget bureau that the increase was needed to meet higher utility billings from his agency's opening more city buildings and keeping them open at night and on weekends. Parks Administrator August Hecksher requested $84.4million of $8million over his agency's present expense budget.

title: Advertising:
description: Considering the amount of talk and rumor about various radio stations being up for grabs, this headline running in a tradepress ad must be getting a lot of attention: For Sale WMCA.

title: Israel to Pay Reward In Capture of Eichmann
description: HAIFA, Israel, Dec. 13 (AP) The Israeli Government is going to pay a $10,000 reward to a blind Argentinian who said he had given the Israeli Secret Service the information that led them to the Nazi war criminal Adolf Eichmann.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 13 (UPI)The semiofficial newspaper Al Rai said today that Arab talk of war, intended primarily for domestic consumption, will be used by Israel as an excuse to start another war.

title: Nixon Made Appeal To China to Release American Captives
description: ANGRA DO HEROISMC, the Azores, Dec. 13The White House said today that President Nixon had sent a personal appeal to Peking on behalf of American prisoners, including the three granted clemency by the Chinese Government.

title: PRESIDENT SCORED BY CONSERVATIVES
