description: The New York County Conservative party yesterday attacked President Nixon's nomination of Arnold Bauman to the Federal bench here as extraordinarily bad judgment and an effort to the lower Federal courts with liberal judges.

title: Soviet Is Said to Intercept Satellite at a Low Altitude
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (Reuters).A Soviet satellite has for the first time destroyed a target below an altitude of 160 miles, indicating the Russians can now intercept reconnaissance satellites, the authoritative Aviation Week magazine said today.

title: LARUE WAGENSELLER
description: LaRue S. Wagenseller, a retired vice president for group insuranceclaims of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, L. I. He was 64 years old and lived at 1425 Plandome Road, Manhasset, L.I.

title: I.B.M. Assists 18 Black Colleges By Lending Employes to Teach
description: Eighteen scientists, engineers and business management specialists of the International Business Machines Corporation have been given fullyear salaried leaves to teach at 18 black Southern colleges.

title: Cougars Triumph, 124115, As Lehmann Gets 36 Points
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 13 (AP)George Lehmann scored 36 points for the Carolina Cougars tonight as they defeated the Utah Stars, 124115.

title: Rojas Suit Under Study
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 (UPI) A Federal judge today took under study a $12.4million damage suit filed against State Farm Mutual Insurance Company by the former California Angels pitcher, Minervino (Minnie) Rojas. United States District Court Judge Matt Byrne Jr. indicated he would rule within the week. The suit was filed as a result of an April, 1970, traffic accident in Florida in which Rojas was made a quadriplegic.

title: Bermuda Golfers in Lead
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 13MidOcean and Ocean View, both of Bermuda, shared the secondday lead today with a tworound total of 118 in the Bermuda Goodwill golf tournament.

title: Lindsay, in Ohio Speech, Urges Fairness Doctrine for Workers
description: CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 13Mayor Lindsay, who has frequently been embroiled in New York labor controversies, called for a new doctrine of fairness for American workers in his first major labor speech as a new Democrat tonight.

title: Strike by Globetrotters Settled Alter a Month
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (UPI)A monthlong strike of the Harlem Globetrotters basketball team was settled over the weekendand the team was scheduled to resume its regular schedule at Springfield, Mass., tonight, officials announced today.

title: Africa and Acts of Dissent
description: WASHINGTONWe were the only two ambassadors named by President Kennedy to represent him in the young Republic of Guinea in West Africa. We accepted these assignments in part because of his keen interest in Guinea and his personal relationship with the country's President, Stkou Tour.

title: Senate Unit Asked By knits to Study Forest Hills Site
description: Senator Jacob H. Javits asked the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee yesterday to hold hearings on important issues raised in the dispute over construction of an 840unit lowincome housing project in Forest Hilis, Queens.

title: Charles Kettering 2d
description: DENVER, Dec. 13 (AP) Charles F. Kettering 2d, a philanthropist who donated money to establish a legal defense project for Chicago's largest youth gang, was fatally injured last night when struck by a car. He was 40 years old.

title: Moscow Assails U.S. Step
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 13The Soviet press agency Tass accused the United States tonight of gunboat diplomacy and gross blackmail against India with its reported movement of an American naval squadron toward the Indian Ocean from the Gulf of Tonkin.

title: BURNET HERSHEY, WAR WRITER, DIES
description: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 13 Burnet Hershey, a foreign correspondent in both World Wars who also wrote books and plays based on his experiences, died todayhis 75th birthdayof a sudden illness while visiting his brother here. He lived at 91 Central Park West in New York.

title: 2 Die in Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENM, Cambodia, Dec. 13 (Reuters)  Two persons were killed and several others were injured tonight by grenade explosion in a crowded movie theater in the heart of Pnompenh. Bystanders said the grenade was thrown by some men dressed in military uniform during a quarrel. It was the first such incident in the capital in nearly a month.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: APPAREL PRODUCERS SPEED FLAME RULES
description: The American. Apparel Man ufacturers Association proposed yesterday to move forward full compliance of standards for flameresistant sleepwear for children from July 1, 1973, to April of that year.

title: GAF Wins Appeals Round;
description: The United States Court of Appeals issued a decision here yesterday, involving a Securities Exchange Act provision that, it said, could produce a marked impact on holders, sellers and purchasers of securities.

title: Supervisors in Nassau Vote $426Million Budget
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 13 A record budget for next year of $426million, which provides for a decrease In the property tax rate, was passed unanimously today by the Nassau County Board of Supervisors.

title: PERM EXWIFE HINTS HE WAS SPY
description: LYNN, Mass., Dec. 13 (A?)The divorced wife of Richard G. Fecteau, the man released from a Chinese prison after serving 19 years on a spying charge, said today: The Chinese haven't been lying.

title: GOVERNORS LAUD TOBIN'S SERVICES
description: The Governors of New York and New Jersey and the commissioners of the Port of New York Authority paid formal tribute yesterday to Austin J. Tobin, who announced Sunday ho would retire as the agency's executive director March 31.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: JOB SAFETY CHECKS UNCOVER VIOLATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI)  Labor Secretary James D. Hodgson said today that Federal inspectors found violations in four out of every five of the 9,300 work places inspected during the first six months of the new Occupational Safety and Health Act.

title: Famous Writers School Agrees To Substantial Revision of Ads
description: The Famous Writers School, Inc., a correspondence school based in Westport, Conn., has signed an agreement with the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs promising what the department calls substantial revisions in advertisements.

title: When Women Take Up Tools and Liberate Men
description: The hammer, plumber's wrench and screw driver may, turn out to be among the great equalizers of this century, for in the past few years increasing numbeta of women have been taking up tools to invade that stronghold of male dominionhome repair.

title: U.S. Lacks Details on China
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Informed sources said today that the United States could neither confirm nor deny the Indian report on Chinese movements.

title: 4 in City Loan Inquiry Refuse Waiver
description: Four large borrowers from the Municipal Loan Program for the rehabilitation of slum housing have refused to sign waivers of immunity requested in connection with an investigation by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

title: Neil Sheehan of Times Receives The First Drew Pearson Prize
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 Neil Sheehan of The New York Times was awarded the first annual Drew Pearson Prize for excellence In Investigative reporting today at the National Press. Club.

title: More Lead Producers Set A Uniform Pricing Policy
description: Metals changes dominated the pricing scene yesterday as several major companies followed the St. Joe Minerals Corporation in dropping dual pricing or discounting by area.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Chuck, Aim Joa, Tom, Bob. Molly and Rudlte look'g fwd. to sca'g their Smilling Physician's Mgmdt, friends at the Plaza tonight, ADVT.

title: Marijuana Is Linked to Brain Damage
description: Ten young men who smoked marijuana regularly and also sometimes used amphetamines (pep pills) and lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) have suffered permanent brain damage, a team of British doctors has reported in a medical journal.

title: Canadians Trade Roberto
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13 (UPI)The Montreal Canadiens today traded Phil Roberto, a 22yearold right wing, to the St. Louis Blues for 31yearold Jimmy Roberts, a former Canadien, who plays several positions.

title: Lindsay Urges a Transit Pay Accord
description: Mayor Lindsay urged negotiators for the transit workers and the Transit Authority yesterday to consider the public interest and to expedite their efforts to reach an agreement before the current contract expires on New Year's Eve.

title: ROBERT L. WALTER JR.
description: PIPERSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 13 Robert L. Walter Jr., an advertising salesman for The Ladies Home Journal, died yesterday of an accidental selfinflicted gunshot wound while preparing to go hunting. He was 58 years old and lived here.

title: 2 SUITS CONTEST BANS ON ABORTION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 The Supreme Court was asked today virtually to sweep away the states' antiabortion laws by ruling that it is unconstitutional for the government to interfere with women's control over their own bodies.

title: Italian Vote Still Undecided
description: ROME, Dec. 13The fifthday of Italy's protracted Presidential election ended inconclusively today. Tonight, no agreement between the political parties seemed in sight. In a change of strategy, all Christian Democrats in the electoral college, which selects the President, abstained from voting, pending the outcome of new negotiations with other groups. Voting resumes tomorrow.

title: British Trade Surplus Declined in November
description: LONDON, Dec. 13 (Reuters)After six months of monthly surpluses varying from $65million to $180million, Britain's overseas trade in November ended with a surplus of only $12million.

title: REDISTRICTING JOB PRESSED UPSTATE
description: SYRACUSE, Dec. 13With a special legislative session called by Governor Rockefeller for tomorrow night in Albany on remapping Assembly and Senate district lines, a harried staff of a dozen legislative committee aides were still working on detailed maps tonight.

title: Mail Box for Reporting Corruption Set Up Here
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 13Whitney North Seymour Jr., United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, has set up a special post office box in New York City where citizens can write and give confidential information about corruption among public officials.

title: Pioneer of the Airwaves
description: It is rare that the story of an industry can be personified in one man. But the development of broadcasting and the life of David Sarnoff were intertwined. The young telegrapher with little formal education turned science into a faith and an art, a harddriving gamble into a successful business and then an empire. The radio music box became a household utility everywhere; the addition of sight to sound became television and, in one of Sarnoff's major struggles, color television.

title: Exiled Bishop Gets New Post
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 (AP)Exiled from South Africa because he objected to apartheid, the Right Rev. C. Edward Crowther has been installed as an assistant bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of California. The Right Rev. C. CaliMyers, Bishop of California, presided over the Installation yesterday in Grace Cathedral. Bishop Crowther said that he regarded his new title as an honorary post because the church doesn't seem to know what to do with deported bishops.

title: Chase, Morgan Cut Prime
description: The banking system's prime lending rate appeared headed for another general reduction yesterday as two major New York City banks announced point cuts, to 5 per cent, in this key business lending charge.

title: Westchester Budget of $220Million Argued at Public Meeting
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 13Dozens of Westchester residents, anguished by a choice between a 25per cent increase in county property taxes or the first sales tax in the county's history to finance a record $220million budget, dissected, condemned and occasionally praised that budget at a lengthy public hearing tonight.

title: INSURANCE LAWSUIT IS SHIFTED TO TEXAS
description: A stockholder's lawsuit seeking to block the proposed reorganization of the American National Insurance Company of Galveston, Tex., was ordered transferred Yesterday from New York to Texas Federal Court.

title: Leary Agrees to Be Knapp Witness
description: Former Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary has agreed to testify at the public hearings of the Knapp Commission, which is investigating whether high officials in the Lindsay administration failed to act on allegations of police corruption.

title: 5th Mutiny at French Jail
description: PARIS, Dec. 13 (Reuters)The Justice Ministry announced that the police broke up a new mutiny today of convicts at the prison in Toul, northeast France. Early reports said that a warder and several prisoners were injured before the mutiny, the fifth at Toul since last week, was put down.

title: Nixon and Pompidou Meet in Azores, but Hope for Early Accord Fades
description: ANGRA DO HEROISMO, the Azores, Dec. 13Hopes for early agreement between Washington and Western Europe on currency realignments and trade receded here today after President Nixon held the first of two days of talks with President Pompidou of France. While the two Presidents met for five hours on this sunny island in the middle of the Atlantic, the American and French finance and foreign ministers held parallel sessions. They looked toward a scheduled meeting of ministers of the 10 leading industrial nations in Washington Friday. After the afternoon meetings, Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally spoke to newsmen and stressed the apparent stalemate in discussions of currency realignment and trade. The crux of the argument, discussed in broad outline to day by the two Presidents, while the ministers dealt with the specifics, is whether new parities, or fixed values, could be assigned to the principal currencies after the United States undertook in August to reduce the dollar's worth in order to correct the American imbalance in trade.

title: THIRD SOVIET VETO BARS TRUCE PLAN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13The Soviet Union tonight vetoed in the Security Council a United States resolution calling for an immediate ceasefire and withdrawal of Indian and Pakistani forces to their own sides of the border. It was the third Soviet veto of such a resolution in nine days.

title: Thrust in Cambodia Is Deepest in Year
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 13  South Vietnamese paratroops and armored units reached the southern edge of the Chup rubber plantation today in their deepest penetration of eastern Cambodia in nearly a year.

title: Steamfitters Continue to Strike In Defiance of U.S. Court Order
description: Union steamfitters defied a Federal court restraining order yesterday and continued their fourday walkout at the World Trade Center in a dispute in volving how many white and nonwhite workers should be laid off.

title: TV: Tales of Hoffmann
description: Last night, at 8 o'clock, the N.E.T. Opera Theater presented a twohour British Broadcasting Corporation production of Offenbach's Tales of Hoffmann. Last month N.E.T. Opera presented its own production of Stravinsky Remembered, with documentary reminiscences of the composer and a highly imaginative performance of his Le Rossignol.

title: NEW SERVICE UNIT ABANDONED BY RCA
description: The RCA Corporation gave up yesterday on an attempt to establish a nationwide operation servicing all makes of television and other home entertainment products. The new group, known as ServiceAmerica, was originally announced last May and had centers in Philadelphia, San Francisco and Miami. Their operations had a total annual volume of about $1.5million, RCA said yesterday.

title: ASSEMBLY BACKS DEMAND OF EGYPT FOR FULL PULLOUT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13The General Assembly tonight overwhelmingly adopted an Egyptiansupported resolution calling on Israel to withdraw from the Egyptian territory she has occupied since the June, 1967, war.

title: NOTRE DAME BIDS FOR HOCKEY APEX
description: Notre Dame is sending a hockey team to New York but its arrival will cause hardly a ripple compared with the splashy greeting traditionally given Irish football teams by the socalled subway alumni.

title: EDWARD J. KEMPF, PSYCHIATRIST, 86
description: WADING RIVER, L.I., Dec. 13Dr. Edward J. Kempf, a psychiatrist, psychobiologist and author, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here. He was 86 years old.

title: POTATO FUTURES CLIMB IN PRICE
description: Potato futures closed 1 to 14 cents higher a hundredweight on the sale of 1,231 lots on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, in moderately active trading.

title: A HANUKKAH RITE ATTRACTS 20,000
description: A cantor intoned the traditional blessings. A huge candle was used to light two others on the eightbranched candelabra.

title: W. J. Barney Corp. Elects
description: Robert F. Lathlaen has been elected president of the W. J. Barney Corporation, a New York building concern. Mr. Lathlaen succeeds Alfred T. Glassett, who has resigned the presidency after serving since 1950.

title: City Block: Love Is Only a Sometime Thing on West 85th Street
description: Sometimes love flourishes on 85th Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue, but more often it does not, and then, particularly among the young, who expect so much more of it, love leaves behind it a sour disenchantment.

title: Advertising:
description: A group of employes of Lennen & Newell of Puerto Rico headed by Jaime J. Cordova, general manager, are buying the agency from the parent company. The papers were signed yesterday.

title: Americans Are Sped to U.S.
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 13  The two Americans released by China passed through here today and departed by plane for the United States. The British authorities kept them from contact with the press.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: BLUEGRASS SERIES GETS LIVELY START
description: A new series of bluegrass concerts was begun Sunday by the Bluegrass Club of New York, which presented afternoon and evening performances by Don Reno, Red Smiley, Bill Harrell and the Tennessee CutUps at St. Catherine of. Sienna Auditorium, 420 East 69th Street.

title: CORNELL SETS UP PANEL OF INQUIRY
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 12 A fiveman committee composed of three whites, one black and one Puerto Rican has been set up to investigate and make recommendations on grievances of the six black players who have refused to play in Cornell's last two basketball games.

title: Vatican Cautions Rome's Priests on Discipline
description: ROME, Dec. 13Pope Paul's vicar for Rome announced a disciplinary crackdown today on the many thousands of priests, friars and nuns in the city.

title: MORRIS GRAYSON, PSYCHIATRIST, 62
description: Dr. Morris Grayson, preceptor of clinical psychiatrists at Mount Sinai Hospital, died yesterday at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park. He was 62 years old and lived in Great Neck, L. I. His office was at 420 East 55th Street.

title: Realism on the Subcontinent
description: Washington's renewed efforts to obtain effective intervention by the United Nations Security Council to stop the IndianPakistani conflict are once again too little and too late.

title: RAP BROWN MAKES COURT APPEARANCE
description: H. Rap Brown, the black militant who has been confined to the Bellevue Hospital Prison. Ward for two months, limped into Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday and pleaded not guilty to a 24count indictment charging him with attempted murder and robbery In a shootout at a West 85th Street bar in October.

title: Court Widens Ruling on Trial Appeals of the Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that states must furnish free trial records for poor persons who wish to appeal misdemeanor convictions, even in cases involving only fines.

title: Maurice J. McDonald Dies at 69; Hamburger Chain's Co Founder
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 13Maurice James McDonald, cofounder of McDonald's Hamburgers, the chain of roadside eateries and other restaurants that today emblazon across their golden arches the story of their product's successOver Eight Billion Solddied Saturday at his home here. His age was 69.

title: $180,000 for Exchange Seat
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it sold a seat for $180,000, down $20,000 from the previous, which was made last Friday. The current market is $145,000 bid, $205,000 asked.

title: Witter's ExPresident Is Joining Wertheim
description: Lawrence B. Morris Jr., who resigned Oct. 1 as president of Dean Witter & Co., has agreed to join Wertheim & Co., another investment house, as a general partner. It was understood that Mr. Morris already was working at Wertheim, but would not assume formal partnership status until Jan. 1.

title: RUSSIANS EXPAND SPACE TRACKING
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 13The Soviet Union unveiled this weekend its latest and largest space tracking ship, the 45,000ton Cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin, which represents a significant addition to the Russians' deep space communications network.

title: What Is a oman?: II
description: LONDONThe women's liberation movement is frequently seen as one of a series of radical uprisings: black power, students, women, gay liberation. Such an assimilation obscures one of its crucial defining features. Blacks are in ghettos, students in colleges, homosexuals discriminated against together. Women inhabit neither geographical nor social space as a group. They are isolated. This factor is repeatedly stressed in the movement, but often it is treated only descriptivelyas an expression of woman's psychic and social loneliness. But, in fact, it is crucial to the definition of women's oppression in capitalist societies.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: If certified by the International Game Fish Associaation (I.G.F.A.), a giant bluefish caught this November in the surf of Nags Head on North Carolina's Outer Banks by Mrs. Rita Mizello of Southern Shores, N.C., will tie the present alltackle record for the species.

title: North Korean Scoffs Seoul's Charges
description: TOKYO, Dec. 13A member of the North Korean Parliament scoffed today at South Korean charges that his Government was preparing for war against the South.

title: A 3PRONGED DRIVE
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 13Indian forces today continued their threepronged advance on Dacca, the capital of East Pakistan, and an Indian spokesman declared that within 24 to 48 hours we will be in a very strong position around Dacca.

title: 4DAY WEEK TALKS ENDED AT CHRYSLER
description: DETROIT, Dec. 13 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation and the United Auto Workers broke off discussions today on the feasibility of a short work week after the company refused to test a work week of four 10hour shifts in one of its plants.

title: Rocket for Apollo 16 Moon Mission Is Moved to Pad
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 13 (UPI)Thomas K. Mattingly 2d watched the next to last moon rocket move to its oceanside launching pad today and said the space program was just beginning.

title: SURVEY FINDS 44% WON'T LIFT PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The Price Commission said today that in a survey of the nation's biggest businesses, 44 per cent of dose answering gave assurances they would try to hold the line on price increases.

title: ' Nicholas and Alexandra' Depicts Fall of Romanovs
description: It opens with a close-up so tight that the object seen is almost an abstract shape. It's a lamp in a bedchamber where a woman is giving birth to a son. The woman is the Empress Alexandra, the gently neurotic, German-born consort to Nicholas II, and her son is the hemophile czarevich, Alexis.Thereafter, for a little more than three hours, "Nicholas and Alexandra" keeps pulling back and back until its vision encompasses not only the last Romanov czar and his immediate family, but also cousins and uncles, family retainers, Rasputin, moderate politicians like Stolypin and Kerensky, revolutionaries like Lenin and Trotsky and Stalin, assorted proles and priests, the beginnings of World War I and, finally, the epic Bolshevik Revolution, which is still changing the look of this planet, and even Mars, where it recently made a soft landing.Sam Spiegel, the producer of the film; Franklin J. Schaffner, its director, and James Goldman, who adapted Robert K. Massie's huge, bestselling, carefully researched book, have made something much less than a great movie. However, "Nicholas and Alexandra" covers such an extraordinary period, events so bizarre, and a course of history so implacable, that I was fascinated even through its dopey failures.I have no way of knowing exactly, but most of these I would attribute to Mr. Goldman ("A Lion in Winter," "They Might Be Giants"), whose job it was to dramatize a slice of history more complex than can be contained in any one film. Indeed, he hasn't really dramatized it. He has synopsized it, and popularized the rather sober documentations of Mr. Massie's book with fictional inventions of a sometimes ludicrous order.This is especially true of sequences dealing with the revolution, a subject dramatized with somewhat more passion and style by the Russians themselves in films I hope I need not mention. Thus we are introduced to cartoon characters  to an argumentative Trotsky, a ruthless Lenin and a ferret-eyed young man who says something on the order of: "Hello. My name is Josef Stalin. . . ." Mr. Goldman's dialogue does not exactly enhance these great moments of history.There is another problem with the film in that Nicholas and Alexandra are not really tragic characters, though the movie seems to pretend that they are. They are a nice, loving, fatally uninformed couple who, between them, were ultimately responsible for the death of something like 7 million subjects. One can be more or less hypnotized by the spectacle of their downfall, but it's difficult to be really moved by it.Curiously enough, there was some of this same confusion in attitude toward its subject in Mr. Schaffner's "Pattorn," a much better and, ironically, a much more imperial film than "Nicholas and Alexandra." I, for one, miss here the marvelous, deep-focus photography that gave a panoramic sweep to Mr. Schaffner's film about the American general who was described as a 16th-century man in a 20th-century world. (Someone in "Nicholas and Alexandra" describes Russia as an 18th-century country in a 20th-century world  which may well prompt a few theses about the director's hang-up with people and things outside of their own times.)"Nicholas and Alexandra" doesn't sweep. It jerksfrom vignette to great moment to vignette, some more effective than others. In the title roles, Michael Jayston and Janet Suzman, two young British performers, are, I think, immensely effective whenever the screenplay allows them to be. Mr. Goldman doesn't interfere with them to quite the same degree that he does the revolutionaries, although I was a bit taken aback when he has the czarevich turn on his father, after the abdication and while the family is awaiting execution, and berate him for having given away his family heritage.In addition to the two stars, I also liked Tom Baker's Rasputin, which is played as an outright rogue, and almost everyone in the supporting cast on the royalist sideHarry Andrews, Irene Worth, Laurence Olivier, Jack Hawkins and John McEnery who, as Kerensky, isn't exactly on the royalist side, but at least he is recognizable as a real character.The physical production is lovely  all that money can buyand since movie money is in such short supply these days, it may be as much the end of its line as Nicholas was of his. The film opened yesterday at the Criterion Theater, where, at the intermission of a preview performance, I heard someone remark: "They've certainly inflated this story." That's both unfair and incorrect. The problem with "Nicholas and Alexandra" is not inflation, but deflation, the attempt to cram too big a picture into too small a frame.

title: Red Youths in Calcutta Attack a Pan Ant Office
description: CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 13 (UPI)A group of about 30 Indian Communist youths, screaming antiAmerican slogans, attacked the downtown ticket office of Pan American World Airways today with gasoline bombs and stones.

title: Man in the News
description: Richard S. Scolaro, the man in charge of drawing up the state's latest reapportionment plana complex procedure something like solving a multidimensional jigsaw puzzle in the darkfirst became involved with the field because, he says, he had nothing else to do. It goes back to one crazy day in Senator Hughes's office, Mr. Scolaro recalled. That was in 1963, when Mr. Scolaro, now the executive director of the Joint Legislative Committee on Reapportionment, was fresh from New York University Law School and had been working on tax accounts for the Syracuse law firm of State Senator John H. Hughes.

title: FREED BY BENGALIS, WOMAN IS BACK HERE
description: A 28yearold American woman held in a Pakistani prison for two months until she was freed last week by Bengali rebels returned to the United States last night for a reunion with her husband and parents.

title: Books of The Times
description: After reading through several hundrod children's books published this year, I found myself bewildered. First of all, by the lack of outstanding quality. How can it be, one wonders, that such an abundant industry produces so little of real excellence? (Is it because children, like Army draftees, have so little say about what they must consume, which places the industry beyond any true law of supply and demand?) Second of all, by this business of age classifications. What purpose can It possibly serve to distinguish between 12  year  olds and teenagers, when even picture books are so often more sophisticated than socalled teenage novels? And third of all, by the continuing upsurge of socially significant books. Does a primer on ecology tell children more about marauding man than The Walrus and the Carpenter? Do black children get any benefit from poorly written poetry that happens to be about black subjects? In short, are children's books written for children?

title: Retail Sales Make A Strong Rebound
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Retail sales rebounded strongly in November after a dip in October, preliminary figures of the Commerce Department indicated today.

title: City Adds 66 Employes in Year Despite Job Attrition Program
description: Despite job freezes and budget crises, the city has more lemployes on the payroll today than it had one year ago, the Budget Bureau acknowledged yesterday.

title: PREMIERE AT TULLY OP MARTIN POEMES
description: While there was scarcely dull moment in the Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society's farranging and instrumentally varied concert Sunday afternoon in Tully Hall, primary interest centered on the world premiere of Frank Martin's Poemes de la mort.

title: Hockey Coach Selected
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 13 (AP) Paul Giel appointed Ken Yackel today as interim hockey coach of the University of Minnesota team, and said it would probably take about two weeks before he could find a new football coach. Giel resumed duties as athletic director, after a misunderstanding was resolved on the hiring of coaches.

title: MRS. MEIR IS HOME, SEES DANGER OF WAR
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 13Premier Golda Meir returned from the United States today and again warned Israelis to be ready for war. She refused to disclose whether she had been given any promise that the United States would resume the supplying of Phantom jet fighterbombers.

title: Praised Soprano Keeps Maori Cool
description: LONDON, Dec. 13The Countess in Mozart's Marriage of Figaro has experienced the sadness, the humiliation of strayed love. There is nobility in her, a passion restrained by dignity. Musically and intellectually it is a most sophisticated part, expressing Mozart's realistic understanding of human imperfection.

title: GIANTS DWINDLE FOR FINAL GAME
description: What began as straight situation comedy for the New York Giants is ending as pure daytime hospital drama. A training camp marked by daily disappearances and a daring leap by Charlie Harper out of a firstfloor window has led to a final game in which only 35 players will be available to face the Philadelphia Eagles Sunday.

title: Campaign Notes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Mayor Sam Yorty of Los Angeles needs a strong run in Manchester if he is to do at all well in New Hampshire's March 7 Presidential primary. But a large percentage of the city's Democratic voters are workingclass Roman Catholics of French and Irish ancestry and Mr. Yorty's opponents think they have found something that could damage the Mayor's chances among those voters. AntiYorty politicians have begun dropping hints about a pamphlet written by Mr. Yorty in 1960, during the Presidential campaign of John F. Kennedy. It is called I Cannot Take Kennedy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes
description: The East New York Savings Bank announced yesterday that John P. McGrath has been elected to the newly created position of chairman of the board, Mr, McGrath, who will be succeeded as president by Robert G. Brandely, will retain the title of chief executive officer. Mr. Brandely, who has been the bank's executive vice president since 1968, will serve as the chief administrative officer. The changes are effective Jan. 1, 1972, Mr. McGrath was made a trustee of East New York in 1942 and became president in 1966. Mr. Brandely Joined the bank, which has assets of over $850million, in 1939.

title: Hanratty Suffers Fracture
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 13 (UPI) Terry Hanratty, Pittsburgh Steeler quarterback, suffered a fractured left collarbone when tackled in the second quarter of the Steelers' game with Cincinnati yesterday, a club spokesman said today.

title: SCHOOL TAX CRISIS FORCING CUTBACKS
description: The money crisis in the nation's public schools, compounded of sharply rising costs and shrinking local revenues, has entered a new, more acute and more threatening phase. At the same time, the perennial talk about reforming the school tax system is beginning to turn into action.

title: Suns Set Back Knicks, 110100
description: Two ancient sayings, the one about lightning not striking twice in the same place and the one about nothing lasting forever, formed the theme of the 110100 victory the Phoenix Suns scored over the New York Knicks at Madison Square Garden last night before a crowd of 19,256.

title: FORAM BEATS COLUMBIA, 8870
description: Fordham University gained an 8870 triumph over Columbia last night at the Rose Hill gymnasium before a crowd of 3,107.

title: Canada Would Keep Parity
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 14The Canadian Government will seek to maintain the present parity between the Canadian and United States dollars, Edgar J. Benson, the Finance Minister, said today.

title: Natural Gas Discovery
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Dec. 14 (Canadian Press)  Panarctic Oils, Ltd., announced today that natural gas had been discovered at Kristoffer Bay on, Ellef Ringnes Island in the Arctic Ocean.

title: Confusion Keeping Congress in Session
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The House, attempting to clear the way for Congressional adjournment, approved tonight a $70.5billion defense appropriations bill providing about $3billion less than requested by the Administration.

title: Terrorists Attack Homes of Five Belfast Leaders
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 14 (Reuters)  Guerrillas attacked the homes of five prominent Belfast citizens today, leaving the husband of a woman Senator badly injured and causing widespread damage to property.

title: Advertising:
description: At the Association of National Advertisers workshop on copy research yesterday threesome from DancerFitzgeraldSample talked about the agency's Adlab and showed some commercials that had grown out of it.

title: Second Sperm Bank in City, Called First of Chain, Opens
description: The second commercial sperm bank in the city opened yesterday and its operators said it was the first of an international chain of 20 such banks to be opened in the next few years.

title: A 5% Income Surtax Sought by Governor
description: Governor Rockefeller yesterday asked for $427million in new taxes that include a 5 per cent surcharge on the state tax on income earned next year and increases in the taxes on beer, wine, liquor, cigarettes and gasoline.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In a simpler time not too long ago, an unfailing Thanksgiving Day tradition was the newspaper editorial or letter to the editor asserting that the Pilgrim Fathers were the first American champions of free competitive enterprise. They tried Communism at first, the story went, but found that it did not work, abandoned it, and turned to the American Way of Life instead.

title: Battle for City Starts
description: The following pool dispatch was transmitted to Washington yesterday from 13 correspondents in East Pakistan, representing The Associated Press, United Press International, Time, Newsweek, The New York Times, The Christian Science Monitor, The Wall Street Journal, the American Broadcasting Company, the Columbia Broadcasting System, the National Broadcasting Company and The Washington Post:

title: Negro Policemen Sue Miami
description: MIAMI, Dec. 14 (UPI)Fifteen Negro policemen filed suit in Federal District Court today charging the city of Miami with practicing racial discrimination ht the hiring and promotion of Negro policemen. The suit, which asks more than $1million in damages, was brought against the city, Mayor David Kennedy, Police Chief Bernard Garmire and Dr. C. A. Scarborough, city medical director.

title: WALTER M. PEARSALL
description: Walter Montague Pearsall, who headed his own advertisling agency in Manhattan from the turn of the century until this year, died Monday night in Englewood (N. J.) Hospital. He was 94 years old and lived at 115 Columbus Drive, Tena fly, N. J.

title: Good jobs Are Rare in the Villages
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 14 Cpl. Sidh Ram, a short, lean, darkskinned man with a thick mustache, volunteered for the Indian Army 11 years ago to escape the poverty of his native village.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
CONGRESS VOTES TO REQUIRE WORK FOR WELFARE AID
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14In a surprise move, Congress passed and sent to the President today a bill requiring most ablebodied welfare recipients to sign up for work or training so as to continue receiving benefits.

title: Allen and Aging Redskins Deliver Lesson to Rams
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 George Allen's antiquarians have more than vindicated the Washington Redskin coach's tohellwithrookies policy.

title: Teachers' Strikee Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) The number of teacher strikes dropped from 181 in the 196970 school year to ISO in 197071, a reduction of 28.2 per cent, the National Education Association reported today.

title: 10th Ballot Fails to Name A New President of Italy
description: ROME, Dec. 14The 1,008member electoral college remained deadlocked today, on the sixth day of voting for a new president of Italy.

title: 7 Banks Admit TransitBond Drive Gifts
description: Seven of the largest commercial banks in the city have admitted contributing $5,000 to $10,000 each to the campaign for the $2.5billion state transportationbond issue, a banking newspaper disclosed yesterday.

title: RUNNERSUP LEFT BEHIND IN LOTTERY
description: The states yearold $1million lottery, whichadvertises that tor a $3 chance a man could become an instant millionaire, will not be paying off any $500 runnersup today because for the first time it has not collected enough to do so.

title: MUSKIE CRITICIZES MEDICAL SERVICES
description: Senator Edmund S. Muskie described the nation's health services yesterday as a system of medical neglect and proposed a threepoint program to bring our health care system back to the people.

title: SILVER PRICES UP ON DOLLAR NEWS
description: The announcement that President Nixon had indicated that the United States was prepared to devalue the dollar as part of an international currency realignment had a generally bullish effect on the commodity markets yesterday.

title: Youth Killed Fighting Troops
description: BELFAST, Wednesday, Dec. 15 (AP)British soldiers early today shot dead a 16yearold boy said to be a member of gang of gunmen. He was the 197th person to die in Northern Ireland's 28 months of violence.

title: ELOISE WALTON DIES; FORMER PRESS AGENT
description: Mrs. Eloise Kimball Walton Petersen, a retired public relations consultant known as Eloise Walton, wife of Harold G. Petersen, public relations director for the Seamen's Church Institute, died Monday night in Roosevelt Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived at 300 East 21st Street.

title: The Music season: Imprint of Boulez
description: Established musical organizations are large, and they are immutable. Year in and year out they work much the some way, with much the same personnel, philosophy and (if a performing group) repertory. Thus it has been up to the halfway point of the music, seasonwith one exception. The New York Philharmonic has broken the mold.

title: Flu Epidemic in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 14 (UPI) About 100,000 Swedes are ill with Hong Kong flu and the epidemic is spreading, health officials said today.

title: U.S. OIL COMPANY IN ALGERIAN DEAL
description: An $8billion agreement calling for the delivery of 340 million tons of crude oil and petroleum products by Algeria to the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, Inc., was announced yesterday by the two participants.

title: U.N. SHIFTS FOCUS TO POLITICAL ISSUE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14The Security Council, brustrated in its attempts to ring about a ceasefire on the Indian subcontinent, shifted its attention tonight to an effort to promote a political settlement in East Pakistan.

title: EARL BLOUGH, 95, ALUMINUM FIGURE
description: Earl Blough, a leader in the development of manufacturing processes of aluminum in the early years of the industry, died Monday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived at 520 East 86th Street and in Tiverton, R. I.

title: WIRETAPS CALLED INEFFECTIVE TOOL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14A law professor has written a report for the American Civil Liberties Union contending that Governmental eavesdropping, though bringing hundreds of thousands of conversations within its net, is Ineffective and expensive.

title: Repertory Movie Theaters Multiply in Manhattan
description: The repertory cinema, once a tiny fraction of the motion picture scene here, is on the rise. Five years ago there were three Manhattan theaters devoted to it. Now there are at least 11.

title: Saudi Aide Says New Oilfield May Rival World's Largest
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 14 (Reuters)  Saudi Arabia's newest oil strike could rival the biggest field in the world, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Minister of Petroleum and Mineral Resources, said here today.

title: Market Place: Market Drops: Another View
description: Those spinetingling and pocketbookrattling drops in the market price of Big Board stocks have alarmed many observers.

title: Gotbaum Files Suit to Get Names of Price Violators
description: Victor Gotbaum, executive director of the city's largest public employe union, filed suit yesterday againt the Internal Revenue Service over its refusal to make public the name of merchants or companies who have violated the Federal pricecontrol program.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Imagine two of the best drivers and cars in the country, sponsored by Viceroy cigarettes, racing on a circuit on which Marlboro cigarettes spends $500,000 a year to sponsor. Imagine either driverMario Andretti or Al Unser  winning a series copyrighted as the Marlboro Championship Trial, winning the Marlboro Cup and winning about $35,000 of Mariboro's $150,000 point fund. Imagine the track announcer, hired by Marlboro for the 11 or 12 races on the schedule, identifying the Viceroy team. Imagine a Viceroy driver who wins a race refusing to pose wearing the victory hat with the Marlboro logo. Imagine Andretti and Unser refusing to wear the Marlboro patch on their coveralls, as other drivers are required to do if they are to qualify for the Marlboro share of race purses. Finally, imagine Viceroy compensating its drivers for whatever money Marlboro withholds.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Even Experts Find It Difficult To Resist Playing to Gallery
description: Many experts have a touch of the actor in their makeup. When playing before an audience they find it difficult to resist an urge to play to the gallery so they indulge in flashly bids and dramatic plays that they would reject in a cooler moment. In international competition some captains find it necessary to hide a certain player in the closed room, away from spectators, so that he will not succumb to his theatrical leanings.

title: Roy Eldridge Adds A Variety to Jazz At Jimmy Ryan's
description: One of the few certainties of life in New York is the music at Jimmy Ryan's, 154 West 54th Street. It is primarily Dixieland, focusing on such staples of the repertory as Muskrat Ramble, Jazz Me Blues, Bill Bailey and When the Saints Go Marching In. Even the musicians are apt to be the same from one year to the next.

title: Group of Ten Will Confer in Castle on Mall
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The finance ministers of the world's 10 richest nonCommunist countries will meet this week in a setting more conducive to prayer and meditation than hard bargaining about money.

title: Car Sales Weaken
description: DETROIT, Dec. 14Newcar sales began to show some weakness during the Dec. 110 sales period, according to reports of three of the four United States auto concerns.

title: Amnesty Bill for Foes of Draft Is Introduced in Senate by Taft
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 Senator Robert Taft Jr., Republican of Ohio, introduced legislation today offering amnesty to draft resisters who are in Federal prisons or who fled the country to avoid service in the Vietnam war.

title: REMESTATE UNIT FORMED BY G. N.
description: DETROIT, Dec. 14Gulf & Western, Industries, Inc., today disclosed plans to enter the real estate development business at its annual stockholders' meeting here.

title: CITY'S AIDES UNITE ON PLAN FOR MALL
description: Top city officials, some of whom in the last week have presented different plans to solve the growing midtown traffic congestion problem, united strongly yesterday behind the proposed Madison Mall.

title: Original Tenants of 40YearOld Phipps Apartments Are Honored
description: It turned out to be a kind of love your landlord day yesterday at Phipps Garden. Apartments in Sunnyside, Queens.

title: Master Builder
description: The decision of Austin J. Tobin to retire as executive director of the Port of New York Authority represents an act of public responsibility in line with the high accomplishment of his three decades as master builder of bridges, tunnels, airports and terminals.

title: Zambia Said to Deport 129 As Rhodesian Security Men
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 14The Zambian Daily Mail, a Government newspaper, reported today that 129 members of a Rhodesian African liberation movement had been deported to Rhodesia because they had allegedly worked for Rhodesian security services.

title: U.S. Project Finds Work for Jobless
description: DETROIT, Dec. 14In Detroit all the galleries of the city's art museum will be open each day for the first time in years.

title: Planning Commission in Nassau Adopts Comprehensive Program
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 14The Nassau County Planning Commission, in an unexpected move, adopted today its comprehensive plan for the development of the county.

title: Economic Analysis
description: President Niicon's announcement in the Azores that the United States has agreed to devalue the dollar will strengthen hopes that the international monetary and trade confrontation will soon be over. And Wall Street should be pleased even if it had already anticipated the newsbecause, if investors and speculators around the world believe that a currency realignment has taken place and ono that will hold firm, money now held in foreign currencies is likely to come pouring back into dollars and into American investments. But a word of caution is in order.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: CAIRO  The IndiaPakistan war came as a political blow to Egypt. It is not simply distressing that fighting should erupt between Cairo's special nonaligned friend and another Moslem land. But the conflict also seemed to damage Egypt's tactic to regain control of the Sinai Peninsula from Israeli occupation.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When President Nixon told American business about the wageprice freeze on Aug. 15, one of the last to hear was his No. 1 boy on American business, Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans. Gone fishing, read the sign on the secretary's office door. He and his son were battling the truculent lake trout that troop through the waters of Great Bear Lake, which straddles the Arctic Circle in Canada's Northwest Territories. I got back to Edmonton on Atm. 16, Stens said the other day, and there was a message, to call Washington. I'd been out of touch for a week. One day my son and I caught and released 50 fish and never heard a telephone. That's one reason I go on safaris. In New York for a series of meetings, the secretary took an hour off to swap fish stories. To conservationists and animal lovers he is known, with no especial warmth, as an avid biggame hunter who has made 11 safaris to Africa, but it turns out that he is handy with a flyrod as well as a rifle. In the beginning he looked on his shooting as sport, but he has grown defensive about the trophies on display in Stans African Hall, the Children's Nature Museum in Rock Hill, S. C.

title: Attica Told to Start Hearings On Segregation by Tomorrow
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 14  Judge John T. Curtin of United States District Court here Is ordered the superintendent of the Attica State Correctional Facility to begin administrative hearings by Thursday afternoon for 38 prisoners who have been segregated from the rest of the prison population since the Sept. 9to13 riot there.

title: Ancient Bones Sought in Florida Spring
description: NORTH PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla., Dec. 14 (UPI)  Underwater explorers pitched camp today at the lip of a junglehidden sinkhole that has been swallowing man and beast more than 5,000 years.

title: Mayor's Holiday Party Mix: Politics, Conviviality
description: Mayor Lindsay swept through three dinners, two Christmas parties and a Hanukkah candlelighting ceremony last night, a hectic schedule that mixed a little pleasure with a lot of obligatiofi for the Mayor, put him in touch with a number of his important constituencies.

title: Arms Negotiators in Vienna Hold Their Longest Session
description: VIENNA, Dec. 14 (AP) United States and Soviet negotiators at the talks on limitation of strategic arms today held their longest session since the conferences started more than two years ago in Helsinki, Finland.

title: ELKS LODGE DROPS CASE AGAINST CRITIC
description: MIDDLEBORO, Mass., Dec. 14 (AP)The Middleboro Lodge of Elks has dropped charges against a priest who opposed its whiteonly rule and dismissed the black Scoutmaster of a Boy Scout troop that it sponsors.

title: Campus Homosexuals Organize To Win Community Acceptance
description: In defiance of taboos that have prevailed for generations, thouhands of college students are proclaiming their homosexuality and openly organizing gay groups on large and small campuses across the country.

title: CITY UNDERTAKES ITS BIGGEST LOAN
description: New York City sold $376.8million of bonds yesterday in the largest longterm borrowing it has ever undertaken.

title: Screen: 'The Hospital'
description: "My God!" shouts Dr. Herbert Bock (George C. Scott), the chief of medicine at a huge, modern New York City hospital that appears to be collapsing into premature ruins, "the incompetence here is absolutely radiant!" But, as his head nurse says, in the manner of someone who has seen Rome fall more than once: "These things happen."Among the things that happen in "The Hospital," a very serious (in fact, perhaps, a little too serious), very funny melodramatic farce, are pilferage of equipment that amounts to piracy, a confrontation with a local action group that objects to the hospital's participation in slum clearance, a patient who dies after having been wrongly diagnosed, and a series of mysterious coincidences that threaten to push the mortality rate of the doctors and nurses higher than that of the ordinary Blue Cross subscribers."The Hospital," is not, as you might be led to believe, the sort of pious, inside-institution literature that Arthur Hailey grinds out to satisfy the book clubs, if not the muses, nor is it really one of those malpractice horror stories that are so helpful in obtaining lecture tours for medical men.It deals in such horror stories, in grotesquely comic, inventive detail, but the ultimate concern of Arthur Hiller, who directed the film, and Paddy Chayefsky, who wrote the exuberant screenplay, is not the hospital but a social order that has grown so complex that it allows people to be forgotten to death, and is so full of awful contradictions that only escape, by one means or another, seems rational.Anyone who has seen or read Mr. Chayefsky's play (unproduced in New York). "The Latent Heterosexual," must be aware that he is one of the few fine television writers ("Marty," "Bachelor Party," etc.) of the 1950's who has continued to mature, to test his talent in rather brave, unpredictable ways that leave him open to disaster.Melodramatic farce is a pretty far remove from the slice-of-life things that Mr. Chayefsky once did so well. However, the writer's intelligence, and his only recently exercised gift for fantasy (which reminds me a bit of Evelyn Waugh's) save "The Hospital" from a couple of serious seizures that, toward the end, overtake the movie when it feels called upon to certify its serious purposes and to straighten out its peculiar plot. The latter involves, among other things, my favorite movie line of the year: "God was admitted to this hospital last weekunder the name of Guernsey."Mr. Hiller, who is a much better director than the scripts of "Love Story" and "Popi" could possibly indicate, works beautifully with Mr. Chayefsky, with whom he collaborated in 1964 on "The Americanization of Emily." It isn't simply that he obtains excellent performances from his stars, from Mr. Scott and especially from Diana Rigg, but he has perfectly cast the film down to roles that are so small they dependI suspectas much on natural mannerism as on acting talent.Although Mr. Chayefsky has written a very contemporary melodramatic farce, his political sympathies have their roots in the liberalism of 20 years ago. This is apparent in Mr. Scott's character, a once brilliant, now exhausted and suicidal doctor who is brought back to life and commitment by an improbable, immensely romantic one-night stand with Miss Rigg, a dropout from Boston's Beacon Hill who now lives in the mountains of Mexico where her father preaches "the apocalypse to solemnly amused Indians." Mr. Chayefsky has been responsible for some lovely lines in his life, but nothing quite to equal the monologue by which this marvelous actress seduces her co-star, by word and well-exposed leg."The Hospital" opened yesterday at the Sutton Theater.

title: U.S. JURY INDICTS 6 AT NEVADA HOTEL
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 14 (AP)  A Federal grand jury returned a threecount indictment against six top officials of the Dunes Hotel today, alleging that they conspired to skim money from gaming tables and filed false corporate income tax returns.

title: Nixon Views Concorde, Expects Similar U.S Jet
description: LADES FIELD, the Azores, Dec. 14 (AP)President Nixon spected the Concorde, the BritishFrench supersonic transport, today and voiced regrets that the United States has not built a similar plane.

title: CONGRESS VOTES ALASKA LAND BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 Congress passed today a bill to pay Alaska's natives $962.?? million and grant them 40 mil lion acres of land in settle meet of their centuryold land claims.

title: JURY IN MYLAI CASE TO HEAR ARGUMENTS
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Dec. 14  The closing arguments by the defense and the prosecution in the courtmartial of Col. Oran K. Henderson will be heard tomorrow by the jury of two generals and five colonels, who will probably begin their deliberations Thursday.

title: Wall Street Shoppers Get the V.I.P. Treatment
description: Now that they're letting women into such posh Christmasshopping arrangements as Bonwit's 721 Club and Sak's Stag Club, how is a Wall Street executive going to buy his presents? After a couple of decades of having the clubs to themselves, being plied with drinks and generally pampered by the stores, the men are pouting over sharing their privileges with pushy female shoppers.

title: 2 Puerto Ricans Are Sentenced in Explosives Case
description: Justice Harold A. Birns of State Supreme Court in Manhattan imposed prison sentences yesterday on two young Puerto Rican students convicted of possessing explosive devices as scores of activists crowded in the courtfoom erupted into cries of Yankee asesino.

title: High Court Lets Stand Ruling on Fidelity Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) The Supreme Court let stand today a lower court ruling that, prior to 1968, a Massachusetts mutual fund should have been getting back part of the commissions it paid brokers who bought securities for it on regional exchanges.

title: Street Is Closed After Building Cracks
description: The police have closed 32d Street to automotive traffic between Broadway and Fifth Avenue following the discovery of a 15footlong fissure on the back wall of a twoyearold 40story building at 1250 Broadway.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (UPI)  The State Superior Court upheld yesterday 4 to 3, a court ruling that because Harrisburg Moose lodge was private club it had not violated the State Human Relations Act by refusing to serve dinner to Pennsylvania's leadMg black legislator, K. Leroy Irvis.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I have to say I saw it coming, a letter to The Times similar to that of Gerald E. McGuirk [Nov. 23], opposing school busing (for racial integration) with the higherorderofright argument.

title: Nixon Sees Azores Talk As Historic Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 President Nixon tonight described as a historic meeting his conference in the Azores with President Pompidou.

title: Dr. Pablo de Azcarate, Offkial Of League of Nations, 81, Dead
description: GENEVA, Dec. 14Dr. Pablo de Azcarate y Florez, Deputy Secretary General of the League of Nations from 1932 to 1936, died hero yesterday. He was 81 years old.

title: 47 Americans in Dacca
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 14 (AP)A Government spokesman said today that 47 Americans were among the foreign nationals who had chosen to remain in Dacca instead of joining air evacuation of foreigners from the besieged East Pakistan capital. A Foreign Ministry official said that they included 17 United States Government trade and consular representatives and that the rest were missionaries, doctors and other professionals.

title: U.S. Decision on Dollar a Shock to Europeans Even Though It Was Held Inevitable
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 14The announcement of a decision by the United States to devalue the dollar, long seen as inevitable in Europe if the United States was ever to straighten out its finances, still brought with it an clement of shock today as Europeans suddenly had to weigh the consequences.

title: POVERTY UNIT SETS RURAL HOUSING AID
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 The Office of Economic Opportunity is planning a nationwide experimental effort to develop a Volkswagen house intended to relieve widespread rural housing squalor.

title: Seafarers Head to Get Award
description: Paul Hall, president, of the Seafarers International Union, is scheduled to receive the fifth annual, Labor Human Rights Award at a dinner in his honor tonight at the New York Hilton Hotel. Charles S. Zimmerman, Chairman of the dinner, said that the award by the Jewish Labor Committee's National Trade Council for Human sights was being given to Mr. Hall as a tribute to a trade unionist who stands in the forefront of the struggle for social justice and equal opportunity.

title: Labor Aide Quits Governor
description: Victor Borella has resigned as special assistant for labor affairs to Governor Rockefeller and plans to move to a farm he owns in Enfield, N. H. Manager of operations and later executive vice president of Rockefeller Center, he had been associated with Mr. Rockefeller for more than three decades. One of the Governor's key contacts with labor leaders and werkers throughout the state, he helped win labor support for the Governor in political campaigns.

title: Excerpts From the Testimony by Serpico
description: Following are excerpts from testimony yesterday before the Knapp Commission as it resumed public hearings arising from its inquiry into police corruption here. The commission heard nine days of testimony in October.

title: Senator Byrd Backs Admiral, His Uncle, On '26 Polar Flight
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) Beret Balchen, the Norwegianborn pilot of the first plane to fly over the South Pole, in 1929, says that Adm. Richard E. Byrd was false in his claim of being the first to fly over the North Pole, in 1926.

title: MIKE RYBA, PITCHER IN 2 LEAGUES, DIES
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Dec. 14 (UPI)Mike Ryba, a former St. Louis Cardinals and Boston Red Sox pitcher, was fatally injured in a fall in his yard at home here yesterday. He was 68 years old.

title: Sea Attack on Chittagong
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 14 (AP)The Indian Navy said today that it had given Chittagong, East Pakistan's most important port, a severe pounding from the sea and the air. It said that parts of the city had been set ablaze.

title: C. W. Post, Stony Brook Win
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I., Dec. 14 C. W. Post and Stony Brook gained the final of the second annual Schaefer of Long Island basketball tournament at the State University in Farmingdale tonight.

title: Inventories for October Showed a Sluggish Climb
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14Total busineis inventories conuntied to rise only sluggishly in October, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CAPITAL BASEBALL CALLED OUT IN '72
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)  Bowie Kuhn, Commissioner of Baseball, said today a major league team for Washington in 1972 was not possible. But he left open the possibility that a new team will move into the nation's capital in 1973.

title: ROBERT NICKERSON, LAWYER, DIES AT 54
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 14 Robert E. Nickerson, a lawyer here and in New York, died yesterday in Crystal Springs, Fla., while on a business trip. He was 54 years old and lived at 27 Meadow bank Road, Old Greenwich.

title: Burns Will Resign To. Assist Lindsay, Democrats Report
description: John J. Burns, Democratic State chairman, was reported last night to be resigning his job to aid the expected campaign of Mayor Lindsay.

title: Germans Set the Signing Of Berlin Pact for Friday
description: BONN, Dec. 14 (AP)West Germany and East Germany will put final signatures Friday to accords on putting into effect the fourpower agreement on Berlin, Chancellor Willy Brandt's Government announced today.

title: Text of Joint Statement
description: ANGRA DO HEROISMO, the Azores, Dec. 14Following is the text of a joint statement by President Nixon and President Pompidou announcing broad agreement on the basis for a settlement of the world monetary crisis:

title: Japanese Doctors Link Nerve Disease To Dysentery Drug
description: A crippling disease closely resembling one that has afflicted 10,000 Japanese has been induced experimentally for the first time by feeding animals a drug that is used frequently to treat dysentery, a team of researchers in Okayama has reported in a medical journal.

title: Ducks Obtain Wally Jones From 76ers, Drop Webb
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 14 (AP) The Milwaukee Bucks of the National Basketball Association said today they had acquired Wally Jones, who has not played all season because of a contract dispute with the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Impact of Devaluation
description: To devalue the dollar, Congress would have to approve an increase in the official United States price for gold, which has stood at $35 an ounce since 1934.

title: Acupuncture Demonstrated at Medical Parley Here
description: Before a skeptical audience of anesthesiologists, a Chinese acupuncturist demonstrated yesterday what his ancient medical art can and cannot do to relieve chronic pain.

title: India in Red Cross Accord
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 14An Indian spokesman said today that the Indian Government had been informed this afternoon by cablegram from the headquarters of the Red Cross in Geneva that its representative in Dacca had given protection to the East Pakistan officials.

title: LAKERS TAKE 22D AS BLAZERS LOSE
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 14 (AP)The Los Angeles Lakers, with five players scoring in the 20's raced to their 22d straight National Basketball Association victory tonight, a 129114 triumph over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Parley Urges College Facilities For Counseling of Homosexuals
description: College counselors and student homosexuals, in a daylong conference yesterday, called for facilities to provide homosexual undergraduates with more sympathetic, skillful and specialized advice.

title: Merger News
description: Shareholders of Mohawk Airlines and Allegheny Airlines, at separate meetings yesterday, approved the proposed merger of Mohawk into Allegheny. Allegheny would issue one common share for each 4.25 shares of Mohawk common stock, plus a sevenyear warrant to buy twothirds of a share of Alle gheny common at $18 a share for the first five years and at $25 a share for the next two years. Allegheny has 4,687,589 common shares outstanding and Mohawk has 2,991,147 shares outstanding. The combined carrier would be the nation's sixth largest domestic line in terms of passengers carried.

title: NATO Aides Voice Concern Over Weakness of Northern Defenses
description: COPENHAGEN, DenmarkSenior officers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization report a significant shift in the trategic balance toward the Soviet Union in the Northern European Command.

title: Reaction Here Good but Guarded
description: The business and financial community responded favorably, if somewhat guardedly, to the announcement yesterday that President Nixon had agreed to move toward a formal devaluation of the dollar.

title: DISTRICTING STIRS POLITICAL ANXIETY
description: ALBANY, Dec. 14The state's lawmakers showed up here today to sec what the masterminds of legislative reapportionment had done to them. What they found was that despite the months of work with computers, the actual bills were not yet ready for them.

title: Trainer Notches No. 100 As Clear And Fast Scores
Postel Asks Inquiry on Donations To Lindsay by City Borrowers
description: Councilman Robert I. Postel called yesterday for a Council investigation into contributions by Municipal Loan Program borrowers to Mayor Lindsay's 1969 reelection campaign.

title: LOUIS A. ROSENBLUM; INTERNIST, WAS 60
description: Dr. Louis A. Rosenblum, an internist, died yesterday at Parkway Hospital, Forest Hills, Queens, of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 60 years old and lived at 11035 Jewel Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Lord & Taylor Planning 5 Stores in Chicago Area
description: In an unusual move by a major fashion retailer, Lord & Taylor announced yesterday plans to open five large stores in the Chicago area, requiring an investment of more than $60million.

title: About Pro Football
description: While the teams that got into the postseason playoffs are congratulating themselves, what does the future hold for those that were expected to Qualify and did not? There are four that disappointedinclude the Jets and five should San Francisco fall on Sunday to beat Detroit and win the title in its division. The others are the Lions, who have an angry owner in Bill Ford; the St. Louis Cardinals, one of whose players was just suspended for having insulted en owner, and the Oakland Raiders, who are angry at themselves.

title: MRS. EDWARD NAHON
description: Mrs. Ruth Taub Nahon, who operated the Nahon Company, a furniture house, for many years after the death in 1939 of her husband, Edward, who founded the concern in 1906, died on Sunday at her home, 930 Fifth Avenue.

title: Packard $18Million Stock Gain Going to Charity
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14David Packard, the California businessman who resigned last weekend as Deputy Defense Secretary, announced today that he was giving $18.8million in stock holdings to charity to avoid any conflict of interest during his three years in government.

title: COURT BUCKS TV FROM MONTICELLO
description: Offtrack action on the superfecta at Monticello Raceway. will begin today, but not with the live television and $1 wager the Offtrack Betting Corporation had hoped to offer.

title: Bengalis Urgedto Observe Geneva Accords in Dacca
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14The chief spokesman for the Bengali secessionists at the United Nations said tonight that he had asked the acting president of the secessionist regime to give assurances to the Red Cross that the Geneva Conventions on the treatment of prisoners will be respected in Dacca.

title: Black Woman Joins Guard
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 14 (UPI)Mrs. Yvonne Marie Gooch today became the first black woman to take the oath of office as a Wac in the Army National Guard. The 23yearold Nashville woman is the sixth Woman to enter the ranks of the Army National Guard.

title: Oppenheimer Takes Over British Advisory Concern
description: Oppenheimer & Co. announced yesterday that it had acquired Brendan Securities, Ltd., a British investmentmanagement concern that will opcrate out of Oppenheimer's London headquarters. The entire Brendan moneymanagement staff will be retained.

title: U.S. Skiers Balk at Course
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Dec. 14 (UPI)The United States women's ski team will refuse to compete in the Kandahar downhill event this weekend because the course is too dangerous, Coach Hank Tauber said today.

title: U.S. Trying Paving Material Made of Wastes and Carbage
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)  The Government is trying out a new paving material made of industrial wastes, trash and garbage.

title: St JOHN'S DOWNS AMERICAN, 8376
description: A rebound basket by Greg Cluess with 2:50 left in overtime put unbeaten St. John's ahead to stay as the Redmen staved off American University, 83.76, at the victors' court in Jamaica, Queens, last night.

title: Dollar Decision Is Hailed By Congressional Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 Congressional lehders overwhelmingly applauded President Nixon's decision today to devalue the dollar.

title: Alfred E. Broth Dead at 52; Led Film Laboratory Firm
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) Alfred E. Bruch, president of Capital Film Laboratories of Washington and Miami, died of a heart attack yesterday while on a business trip to Miami. He was 52 years old.

title: DATA FROM SOVIET WITHHELD BY U.S.
description: SPACE CENTER, Houston, Dec. 14 (AP)Some information about the Russian space program is being withheld from the American public.

title: Advertising:
description: Late next summer the J. C. Penney Company, one of the nation's top merchandisers, will launch a greatly expanded national advertising campaign that will include its debut in network TV and increased use of national magazines.

title: MISS DUNN SINGS CARMEN FOR MET
description: Since the world is full of singers who know the roles in Carmen, the Metropolitan Opera revolves the casting of the Bizet work a good deal. In such a familiar piece, varied personnel can be desirable, particularly if the production retains some smoothness. The company's eighth performance of the season on Monday night, to its credit, went without noticeable hitch.

title: PHYSICIAN SUES CITY FOR A NEW HOSPITAL
description: Dr. Dominick Miraldi, a prominent Staten Island physician, sued Mayor Lindsay and city health officials yesterday, trying to force the city to provide a general municipal hospital on the island.

title: I.R.S. Issues Booklet Explaining Phase Two
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)The Internal Revenue Service said today that it was making available free a new eightpage booklet designed to explain Phase Two.

title: C. C. N. Y. Defeats Yeshiva
description: City College broke open a close game midway through the second half and defeated Yeshiva, 7356, last night on the loser's court.

title: SUFFOLK DEBATES CONDIMENT RULES
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Dec. 14 Salt shakers, sugar bowls and catchup bottles may be on their way off the tables of Suffolk County's 5,000 restaurants and diners because the police have received reports that LSD and other drugs have been put into the condiments.

title: Claims Against State Mount
description: ALBANY, Dec. 14 (AP)The State Court of Claims said that, as of this morning's mail, it had received 506 notices of intent from current and former Attica prison inmates planning to file claims against the state for damages allegedly suffered on or after Sept. 13, when the riot there was quelled.

title: Auto Prices Trimmed To Reflect Tax Repeal
description: DETROIT, Dec. 14 (UPI)The sticker prices of 1972 model automobiles were changed again today as the makers announced reductionsas much as $341 in one caseto reflect the repeal of the 7 per cent Federal excise tax.

title: Tax Program's Highlights
description: Following are the highlights of Governor Rockefeller's proposal yesterday for $427million in new taxes that he says are needed to help meet an anticipated state budget deficit of $1.5billion during the next 15 months:

title: Suit Attacks Political Use Of Compulsory Union Dues
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)  A suit to end the tax exemption of any labor unions that use compulsory dues for political purposes has been filed in Federal District Court here.

title: La Fonda del Sol Citod As Health Code Violator
description: Saying there were serious Health Code violations at La Fonda del Sol, the city Health Department announced yesterday that it would close the midtown restaurant Dec. 28 unless they were corrected.

title: LINDSAY CONCEDES LABOR'S HOSTILITY
description: Mayor Lindsay, who has presided over sonic of the most costly settlements to municipal unions in the city's history, conceded early yesterday that ninny labor leaders were hostile to him.

title: Asks to See Nixon on China
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 14 (AP)A civil rights leader and his wife who visited Communist China last summer have requested a meeting with President Nixon. Hosea Williams, program coordinator of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, in a telegram to Mr. Nixon asked for the meeting prior to your Chinese visit. The President has scheduled a trip to China in February.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Southern Company raised an indicated $131.46million yesterday in what was believed the largest competitive sale of utility common shares for cash on record. A ninemanager underwriting syndicate led by Blyth & Co. won 7 million Southern shares with a bid of $18.78, or 3 cents higher than the closing price on the New York Stock Exchange. On reoffering, the stock was priced at $19.25 and was reported by a Blyth spokesman to be going very well.

title: Firestone Lifts Its Dividend to 20.8c
description: The Firestone Tire & Rubber Company raised its quarterly dividend yesterday to 20.8 cents a share from 20 cents a share, effective with the payment of Jan. 20. A company spokesman said the 4 per cent increase was the maximum alallowable for 1972 under Phase Two guidelines.

title: Blast in Zambia Kills 29
description: MUMMA, Zambia, Dec. 14 (AP)Nine freight cars loaded with explosives blew up at the siding of an explosives factory today, killing 29 persons and scattering debris over 25 acres.

title: PACT WITH FRANCE
description: ANGRA DO HEROISMO, the Azores, Dec. 14The United States, determined to resolve the world monetary crisis, announced today that it was prepared to devalue the dollar by a small but as yet undetermined amount as part of an international agreement to realign the rates of major currencies.

title: Silverstein, Alone, in Program Of Unusual Violinistic Interest
description: Every other person entering Alice Tully Hall Monday night, It seemed, carried a fiddle case, a hint that something of more than passing violinistic interest. might be about to take place inside. The hint was correct: Joseph Silverstein, who has been the Boston Symphony's concertmaster for nine years, walked onstage alone and proceeded to play with extraordinary skill an entire program of unaccompanied works.

title: A New Chapter in U. S. Monetary History
description: President Nixon's agreement yesterday on the need for a devaluation of the dollar marks the latest chapter in American monetary history, which began even before the establishment of the United States.

title: SOHIO DIVESTITURE IS APPROVED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) The Justice Department approved yesterday the divestiture by the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) of its Fleetwing and Fremont Oil subsidiaries and some retail gasoline and commercial Consumer accounts to Pennzoil United, Inc., of Houston.

title: Reagan Signs Bill to Halt Contempt Citations on News
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP)Newsmen who refuse to disclose sources of information can no longer be cited for contempt under legislation signed into law by Gov. Ronald Reagan.

title: Ex Hudson Official Admits Embezzling
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 14  C. Harry Callari, a 58yearold Democratic ward leader here who headed the nowdefunct Hudson County Mosquito Extermination Commission, pleaded guilty here today to charges of embezzling $150,000 in county funds.

title: Bonavena, Miffed, Signs for Patterson
description: Just when the match appeared to have been lost in the translation of financial arrangements, Oscar Bonavena signed yesterday to oppose Floyd Patterson, the former twotime world heavyweight champion, in a 10round bout at Madison Square Garden on Friday, Feb. 11.

title: JAZZ RECITAL GIVEN BY PEIFFER, PIANIST
description: Bernard Peiffer's concert at Town Hall Monday night was a study in what can happen when a classically trained pianist takes a patronizing view of jazz. What resulted had less to do with swing and rhythm than with the 19thcentury tradition of piano impromptus.
