description: Miss Fanchon Metcalf Watkins plans to be married late next month to Richard Irving Burnham, a former Foreign Service officer who is vice president and general counsel of the International Executive Service Corps.

title: COLUMBIA ARTISTS APPEAR AT GARDEN
description: Few people had any trouble humming the tunes as they came out of Madison Square Garden Friday night. Columbia Records had just presented a showcase of its M.O.P. artists. M.O.R., in the jargon of the record burliness, means Middle of the Road; it also means Easy Listening, and it refers to per formers whose music is blandly melodic enough to have spe cial appeal to those members of the audience who don't want to be disturbed, just enter tained, thanks.

title: Leslie Valk Is Fiancee of Student
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 18John Garry Valk, publisher of Life magazine, and Mrs. Valk have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leslie Valk, to Lawrence David. Denton, son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Benton of Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: Mary Giuliano Is Pride
description: Miss Mary Jane Giuliano and Vincent Joseph Lee Jr. were married here yesterday morning. The Rev. Joseph Hellman performed the cere mony in St. Stanislaus Ro man Catholic Church in Mas peth, Queens. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Giuliano of Mas peth are the parents of the bride, whose husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee of Lakewood, N. J.

title: The Case of The Spiked Salt Shaker Is Pondered
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I.With some people responding to his suggestion with astonish ment and others with en dorsement, Suffolk County Legislator Louis A. Fuoco Jr. has begun redrafting his proposed law that would mandate individual packages of seasoning, at restaurant tables.

title: The World
description: I became very angry when I heard, and made immediate arrangements to be driven to the airport.

title: Last of U.S. Whalers Call It Quits as Era Ends
description: POINT SAN PABLO, Calif., Dec. 18They had worked through the day stripping the huge harpoon gun off the deck of the Dennis Gayle and now in the late afternoon the job was done.

title: 9YEAR STRIKE ENDS ON FLORIDA RAILWAY
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP)Union employes and of ficials of the Florida East Coast Railway have agreed to end a strike of nearly nine years under a plan that was given preliminary approval by a Fed eral district judge.

title: A perfect pair
description: Beguiled by jacket encomiums from Thornton Wilder (this gifted portrait painter), Sir Laurence Olivier (a delicious draught), Rene Clair (daz zlingly brilliant, deeply mov ing) and Artur Rubinstein (brilliantly written), I opened this book with great expecta tions of learning, at long last, the earthly realities behind the Hollywood legend of Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy concluded the book with two firm convictionsthat persons described favorably in a book are not necessarily reliable wit nesses to its worth; and that Mr. Kanin's memoir is too modestly titled. It's proper title should be Me and Tracy and Hepburn and Me. But perhaps humility forbade.

title: AT CHRISTMAS REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST
description: WHEN public welfare is available, why give to the voluntary social agencies? Because welfare checks will buy food, shelter and clothing but they do not provide for the resourceful guidance and spe cialized services which the agencies offer to bewildered fathers struggling to hold their homes together, to deserted mothers, to the children and old people who are without friends or material resources.

title: Miss Edwards Triumphs In SquashRacquets Event
description: Marigold Edwards of Pitts burgh defeated Mrs. Nina Moyer of Pennington, N. J., yesterday in the final of the Columbia University Club's first women's invitation squash racquets tournament. The scores were 1510, 1817, 159.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I thoroughly enjoyed Ar nold M. Auerbach's article, Were You There, Ada Louise? I read From the Tempora Romana to all the Latin classes I teach. Our question to Mr. Auerbach is: Was Carthage there in 80 A.D.?

title: Miss McQuide Has Nuptials
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 18  Miss Sarah Sanford McQuide, an elementary school teacher in Ware, Mass., and Alfred Leland Griggs, treasurer of the CocaCola Bottling Company, in Northampton, Mass., were married here this afternoon.

title: Slower Growth Ahead
description: Japanese automobile manu facturers, who in recent years moved strongly into the American market, expect sales increases to continue in 1972, but a much slower pace.

title: OFFICIAL SCORES METHADONE PLAN
description: Howard A. Jones, chairman of the State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission, contends that the planned expansion of New York City's ambulatory methadone maintenance pro grams from 3,000 to 11,000 patients by next June is too rapid an, increase.

title: Bruce Martin Weds Lindsay Crawford
description: HOHOKUS, N. J., Dec. 18 Miss Lindsay Anne Craw ford and Bruce Beahm Mar tin were married here this afternoon in St. Bartholo mew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Hayward L. Levy.

title: 3 U.S. Planes Reported Down in North Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Dec. 19 (UPI)North Vietnamese gunners shot down three American planes deep in North Vietnam yes terday, the Hanoi radio said today.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Clive Barnes is entitled to his opinion concerning Harold Pinter's Old Times. He re fers to it as a great play and one to luxuriate in. Htewever, I think not. In fact, Pinter has not even written a play in the technical sense. It's more of a lyrical, Prous tian novelone that tries to evoke thought and feeling among its characters, rather than sustain any type of con certed action.

title: Photography
description: EITHER I'm getting old and jaded or this Christmas season is slower than most. Ex cent for a very few, which I discussed here two weeks ago, this season's crop of books has offered slim pick ings, the year's best having appeared months ago. So, too; with the exhibits; I spent a day wandering around from gallery to gallery re cently, and out of half a dozen shows found none which elicited anything stronger than a rerfunctory nod at their competence. Steve Schapiro's group of blackandwhite documen tary photographs at the Im age Gallery, 565 Fifth Ave nue, is one example; accept able photojournalism which doesn't successfully nego tiate the transition from the newspaper  page reproduc toin to the print on the wall. Cory Friedman's color series, Northern Light, at. Discov eryModernage, 6 West 45th Street, is another, wellmade  by the photographer him self  color prints, atmos pheric landscapes and rural vignettes, pleasant but less than challenging.

title: HEALTH CARE PLAN IS LOSING SUPPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Support for compulsory nation al health insurance appears to be on the wane, although or ganized labor insists that it has not given up the fight to have Congress enact such a program for all Americans.

title: Horse Shows
description: Enforcement of the drug rules and the serious epidemic of Venezuelan Equine Encephalomyelitis (VEE) domi nated the equestrian world during 1971.

title: Harry Nichols, 75, Retired City Editor of The News
description: Harry Nichols, who retired last year after having been city editor of The New York Daily News for 24 years, died yester day in Bellevue Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 330 East 43d Street.

title: Ragtime, Jazz And Bobby Hackett
description: NEW ORLEANS RAG TIME ORCHESTRA (Pearl Records, P. O. Box 1411, Salisbury, N. C., $5); DAWN OF THE CENTURY RAGTIME OR CHESTRA (Arcane Records, Maple Leaf Club, 5560 W. 62d St., Los Angeles, Calif., $5.25). As a parallel if unre lated development to the cur rent interest in Scott Joplin and the classic composers of piano rags, two orchestras have been organized to play arrangements of rags and rag time tunes that were written for dance orchestras during the first decade of this cen tury. The New Orleans Rag time Orchestra was formed several years ago by Lars Edegran, a young Swedish Pianist who settled in New Orleans in 1965. The seven piece band is a mixture of Swedish youth, some veteran black New Orleans musicians and the pioneer jazz historian William Russell, who is a vio linist trained in classical music.

title: A Dog's Best Friend
description: RENO, Dec. 18 (UPI) A German pointer named Lobo ventured onto the ice of Vir ginia Lake Thursday in pursuit of a duck and the ice broke. Lobo became tired and was about to go under when Steve Troxe II, an employe of the Parks Department, dove into the water and held the dog up until help arrived.

title: Art Notes
description: If so unpopular with the rest of us, he can't be all bad, one Madi son Avenue dealer re assured another last week over lunch at Les Pleiades. Their topic was Bernard Den enberg, a brash, faststepping art merchant of 35, whose rise from mere money to riches in a decade's short space has not gone unnoticed on the bustling art bourse.

title: Marsha Tretin Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis Tretin of Brooklyn and Monroe, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Marsha Iris Tretin, to Albert Daniel Abrams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gustav Abrams of Bally, Pa. Miss Tretin is a thirdyear student at Brandeis University, Mr. Abrams, a cum lauds grad uate of Brandeis last June, is attending the Temple Univer sity Medical School.

title: David Warner After the Fall
description: IN Sam Peckinpah's new film, Straw Dogs, there is a tall crippled actor who can hardly walk, He plays the village idiot, rather like John Mills without the makeup In Ry an's Daughter. The face is familiar but the name will not be found in the credits. It is David Warner, exRoyal Shakespeare star in Ham let, exmovie star opposite Vanessa Redgrave in Mor gan.

title: A Republican Spy in Muskies Ranks Is Unmasked and Sent Out Into the Cold
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 Despite her $25 contribu tion to the unannounced Democratic Presidential cam paign of Senator Edmund S. Muskie and her handwritten note to the Muskie head quarters offering advice on tactics to turn President Nixon out of Office, Diane V. Moore has been sum marily removed from the Muskie mailing, list.

title: Including, rumor has it, one SPURIOUS WORD
description: The Oxford English Dictionary was the moonlanding project of the Eng lish people, and if Sidney Webb, who was born the year the project was conceived and reached 70 the year it was completed, did not denounce it as a dreadful extravagance in an age when poverty was abundant in the groaning industrial areas of Eng land, it can only have been because he forgot to do so. The enterprise resultedto use the words of its publishers in connection with the new editionin the most prestigious book ever published, even as the moon landing is almost indisputably the most prestigious scientific enterprise ever consummated. Of course, scien tific achievement, like an athletic one, is obsolescent in a sense quite dif ferent from a cultural achievement. The man who ran the fourminute mile knew that he was not being given tenure as a world record holder.

title: Democrats Sent Reeling By G. O. P.'s Districting
description: ALBANY  While most of his State Senate colleagues were still squinting at the maps of their new districts in a Capitol meeting room, Senator Murray Schwartz, a Democrat of Laurelton, Queens, was in an outer of fice on the phone. His swarthy features seemed darker than usual as he talked, his tone alternating between annoy ance and subservience.

title: The Nation
description: CHICAGO  When Otto Kerner let it be known early in 1969 that he would not seek reelection as Gover nor of Illinois, the liberal Chicago Sun Times published an effusive appraisal of his two terms at Springfield. One word best described his career, said the paper: impeccable.

title: Mary Livingston and David BushBrown Affianced
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 18Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Livingston Jr. of Providence and Bristol have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Coe Livingston, to David Fraser BushBrown. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Bush Brown of Locust Valley, L. I., and Barnstable, Mass.

title: Cairo Opera Design Contest
description: CAIRO, Dec. 18 (Reuters) A competition for a design for a new Cairo opera house to re place the one destroyed by fire in October is to be held. The new theater will be constructed on the same site as the old one but will be larger.

title: Toy Profits: Ho Ho Hum
description: The toy business will reach its annual crescendo this week as the final Christmas gifts are purchased and mer chants cash registers give the final tally for the year.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Among the many philosophical gems offered by Satchel Paige was this: Don't look back. Something might be gaining on you. But when 01 Batch looks back on the year just past, he will always glow with pride. This is the year when he was installed in the Baseball Hall of Fame, not in the special wing origin ally set aside for otherwise unqualified Negro leaguers but in the main ball with Babe Ruth, Jackie Rob inson, Ty Cobb, Roy Campanella and other genuine immortals.

title: Cusack of East Tennessee Captures Atlanta Marathon
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 10 (AP) Neil Cusack, East Tennessee State's flying Irishman, raced to victory today in the Peach Bowl marathon, covering the 26 miles 385 yards through hilly section of northwest Atlanta in 2 hours 16 minutes 18 seconds.

title: Louisiana Race Won By U.S. Represnetative
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sunday, Dec. 19 (AP)United States Representative Edwin Ed wards scored a slim victory over State Senator J. Ben nett Johnston yesterday in a runoff election for the Demo cratic nomination for Gover nor of Louisiana.

title: DISAPPOINTED
description: To THE EDITOR: Your man Don Heckman covered my Madison Square concert Nov. 14. He failed to state in his review that he left during the intermission, and yet he commented on the lack of new material and ap parent boredom of my per formance. I do not expect this from a newspaper of your caliber, and I think you do not expect such shortcuts from your staff.

title: When Snow Slows Caucasus Town, The Young Drift Off
description: PASANAURI, U.S.S.R.In the summer this highland town tucked in the shadow of the snowcapped peaks of the Cau casus is busy with farming and tourists. But in fall and winter, time hangs with a dead weight over Pasanauri, as it does in many an Appalachian town in America, and the young drift away to the cities.

title: Jeannine B. Rhinelander to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. T. J. Oakley Rhinelander of New York and Newport, It I., of the engagement of Mr. Rhine lander's daughter, Miss Jean nine Byers Rhinelander of New York and Villefranche surmer, France, to Peter A. V. Schoeffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred 0. Schoeffer of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Common Market vs. Continental Can
description: BRUSSELSIn a major toughening up of its antitrust policy, the Executive Com mission of the European Eco nomic Community told the Continental Can Company of the United States last week that its purchase last April of a Dutch packaging concern violated the competition rules of the Common Market. Con tinental Can was given by the sixnation group until July 1 to end its alleged in fraction.

title: President Tells Pakistani Of Concern for Stability
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 President Nixon today told. Pakistan's Deputy Prime Min ister and Foreign Minister, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, that big power cooperation would be needed to prevent further out breaks of war on the sub continent.

title: LEAD DIE ON, $14,60, WINS AT LAUREL
description: LAUREL, Md., Dec. 18Lead Me On, a 4yearold daughter of the late Native Dancer from the Mooring Stable, posted her second victory in six days to day, leading all the way in tak ing the $24,050 Monumental Handicap at Laurel Race Course.

title: Key West Selected as Site Of Animal Quarantine Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz has announced the se lection of Fleming Key of Key West, Fla., as the site for a new $6.7million animal quaran tine station for livestock from countries where there is hoof and mouth disease.

title: McClendon Delaying Talks On Posts at Texas A.&M.
description: EL PASO, Tex., Dec. 18 (AP) Charlie McClendon, coach of Loui'iana State's Sun Bowl victorys, said after the game today that he would not have any definitive talks with Texas A. and M. officials until he finished his coaching duties in the Hula Bowl in January.

title: Vaulter Loses Poles Rut Not School Event
description: Brad Armstrong of William T. Clarke High in Westbury, LI., scored a victory in the pole vault the hard way yes terday at the. Bishop Loughlin games.

title: Narcotics Policemen Attending Colleges Incognito
description: City narcotics policemen dis guised as students are attend ing classes at several colleges in the five borough in an under cover campaign to cut off drug traffic on local campuses.

title: Law/Medicine
description: If the Government can tell me what to charge my patients, how long will it be before Washington tells me what drugs to prescribe and what op erations to perform?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is surely one of the great ironies of American history that after 300 years of legally enforced and/or sanc tioned oppression of AfroAmericans, black people are now being told they can't be allowed full participation in American society because to do so would discriminate against whites.

title: Michele Faw Wed To Air Lieutenant
description: DARIEN, Conn., Dec. 18 Miss Michele Christine Faw was married here this morning to Second Lieut. Christopher Thomas Griffin, U.S.A.F.R. The Rev. Michael O'Brien performed the cere mony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

title: INDIANA CRUSHES IRISH FIVE, 9429
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 18 (AP)Indiana University's bas ketball team held Notre Dame scoreless for 13 minutes in the first half today and went on to overwhelm the Irish, 9429. The 12thranked Hoosiers, who have a 51 wonlost rec ord, trailed 5.4 in the opening minutes but raced away to a 4513 halftime lead. The Irish, 2.5, were able to make only two field goals in the first half.

title: Reader's Report
description: Pity poor Captain William Montgomery King, a subma riner in the Pentagon. Defense intends to amputate the budg et of the new missile system he has been working on. His wife desperately wants him to retire. And a hippie son plans to dismantle the Navy, along with his father's hopes for flag rank.

title: GREECE WILL EASE HER MARTIAL LAW
description: ATHENS, Dec. 18Premier George Papadopoulos an nounced tonight that the Gov ernment would reduce martial law and release banished politi cal prisoners. He reiterated his annual pledge to restore de mocracy, not demagoguery, but did not say when.

title: Rockets Top Royals
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 18 (UPI) Elvin Hayes and Calvin Mur phy scored 56 points tonight to lead the Houston Rockets to a 126116 victory over the Cin cinnati Royals.

title: New York
description: ALBANYLike a tatterdemalion Santa, Governor Rockefeller reached into his holiday sack last week and pulled out a proposal for $427million in new state taxes.

title: SET TRIAL GOES TO JURY ON COAST
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 18The obscenity trial of a prosperous publisher of erotica, who con verted a Presidential Commis sion's report on pornography Into a best seller by adding more than 500 salacious pic tures to its official text, went to a jury in Federal court here yesterday.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Thelma and Herman. Edin son [Nov. 28] wrote that buying and selling stock in no matter how solid a company  becomes sheer speculation.

title: Miss Cooper Wed To John H. Byrne
description: Miss Christian Cooper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Arthur Cooper of New York, was married yesterday to John Henry Byrne, presi dent of Jack Byrne Advertis ing and son of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Byrne of Belmont, Mass. The Rev. Kenneth 0. Jones performed the cere mony in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: New Era on the Subcontinent
description: Pakistan's Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, Zulfiltar Ali Bhutto, told interviewers here last week his country would have to make drastic changes in its internal and foreign policies in the wake of the Indian Pakistani conflict that was then rapidly approaching its climax. We are now really at the end of the road, Mr. Bhutto said. We have to begin anew.

title: Et Al.
description: Another Blitz book. Mr. Mos ley uses interviews to form his youarethere picture. Especial ly interesting are the long quotes from the diary of one intrepid lady determined to do her bit. The story has been told beforenotably in Angus Calder's The People's War but there is a particular vividness to Mr. Mosley's re construction. The moral, again, is that the bombing stiffened Londoners resistance and in spired them to great bravery and altruism.

title: NETS TURN BACK COUGARS, 118106
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 18 (AP)

title: TERM IS EXPIRED, BUT OTEPKA STAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Among the many matters still pending as the first session of the 92d Congress adjourned was the nomination of Otto F. Otepka to serve a full live year term on the Subversive Activities Control Board.

title: Recordings
description: RAY CHARLES once said about soul that Soul is when you can take a song and make it a part of youa part that is so true, so real, people think it must have happened to you. He mentioned noth ing about being Black or eat ing grits, He didn't even men tion lyrics or musical ar rangements. He simply linked music inextricably with bio graphical and emotional life aral aimed it all at the lis tener's sense of reality.

title: Law/Medicine
description: FT. MEADE, Md.The massacre of South Vietnamese civilians by Ameri can soldiers in the undefended hamlet of Mylal 4 almost four years ago moved last week from a military courtroom into the pages of history.

title: Nancy Williams Bride of J. L. Henderson
description: Miss Nancy Anita Williams and James Lewis Henderson, seniors at Howard Univer sity, were married yesterday afternoon in the Westmin ster Presbyterian Church in Jamaica, Queens, by the Rev. McQuay Kiah.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: John K. Galbraith's definition of neutrality [letter Dec. 9] is ambiguous. Neutrality in the wake of evident ag gression is a clearcut help to the aggressor. The aggressor wants us to be neutral and remain silent.

title: DIANA LYNN DIES; ACTRESS WAS 46
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 (AP) Diana Lynn, the stage and movie actress, died today in Mount Sinai Hospital, nine days after having suffered a stroke. She was 45 years old.

title: Bridge
description: T HE technique of the judo expert, who contrives to use an oppo nent's power against him, can some times be employed by the bridge expert so that an opponent's length and strength in trumps is converted into a liability.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: A NUMBER of major banks reduced their prime rates to 5 per cent from 5 per cent  Auto makers plan to produce about 2.4 million cars in the first quarter, up from 2.3 million a year ago.

title: Dime Novels for $1.50
description: DETROITThe raciest pub lication of the 19th century, The National Police Gazette, is being reprinted by a schol arly and very proper publish ing company that sells refer ence books to librarians.

title: Pakistanis Bitter
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 18 (AP)This is a disgrace. We would have fought to the last man but they told us to surrender. Why?

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: O. R. Strackbein's argu ment (Nov. 28) that too low a rate of increase in foreign wage rates jeopardizes em ployment levels in the United States may seem, at first blush, to clash with welles tablished principles transmit ted by the academic process.

title: Special Edition, a Lakeland Terrier, Is Chosen for Top Award at Boston
description: BOSTON, Dec. 18Ch. Spe cial Edition, a grizzle and tan Lakeland terrier owned by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Farrell Jr the No. 1 representative of his breed in America, gained a sig nal victory tonight. He defeated the second topwinning per former of the year, Ch. Lake side's Gilliagan's Island, the German shepherd owned by Daniel P. Dwier of Kreeson, N. J., and 2,485 other dogs.

title: BIGCITY MAYORS SENSE PROGRESS
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 16 After a year of lobbying in Washington, dining with busi nessmen, courting media execu tives and taking wellpublicized bus tours through one another's decaying cities, the dozen or so Mayors of big cities who have joined forces to dramatize the country's urban problems are beginning to feel that they are having an impact.

title: Students Sue Over Vote
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Several students at Prairie View A.&M. College have filed suit for a Federal injunction asking that the Waller County tax as sessor be required to register students at the predominantly black school as qualified voters. They charged that they had been denied the right to vote because the plaintiffs are black, students and young.

title: SAIGON TASK FORCE PULLS BACK AT CHUP
description: TAYNINH, South Vietnam, Dec. 18 (AP)South Vietnamese forces are pulling back from enemy sanctuaries in eastern Cambodia for what highrank ing military sources call a mo bile third phase of their offen sive across the border.

title: Bobby Jones, Golf Master, Dies; Only Player to Win Grand Slam
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 18Bobby Jones, the master golfer who scored an unparalleled grand slam by winning the United States and British Open and Amateur Tournaments in 1930, died today at his home. His age was 69.

title: SYRIANS REPORT ISRAELI BUILDUP
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 18 Syria reported today that Israel had massed a large number of troops on the truce Lite be tween the two countries in the Golan heights.

title: Mother's Helpers
description: Midnight

title: The Nation
description: Some 5,000 American young men have gone to prison rather than be drafted and fight in Vietnam; 70,000 more have chosen exile. Last week, Senator Robert Taft Jr., Ohio Repub lican, introduced a bill in Congress that would grant them amnesty in re turn for some kind of alternate serv ice.

title: FUHRMANS SCORE IN FIGURE SKATING
description: HERSHEY, Pa., Dec. 18 Gale and Joel Fuhrman, a brothersister team from Yonk ers, won the senior pairs cham pionship today in the Eastern sectional figure skating cham pionships at the Hershey Sports Arena today.

title: BOYS EDGES POWER IN LOUGHLIN TRACK
description: Bill Dabney, a talented junior runner from Boys High, made a move by Coach Doug Terry look like a stroke of genius yesterday.

title: Taylor Reveley 3d Weds Helen Bond
description: LYNCHBURCG, Va., Dec. 18 In the First Presbyterian Church here today, Miss Helen Martin Bond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Everett Bond, was married to Walter Taylor Reveley 3d of Rich mond, son of Dr. and Mrs. Reveley 2d of HampdenSyd ney. The ceremony was per formed by the Rev. Jerold D. Shetler, assisted by the Rev. H. William Vassey.

title: 30 AIDES TO HELP YOUTH OFFENDERS
description: New York City received Fed eral funds last week to employ 30 fulltime aides in Harlem to help provide services for 500 youths on probation there.

title: Session of Congress Marked by Challenge to Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Alternately defiant and passive, the 92d Congress ended its first session this week in an ambig uous position. It had clearly been thrown on the political defensive by Richard M. Nixon but it was still in a rising state of insurgency against the Pres idency.

title: To coddle the ego
description: We asked a group of department store executives and designers what they would giveand like to get for Christmas. Their suggestions, all very personal, are adaptable to all sorts of impromptu situations. For a weightwatcher, Lord & Taylor's Jane Stark sug gests a fivepound stack of assorted towels by Bill Blass, $22, accompanied by a Terraillon scale, $12.50. 2. A countryhouseguesti she says, might arrive on Christmas Eve with a fireside basket full of logs. This one is frora the store's antique collection, $70. 3. Car tier's president Michael Thomas would surprise a host with a sterling silver wine basket, $28, cradling a 1959 Chateau Latour, $27 at Sherry's. 4. Bloomingdale's de signer Barbara D'Arcy teams round woven traymats from China, $8 each, with supersized seashells, $4 each, for an imaginative hostess to use as place trays and salad bowls. 5. Henri Bendel's president, Geraldine Stutz, would choose a rack of Fauchon spices, $12, with an appropriate text, $20, to please the crea tive cook. G. Barbara D'Arcy also suggests an arrange ment of tasty breads on a pewter platter with scal loped edges, $60 at Bloomingdale's, as an instant centerpiece for a gourmet friend. 7. Giftgiving to Ferris Megorrity of B. Altman & Co. could be as simply de lightful as a hullshaped basket, $15, piled with pine cones and fresh apples to give the city dweller a whiff of nature. 8. Or, a wicker hamper, $10, stuffed with gift wrappings is a present for anyone's favorite last minute shopper to open (and use) before the 25th. 9. Designer Mario Buatta would giveand like to receive a handpainted pillow by George Oakes, $275 at The Greenery. 10. Geraldine Stutz crams a fragrant selec tion of Bendel's soaps, from $5.50 to $7 for four, into a wicker basket, $9 at The Greenery. Lastminute stock ing stuffers: 11. An antique gold letter rack, $35, with a box of Crane stationery, $12.50, both at Lord & Taylor. 12. An old Imari compote, $25, brimful of heady Irish $1.25

title: Books:
description: Looking into the future and assaying problems has become a preoccupation of government, scientists, urban planners, foundations, univer sities, business and others. Sometimes the results of such research are frighten ing, sometimes encouraging.

title: Anatomy of an Accident: How I Totaled My Volkswagen
description: IN a horrible way, it was almost sym phonicthis continuing din of beat en metal as our rented Volkswagen slammed over the rockstrewn shoul der of the rainslick Nova Scotia road. It was tile prelude to a serious accident. And it was happening to usto my wife and me. Many thoughts raced through my mindsome of them very strange.

title: Price Commission Asks Inquiry Into 150 Concerns on Violations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The Price commission an nounced today that it had asked the Internal Revenue Service to investigate whether close to 150 large retail and wholesale organizations in the country have increased prices in violation of Price Commis sion regulations.

title: Bills Pending or Defeated
description: A bill providing a twoyear extension of programs of the Office of Economic Opportunity was vetoed by the President, in part because it included a broad national program of child development and day care. The President also objected to mandatory funding levels set by Congress for particular O.E.O. programs, and to the creation of an independent National Legal Services Corporation. Congress failed to override the veto.

title: TwentyFour Titles for the World Traveler's Book Bag
description: One approaches these two dozen volumes like a book store clerk on Christmas Eve groggy but game. My wife, a cautious woman, would not let me put them all at once on our livingroom coffee table, but she did let me stack them on our bathroom scales. They weigh en masse 89 pounds roughly the equivalent of a Labrador Retriever. At full price, they cost collectively $363.75, which comes to seven and a half cents a page, or, if you prefer, $4.09 a pound.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Jodi Slier Married To Michael Conway
description: The marriage of Miss Jodi Myna Slier to Michael Mead Conway took place yester day at the Church Center for the United Nations. The 45 minute ceremony, written by the couple, was performed by the Rev. Dr. Carl D. Soule.

title: ITALIAN PRESIDENT CAUTIONS ELECTORS
description: ROME, Dec. 18President Giuseppe Saragat intervened in the tortuous search for his suc cessor today, the 10th day of inconclusive voting.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: NEW PLAN CALLED AID TO INMATES
description: On the theory that it is often wiser to talk it out than to go to court, the American Civil Liberties Union is plan ning a national effort to solve prisoners grievances through negotiations between ward ens and prisoners lawyers.

title: Harness Racing
description: Harness racing experienced one of its most remarkable years in 1971. Al though Roosevelt Raceway was up slightly and Yonkers Raceway down considerably, the national picture was healthy and many significant performances and achieve ments were regis tered. Overall at tendance was up 2 per cent with a to tal near 27 million. The betting handle was $2,050 million, up about 6 per cent.

title: The World
description: On the surface, Italy's voting for a President is a monotonous, marathon ritual; but underneath, it has the passions and intrigues of a Renaissance power play.

title: Architects Unit Endorses City Master PlanWith Qualifications
description: After 10 months of study, the New York chapter of the American Institute of Archi tects has issued a qualified endorsement of the city's Master Plan.

title: OTB Plans Bowie Telecasts Court Halts Monticello Show
description: The Offtrack Betting Corpora tion is prepared to switch its superfecta television show to Bowie if court action prevents it from continuing at Monticello Raceway beyond Jan. 1.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The conviction of Edgar H. Smith Jr. [news story Dec. 7] again illustrates the weaknesses of the Supreme Court's Fifth Amendment confession doctrine. A deal was made between Smith and the State of New Jersey. In return for his confession, Smith was promised a sentence approximately coequal with the time he had already served.

title: PRIEST IS OUSTED FOR SUING BISHOP
description: CAIRO, Ill., Dec. 18A 32 yearold white priest who has worked with a predominantly black civil rights group here has been excommunicated be cause he filed a civil suit against his Bishop for back pay.

title: Motorboats
description: A New Yorker who traveled three continents with one aimwinning the world offshore championshipand a town in the Midwest campaigning its own unlimited hydroplane provided the highlights of powerboating's year.

title: Poor Nicky, Poor Alix
description: FILM acting continues to be a very mysterious business.

title: The Best Slaves Got Very Drunk
description: How did a plantation slave spend Christmas in 19th century America? Frederick Douglass, above, who was born into slavery and later escaped to freedom and fatne as an Abolitionist orator, Presidential adviser and minis ter to Haiti, looked back on his Christmases in servitude in an 1882 essay called New Relations and Duties, portion of which is printed here. Douglass's words will be spoken by actor James Earl Jones, left, tomorrow night at 8 on Charnel 13, as part of NET Playhouse's An American Christmas: Words and Music. Mr. Jones seen here with singer Freda Payne, whom he accompa nies in a rendition of the spiritual Steal Away.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe 1972 competi tion between the Republicans and the Democrats for the biggest prize of all will operate under a new set of ground rules, both in the elimination round of the primaries that opens in a few weeks and in the finals of the post convention campaign.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: PROTESTANTS NOTE FAULTS IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, Dec. 18The Protes tant Federation of France has published a statement calling the capitalist system and its ideology unacceptable and urging Christians to fight the status quo either by bold re formism or revolutionary op position.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE eDITOR: It seems that the same in dividual who helped destroy the 7:30 curtain in 1969 is trying to repeat the deed in 1971. The theater should pay attention to the theatergoers, not the restaurant lobby.

title: Chess
description: THE sunny Caribbean island of Puerto Rico has become increas ingly familiar to New Yorkers in recent years as a holiday resort a pleasant place in which to escape the rat race for the space of a long week end. It has also by this time replaced Niagara Falls as the in spot for honey moons.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 18  An Israeli Army spokesman de clined to comment tonight on the Syrian report of a troop buildup on the Golan heights and the imminence of an Israeli attack.

title: The World
description: The scene; stately St. Paul's Ca thedral in London. The time last Sun day night. The occasion: a celebration of Holy Communion.

title: Stamps
description: BANGLA DESH, it Ben gal nation, may rise out of the ashes and blood and terror of the IndiaPakistan War. If it does, the eight labels re leased last July 29 are likely to be recognized as the first definitive issue of the new nation, although there were earlier overprinted Bangle Desh stamps on Pakistan is sues.

title: Education
description: Violence in schools, which has reached crisis proportions in some American cities, is also on the rise in traditionally less violent Britain, a report showed last week.

title: Florida and Dartmouth Fives Triumph at the Garden and Remain Undefeated
description: The Dartmouth backcourt of Bill Raynor and James Brown wrecked Seton Hall yesterday in the first game of a college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden. They hit for 48 points as the un beaten Indians defeated Seton Hall, 9382, for their fourth victory.

title: Et Al.
description: A thorough survey of gospel singing, with attention to the relationship between gospel and other black musical forms in America such as jazz and rhythm & blues. The charac terizations of performers and the insulated world of the gos pel church are particularly well done. Unfortunately, Heilbut slights the sociological impli cations, which would have broadened the significance of his study considerably.

title: Super Day for New Breed
description: DALLAS, Dec. 18 (AP)Six boys ages 8 to 13 earned their Super Bowl tickets today at Texas Stadium. The boys won their age groups in divisional competition of Punt, Pass and Kick, a national program spon sored by the Ford dealers of America and the National Foot ball League.

title: Education
description: With inflation hitting the stu dent's pocketbook, the trend in higher education is toward the publicly supported colleges and universities. This has forced the private institutions into an increas ingly tighter fiscal bind, a problem that has prompted much study and investigation.

title: The Nation
description: The Nation

title: Yonkers Sale Lures a Big Crowd And $30,500 Bid For Steady Boy
description: YONKERS, Dec. 18The pre fabricated, heated arena, which was built to accommodate about 1,200 persons at the Old Glory horse sales held two or three times each year at Yon kers Raceway, attracted more than twice that number at to day's winter offering.

title: A Cottage for Those Who Get Their Kicks Seven Fathoms Down
description: FREEPORT, Grand Bakama Island Off this island's town of Lu caya is a cozy little cottage with room for four. It sits in a valley of white sand surrounded by liv ing coral and it happens to be 40 feet below the surface of the sea.

title: Living With Devalution
description: COLUMBUS, Ind.Here in America's heartland, with the flat Indiana farmland stretching out mile after mile under gray and wintry skies, the supercharged world of international monetary crisis and negotiation seemed very far away last week.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONA year ago there was reported in this column what seemed to many people here a promis ing and constructive idea. It has in good part crumbled. That should be reported, too.

title: Vandals Halt Phone Service
description: BREWSTER, N.Y., Dec. 18 (AP)Vandals knocked out virtually all but local telephone service for the hamlet of Pat terson, N. Y., today, the New York Telephone Company, said. Robbert Pugliese, a spokes man for the company, said that a polemounted repeater box four miles north of there on Route 22 was seriously damaged by an obvious act of vandalism at about 8 A.M.

title: Anderson Five Bows
description: COVINGTON, Ky., Dec. 18 (AP)  Marvin Johnson scored 22 points and Jim MacMillan had 15 points and 23 rebounds today to lead Northern Ken tucky to an 8074 victory over Anderson College or Indiana.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Book, music, lyrics by Melvin Van Peebles. I saw the opening of flint Sup posed to Die a Natural Death and said it couldn't be done. It could be and it was. This is a masterpiece of ferocious theater that sticks to your skin and won't come off.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: While reading Anne Tolstoi Foster's article on Ad Lib (Nov. 28), I had the uncom fortable feeling that I was sneaking a look at a confi dential interoffice memo, rather than something meant for general public consump tion. Although I agree that greater and longerlasting so cial progress is made not by appealing to people's good ness but to their selfinter est (rehabilitate inner cities not because human souls are being crushed there, but be cause we might all bo done in if we don't), Mrs. Foster's application of this truism to Madison Avenue is not in the namo of social progress; it is, at best, more of the same and, at worst, regression.

title: Music for a Moroccan Pan
description: BRIAN JONES presents the Pipes of Pan at Jou jouka (Rolling Stones) Coo 49100). The tiny Moroccan village of Joujouka, in the Jebel or little hills not far from Tangier, fascinated the late Brian Jones, a charter member of the Rolling Stories. The village is the home of Morocco's Master Musicians, who were for centuries court musicians to the sultans of Marrakesh and Fez, and who play at certain times of year for a ritual which may be the last survival of the rites of Pan. The Pan Music is unlike anything on earth, and in 1968 Jones, along with re cording engineer George Chkiantz and painternovelist Brion Gysin, visited Joujouka and taped approximately a dozen Moroccan musicians on a portable Uher. Jones spent months, and a small fortune, mixing and editing the tapes into album form.

title: College Football
description: Record crowds and income weren't sufficient to balance increasing costs, so athletic directors spent a restless fiscal season while their coaches and players tried to defend against the increasing success of the wishbone offense on the field. There is no quick solution to the money problems in college football, but it may be just a matter of time be fore defenses catch up with that tricky fouroption offense started by Texas and used so successfully this year by Alabama, Oklahoma and others.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Most Japanese still feel that high rates of growth are the foundation of Japan's prosperity and power.

title: The heart surgeon has his reasons
description: Heart surgeons, or heart cutters as they seem to be known to each other, are practitioners of a particu larly mysterious and admirable set of skills. They know how to do things that are beyond the imaginings of people who aren't doctors, and what they do is so peculiarly connected with life and death they have an aura, even in their profession. The most daring and glamorous of all were the transplanters who, while the operation was in vogue in 1968 and 1969, presumed to take the heart from the body of an allegedly dead person and make it beat in the chest of somebody else who would die without it but perhaps not so quickly.

title: United Parcel Van Hijacked
description: A United Parcel Service van was hijacked in the Bronx yesterday by three men who drove the driver around the borough for two hours before releasing him unharmed, the police said. The men ap proached the driver, Melvin Carter, 30 years old, at 176th Street and Park Avenue. Two hours later the truck was found outside 555 Hutchinson River Parkway with half of its cargo. Detectives of the Bathgate Pre cinct said the cargo's value had not been determined.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: As one who is closely as sociated with the travel in dustry, arid with black travel agents particularly, I should like to commend the objec tivity of Stanley Carr's Why the Black Travel Agent's Clients Want to Travel First Class (Travel section, Nov. 28) and the manner in which the article was presented. This type of reporting is what is needed, and I wish we had more of it in the ghetto communities around the country.

title: U.S. NAVY CAPTAIN SEEKS VINDICATION
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 18A senior Navy captain has been relieved of his command of a highly classified American com munications base in Australia and returned to the United States for a medical evalua tion and a review of charges that he jeopardized friendly AmericanAustralian relations.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: John is the unknown brother; he works for a liv ing, an acquaintance quipped.

title: Et Al.
description: Joan Comay's Who's Who in the Old Testament: Togeth er with the Apocrypha and Ronald Brownrigg's Who's Who in the New Testament offer considerably more than the usual barebone statistics of a Who's Who. These hand somely printed, profusely illus trated volumes tell what is known about literally thou sands of Biblical individuals, ranging from a few lines for littleknown persons to several pages for such major figures as Abraham, Moses, Solomon, John the Baptist, Mary (mother of Jesus) and Paul. The illus trations, many in color, are varied in subject matter, me dium and provenancehistory, tradition, archeology, geog raphy and the Biblical text are all revealed. Mrs. Comay is the wife of an Israeli Ambas sador and the author of a number of books on Israel. Mr. Brownrigg is the British author (with Christopher Hollis) of Holy Places; he has written widely on the Middle East. Both volumes can be highly rec ommended to the general read er for pictorial and textual ex cellence.

title: Nixon Said to Be Gratified At Support of Conservatives
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) The White House expressed gratitude today for the support President Nixon enjoys from such prominent conservatives as Senators Barry Goldwater of Arizona and John G. Tower of Texas.

title: Livingston College Committee Stirs Debate by Its Proposal for MinorityGroup Evaluations of Faculty
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 18A faculty committee at Livingston College has stirred up a campus controver sy here by its attempts to de vise a method of determining how well a candidate for faculty appointment or tenure has related to minority groups.

title: CORNELL INQUIRY ON DISPUTE ENDS
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 18A fiveman Cornell University committee disclosed today it had completed its investigation of grievances that led to dis putes between black players and the coaching staff of the varsity basketball team.

title: Big Board at L.I.R.R. Lights Up Track Trouble
description: There are 5,700 different reasons why a Long Island Rail Road electric train may malfunction, according to a statement issued a while ago by the line.

title: Auto Racing
description: For racing teams and promoters it was another year of economic pinch. Some sponsors quit because of the re cession; others found more profitable ways of spending money. Thus, the Questor Corporation decided against sponsoring a west ern edition of the United States Grand Prix; Johnson Wax stopped sponsoring the CanAm after six years; Chrysler, last of the major auto manufacturers in stockcar racing, dropped out for 1972.

title: Tvardovsky, Liberal Soviet Editor, Dies
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 18Alek sandr T. Tvardovsky, one of the Soviet Union's most prominent poets and long a symbol of the struggle for creative freedom here, has died at the age of 61.

title: Parun Beats Fort of U.S. In New Zealand Tennis
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 18 (AP)  Onny Parun, New Zealand's Davis Cup play er, defeated John Fort of Santa Monica, Calif., 6.4, 6.1, 64, today in a semifinal of the Wellington tennis champion ships.

title: Reader's Report
description: Fly Away Home passes the acid test of introspective fic tion: the protagonist is as in teresting to the reader as to himself. Or herself., as happens to be the case here, since the keeper of this twoyear journal (19661968) is a young English woman taking her psyche apart with the precision and control of a fine clockmaker. Even tually, (Mrs.) Antonia Boileau is able to put her life back to gether  an act that requires the greatest selfknowledge of all.

title: Unsheltered City Kids Held Able to Confront Problems of World
description: In light of the hazards that exist concerning the availability of drugs, the prevalence of de linquency, and pressures by youngsters that represent de structive human values, I cannot easily accept the idea that sub urbia is the place to raise your child.

title: McCloskey Asserts Nixon Shuns SmallBusiness Man
description: ROCHESTER, N. H., Dec. 18 (AP)Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., Republican of California, criticized the Nixon Administration here today for what he called its failure to give sufficient support to the smallbusiness man.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Israel Shenker's article on the Unit ed Nations struggle to define aggres sion (Dec. 9) is a perceptive analysis. He discloses that although the United States and Britain have submitted a draft definition they nevertheless con sider the exercise absolute nonsense.

title: The Mission to Peking
description: WASHINGTONIn the nineteen twenties, I was in Peking as a U.S. Marine. A uniform (which in my case was that of a private first class) was just about all that was needed to in sure a respectful welcome. Much more is required these days. Indeed, it has taken a complex synchronization of developments and very careful plan ning to underwrite the reception which President Nixon will receive next year in the ancient Chinese capital.

title: HEARD'S 73 FOR 217 LEADS RABAT GOLF
description: RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 18 (UPI)  American golfers ad apted so neatly to the new Roy al Rabat golf course that they settled into the first four places of the $50,000 Moroccan Inter national Grand Prix.

title: Reader's Report
description: Leonard Wibberly, specialist in the vestpocket parable, speculates on the ultimate real ity in this atmospheric sliver of a novel. The setting is equa torial Africa, where the nar rator doomed by cancer goes to expend his final days in an ele phant hunt. The elephant he pursues is an immense and an cient pachyderm, probably a hundred years old. (Nobody knows the lifespan of an ele phant.) But when he finally tracks down this legendary brute, he finds that, by an ex ternal circumstance, the hunted is as doomed as the hunter. Mr. Wibberly equates the mys tique of the chase with the mystery of death in a story that winds its way through some intriguing geography.

title: Swimming
description: In the preOlympic year of 1971, American swimmers were the best in the world.

title: Home Improvement
description: IN LINE with the general trend toward the return of the natural look in home interiors, there has been a great increase in the popularity of, hardwood floor ing in recent yearsafter a period of years in which other types of flooring in creasingly dominated the res idential market.

title: Son to Mrs. Phillips
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. James W. Phillips of Warrensville Heights, Ohio, on Nov. 27 in Mac Donald House, University Hospital, Cleveland.

title: The World
description: When Jordanian Premier Wasfi Tal was assassinated as he entered a Cairo hotel some weeks ago, four young men arrested for the killing admitted mem bership in the Black September Movement, described as a loose and more or less ad hoc association of young Palestinians with just one aim revenge against the prominent Jor danians responsible for crushing the Palestine guerrilla movement in Sep tember, 1970. Reports circulated in London that the Black September group had condemned to death 15 leading Jordanians, with Mr. Tal first on the list.

title: Peking Charges Indians Annexed East Pakistan
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 18 Peking said today that the Indian occupation of Dacca represented annexing East Pakistan with armed forces.

title: Reader's Report
description: In a Teutonic climate as mas sively sinister as the forest of the Eel King, Elliott Arnold spins a tale of neoNazis that keeps the reader hanging on every hairpin turn of the plot. No tiresome stereotypes here, thank Heavenno heelclicking Prussians or clumsy Fascists out of pop melodrama. The au thor's atavistic conspirators are camouflaged to present a low profile against the luxuriant Bavarian landscape, making them all the more plausible and threatening. Their habitat is the ancient city of Wurzburg, to which the hero goes in quest of the particulars of his moth er's death. Peter Bauer is a German Jew who had been spirited out of Germany as a youth, and who joined the R.A.F. His return to his native city triggers a sequence of harsh memories and ominous possibilities.

title: Skiing
description: It was the same old story. Europeans again dominated the World Cup scene last winter. Gustavo Thoeni, the 20year old from Italy, won the men's title while 18yearold AnneMarie Proell of Austria, headed the women. Barbara Cochran of Rich mond, Vt., was the only American to finish higher than 10th in the international competition's threeevent standings. She placed eighth. Her older sister, Marilyn, trailed in 11th.

title: Vasquez Guides Amasport to HalfLength Triumph in Handicap at Tropical
description: MIAMI, Dec. 18If there is any one element in horse racing that is consistent, it is incon sistency. In today's seventh race at Tropical. Park, Places Please was a 105 favorite, the shortest price horse in memory at this track.

title: The Last Word: Show Biz and Serious Biz
description: With Thirty Years of Treason, reviewed last week in these pages by Victor Navasky, Eric Bentley has given us an absorbing but troubling book He has edited the history of the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities down to a harle quinade, condensing three decades and hundreds of thousands of pages of witness, entreaty, indignation, defamation and groveling to a single volume. Because he is a Brecht scholar, drama critic and professor of dramatic literature, Mr. Bentley's habit of mind is theatricalas, indeed, were the habits of H.C.U.A.  and it is natural that he should emphasize the theatrical elements of his material. Thus there is much about the Hollywood 10 (screenwriters, movie stars: show biz) and nothing about Alger Hiss (serious biz), lots of drama and not much tragedy. Instead of catharsis, emeticjust like the Living Theatre. Our past is perceived to be a sort of metaphysical pratfall. We laugh at it.

title: Catchitig Lenny
description: CATCH him first in September on the wing just a week before his new Mass is to inaugurate Washington's immense effort at cul tural piety, the Kennedy Center. He is stalking East 79th Street, heading toward a favorite Chinese restau rant in the neighborhood, surrounded by a corps of faithful attendants and collaborators on the new project, all of whom must run to keep up with him. The name is Bernstein, the browned, bony, fatigued face an in stant signal of celebrity to the bour geoisie who pass him on the street, then turn with a quick, pleased half  smile of recognition. It's him, they seem to say, really him, still our boychick, still our Wunderkind, our baby, despite the accumulation of 53 years, despite the agonies of radical chic and the notoriety as well, for which he was publicly booed on one occasion, despite the retirement from the Philharmonic podium, it's him, our very own Lenny.

title: Villanova Wins, 9966
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 (AP)  Villanova raced to a 24.2 lead and went on to crush North Dakota State, 9966, to night.

title: TaxExempts Tarnishing?
description: The riskiness of taxexempt bonds is being evaluated dif ferently now.

title: U.S. Withdraws a Subpoena Ordering Reporter to Testify
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 18 (AP)  Federal officials have with drawn a subpoena ordering John Bell, a reporter for The Seattle Times, to appear before a grand jury in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, to testify about a rock festival.

title: Music: Opera? The Music Is the Message
description: THE Metropolitan Op era had a mighty hit on its hands with its new production of Wagner's Tristan und Isolde. Every performance was sold out (the seventh and last took place yester day afternoon), and tickets were as hard to come by as a pair of ducats for a foot ball game. Much of the busi ness of this office the pastphone in conversations that went something like Hey, old chap? Remember me? You don't?  That time nine years ago on the flight to Los Angeles?  Still drinking double Scotches, heh, heh?  Just thought I'd call you up and say hello  Er, about that Tristan

title: YAHYA DENOUNCED
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 18President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan today asked Zulfi kar Ali Bhutto, the Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, to return immediately from the United States to form a new government.

title: MEXICO ATTRACTS DISABLED U.S. VETS
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico, Dec. 12At 79 years of age, Charlie Munson is the oldest of the ailing or disabled veterans from the United States, who live here. Fiftysix years ago he served in Gen. John J. Persh ing's punitive expedition into Mexico in pursuit of Pancho Villa.

title: Pheasant familymstyle
description: Some misguided streak of asceticism in the American character has assigned the pheasant to an elite, unapproachable luxury status. Hunters know better. And cooks who can add should be able to figure out that veal scaloppine costs more per portion than these game birds. There is, moreover, no need to serve them under glass with truffles. Their meat has more personality than chicken and holds its own very well in a simple recipe. Take, for example, the utterly simple pheasant and sourcream recipe at the right. It is slightly expanded from Escoffier's bible of haute cuisine and takes roughly an hour to complete. Giobbi's way with pheasant calls for more ingredients and more seasonings. It is from his new book, Italian Family Cooking.

title: RAMS, 49ERS EACH SEEKING PLAYOFF
description: The final spot in the National Football League's playoffs will be filled today by either the San Francisco 49ers or Los Angeles Rams, separated by half a game in the race for the Western Division title in the National Conference.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Tom Wicker in his column of Dec. 7 entitled Poll Watching says that re cent polls showing a 29 per cent preference among Democrats for Sen ator Edward Kennedy's Presidential candidacy are not impressive consider ing his heritage and personal glamor.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: For cigarette marketing men this first year without broadcast advertising has been a year of experimenta tion which is not over. For the other media it has been newfound gold. For the cigarette ad agencies it has been lost billings. And for the smoking public it has been increased consumption.

title: Sizerl Enclosed totl cost I at 65.00 per cent Nam, I
description: Miss Irene Elizabeth Wylie was married here yesterday morning to Daniel Tracy Rodgers. The Rev. John Crocker Jr. performed the ceremony in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd of the General Theological Semi nary.

title: DEMOCRATS SHOW AN ACRID DISUNITY
description: ALBANY, Dec. 18The Dem ocratic party advanced its reputation for disunity today with a searing, raucous reap portionment debate that was more internecine than anti Republican.

title: Choral Society Presents Joyous Sacred Works
description: Not all sacred music is solemn, and the New York Choral Society came up with three works in this field in its Philharmonic Hall concert on Friday night that were posi tively cheerful. One would ex pect the Glories of Vivaldi and Poulenc to have a bright ring, for these are hymns of praise. But Haydn's Missa solemnis in B flat (Harmoniernesse) is sometimes downright jolly.

title: Four Ranger Goals in Final Period Set Back Blues
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 18For 401 minutes tonight in the Arena, the New York Rangers played hockey as if they were still suffering shellshock from the lacing they absorbed in Boston two nights ago.

title: Paul Bartlett Weds Barbara E. Wells
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 Miss Barbara Emily Welles, daughter of Russell Welles of Darien, Conn., and Mrs. Anne Scoville Welles of Longboat Key, Fla., was married here today to Paul Holland Bart lett, son of Mrs. John Dallet of New York and the late Walter Bartlett. The Rev. Harry B. Schofield, a Unita rian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of John Fell Stevenson, son of the late Adlai E. Stevenson.

title: VARIETY OFFERED BY PAW TROUPE
description: The Mariano Parra Spanish Dance Companyan American group consisting of four danc ers, two guitarists, one pianist and one singer  works very well on the chamberconcert level. It has none or the polish and imagination of the ton ??? troupes. Yet one can be grateful for its careful avoid anoe of the commercialism that miss many of the minor en sembles.

title: NIXON HAILS PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The world's 10 leading non Communist industrial nations reached agreement tonight on a new pattern of currency ex change rates, including a de valuation of the United States dollar by 8.57 per cent.

title: Television
description: CABLE television is im portant. Just about everyone is agreed on that single point. Com munications is power, the modern theory goes, and its power may eventually replace that of even the dollar. Cable television, its present and fu ture, represents an entirely new communications com plex.

title: LAUB CAPTURE 24 IN ROW 132106
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 18 (AP) The Los Angeles Loiters over powered the Phoenix Suns in the second half to record their 24th consecutive National 13as ketball Association victory, 132.106 decision tonight.

title: the traveler's world
description: HERE is a deadly serious syllogism for the holiday season: Tis the season to be jolly; much holiday jollity involves mixing alcoholic beverages with motorists; therefore, it behooves us to think on the 25,000 traf fie deaths attributed annually to the in fusion of alcohol into motorists and pedestrians.

title: Demogines Wins in Midwest
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 18 (AP) Jim Demogines of the Broad moor (Colo.) Figure Skating Club won the'senior men's title at the Midwestern figure skat ing championships last night at the suburban Golden Valley Ice Center. He qualified, with other winners, for the national cham pionships.

title: Sato Welcomes Accord But Sees Serious Impact
description: TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 19  Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan said this morning that the revaluation of the yen would have a serious impact on the nation's economy but he expressed confidence that it would recover within a year.

title: Text of Nixon Statement
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18Following is the text of President Nixon's announcement tonight on the monetary accord:

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The article on Canyonlands National Park In Utah (Travel section, Oct. 31) raises the question of what develop ment, what concessions to creature comforts should be made in wilderness areas and the national park and forest system. For every area we close to development we im pose just that greater burden on those developed areas that serve the weekend adventur er. I am opposed to the no tion that hiking alone eating berries and talking to eagles is noble while riding a dime buggy across the desert is evil. Man is part of the en vironment and land kept from man is just as artificial as our urban jungles.

title: Karen Holman Bride Of Houston Conwill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 In the New Bethel Baptist Church here this afternoon Miss Karen Holman and Houston Conwill, juniors at Howard University, were married by the Rev. Walter L. Fauntroy.

title: Where shattered lives can be rebuilt
description: John G. is 49. Fifteen years ago, while out cycling with his children, Frank then 7, and Elizabeth, 5, he lost control of his bicycle and crashed into a ditch. When he regained con sciousness, he was unable to speak and his legs were permanently paralyzed.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The first cluck hunting blind I ever had was the packing crate that brought my aunt's new piano to Martha's Vineyard.

title: Christmas in Queens Village: Shopping and politicking
description: This time of year, when the red, white and green lights arch over Jamaica Ave nue near Springfield Boule vard and store windows glit ter with tinsel, the word Vil lage in Queens Village seems particularly appropriate.

title: Grey Guard, on Late Rush, Captures Christmas Purse
description: PAWTUCKET, R. L, Dec. 18 (AP) After trailing six rivals for more than halfamile. Grey Guard finished with a charge and won the 4,000 Merry Christ mas Purse today at Narragan sett Park.

title: PACT ENCOURAGES BUSINESS EXPERTS
description: Economists, bankers and businessmen, all of whom have been closely following the in ternational monetary discus sions of the Group of 10 in Washington, were much en couraged by the agreement an nounced last night.

title: John R. Gordon Plans to Marry Miss Lardner
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 18 The engagement of Miss Melissa Bedford Lardner to John Housmaniere Gordon has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Lynford Lardner Jr., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Albert H. Gordon, board chairman of Kidder, Peabody & Co., investment bankers, and Mrs. Gordon of New York.

title: Kenneth Paul Morse Marries Miss Joan Harney in Bay State
description: ANDOVER, Mass., Dec. 18 Miss Joan Waugh Harney was married here this after noon to Kenneth Paul Morse. The Rev. Joseph Edison Pike performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Child for the Wags
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Norman Torrey Waag of 141 East 88th Street on Nov. 21 in the New York Hospital.

title: Squires Beat Condors
description: NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 18 (AP) The Virginia Squires, led by Charlie Scott and Julius Erving, built a 17point lead early in the second half tonight, then held off the Pittsburgh Con dors for a 134124 victory.

title: Jolters Meet Chiefs Today In Roller Derby at Garden
description: Ann Calvello, one of Roller Derby's brightest stars, will make her first New York ap pearance of the season today at Madison Square Garden. She will lead the Jolters against the Chiefs, the Garden's team. Game time is 1 P.M.

title: Freezing Weather And Icy Gusts End City's Warm Spell
description: New Yorkers bundled up yes terday and store windows were starfrosted as cold weather settled into the city after two days of unseasonably high tem peratures.

title: Impatience Over Phase 2 Expressed by Humphrey
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 18 (AP) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, voiced impatience today with the sec ond phase of President Nixon's wageprice controls. He urged more action to fight inflation and unemployment and to in crease consumer confidence.

title: Post Downs Hunter, 8074
description: GREENVALE, L. I., Dec. 18 C. W. Post, led by Ed Miller's 19 points, defeated Hunter, 8074, tonight. Miller scored 11 points in the second half as Post came back from a 5352 deficit with 10 minutes re maining.

title: Now It's Lavender, Blue
description: DENVER, Dec. 18 (AP)The Denver Spurs said today that Brian Lavender, the club's fourthleading scorer, has been recalled by the St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League. Lavender had appeared in 26 games and had 13 goals and 14 assists.

title: News of Dogs
description: For the first time in its 87 years, the American Kennel Club will have a chairman of the board. At the quarterly meeting of the organization last Tuesday, 160 delegates voted unanimously for the move.

title: Mrs. Juceam Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Juceam of Manhasset, L. I., on Dec. 8 at the LyingIn Hospital here. Mrs. Juceam, known profes sionally as Dr. Eleanor Pam, is executive assistant to the president and associate dean of Queensborough Communi ty College, City University. Her husband is a lawyer with Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson. The child has been named Daniel James.

title: Francoise Macchi of France Wins Slalom Race and Takes Lead in World Cup
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Dec. 18 (AP)  Frangoise Macchi of France regained her touch to day, dominated the women's slalom race and took the lead in skiing's 1972 World Cup.

title: INJURIES WIPE OUT SUPER BOWL HOPE
description: When the Jets conclude to day's game at Shea Stadium with Cincinnati, many of the players who don't live in the area will scatter immediately for home. Others will linger a little longeruntil tomorrow morning perhaps.

title: 3 DEMOCRATS FAIL TO REACH ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Representatives of three lib eral Democratic Presidential candidates met for a second time this week, and they came away feeling that they had very limited room to cooperate during the campaign.

title: IndiaPakistan
description: NEW DELHIWe hail the people of Bangladesh and their hour of tri umph. Thirteen days and some 10,000 Indian casualties in dead, wounded and missing after she accepted the gamble of allout war, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi stood before Parliament last Thursday to announce as com plete a victory as she could have wished for.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: It's a crying shame the way the critics all used a song in the show Aint Sup posed to Die a Natural Death called Put a Curse on You as a point of de parture to pan the show in general. am sure that when these same gentlemen go to church and hear the pastor denounce sinners, they assume he is referring to their neighbors, and do not feel personally affronted.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The driveaway cars article evoked memories of a fortui tous experience my husband and I had during an other wise dreadful trip to Florida a few years ago. Our three yearold car, a lemon from the start, was brought to a final stop on the Tamiami Trail by an undiagnosed mal function. It could be repaired, we were told, for $450. We decided to sell the car and rent one for the return to New York. The Hertz people told us they were looking for drivers to take their cars north (it was May) and that we need pay only $6 insur ance. They would pay for the gas and oil and allow us 1,600 miles and eight days to deliver the car to New York. That was 250 miles and four days more than we needed so we had a car to use while still in Florida.

title: Israel Weighs Claims of Two Russian Churches
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 18Sit ting in his ornate parlor under formal portraits of Czar Nich olas II and Empress Alexan qa, the bearded Archiman drlte gestured theatrically.

title: Pro Football
description: Two reasons illustrate why pro foot ball's Super Bowl will be played in New Orleans on Jan. 16 rather than at Miami or Dallas, which also bid for the game the sport's current status on the levels of competition and litigation. The owners of the 26 teams chose New Orleans at their annual meeting in Palm Beach, Fla., last March because the Miami Dolphins and Dallas Cowboys were very good teams and one or the other might wind up playing in the Super Bowl, thereby enjoying the un fair advantages of home field, home cooking and home fans. That would be too much.

title: About Motor Sports
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Dec. 18Besides his many other attributes, Mark Dono hue has gall. Quite frankly, he says, I've never seen a stockcar race. And what is he getting into? Stock car racing. Born in New Jersey and educated at Brown Univ ersity in Rhode Island, Denohue has not quite got the hang of Southern dialect. Yesterday Dono hue asked his mechanic a question and he got an unintell igible answer. I found out, Donohue explains. That is, I found out not to ask any more. Donohue has learned though, that the word tires is pronounced tars  he says the i is silent like the q in billiards.

title: Sponsor Change Helped Put U.S. Controls on Rents
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 As the House was debating legislation extending the Pres ident's powers to control wages and prices the other day, Representative Bella S. Abzug, Democrat of Manhat tan, walked over to the cleric's desk, scratched out her name as sponsor of a waiting amendment and wrote in the name of Representative Frank J. Brasco, Democrat of Brook lyn.

title: Farmers, Unhappy With. Administration, Falling Income and Rising Costs, Are Wooed by 1972 Aspirants
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 18 Though it grows smaller by the day, the farm vote is shap ing up as particularly impor tant in next year's Presidential election.

title: GALLUP FINDS WAR DECLINES AS ISSUE
description: Concern about the Vietnam war has declined sharply among the American people, the Gal lup Poll reported yesterday.

title: F.D.A. Is Accused of Laxity On Artificial Food Coloring
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Three consumer groups have accused the Food and Drug Ad ministration of allowing pro ducers to use artificial coloring in food without advising the buyer.

title: Soccer
description: Major league soccer expanded to Montreal and Toronto and returned to Yankee Stadium, but lost Minns City in 1971. The eight franchises started the year at 20 below zero financially. They finished at zero, but the caliber of play showed im provement, especial ly in Dallas, Atlanta, and St. Louis. The fact that Dallas won the final North American Soccer League playoff from Atlanta, plus the fact that Dallas in creased its attendance by 60 per cent, showed that the drive toward the Amer icanization of the sport, had, at least partly, worked.

title: Cowboys Make Ticket Plans
description: DALLAS, Dec. 18 (AP) Tickets for the National Foot ball Conference championship game on Jan. 2should it be played herewill go on sale Dec. 26 at 7 A.M. at Moody Coliseum on the Southern Meth odist campus. All tickets are $12 and there will be a limit of four to a person.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONNot how he played the game, but whether he won or lost that was the question in the minds of politicians here last week as the first session of the 92d Congress end ed. To use the yardstick most in vogue among his coterie, has President Nixon's performance with Congress helped him politically? And as minority President, what course must he follow in the election year ahead to hold together his own party while preempting as much as possible the thunder of his Democratic opponents?

title: Palmer: Deeds Will Live On
description: LATROBE, Pa., Dec. 18 (UPI)Arnold Palmer said to day that Bobby Jones's accom plishments will live on for ever.

title: Ctoins
description: NEW YORK CITY and New York State will be among the first in the nation to have official medals marking the 200th anniversary of Amer ican Independence. Two con tests to select suitable de signs for the medallions were announced by city and state officials at a recent confer ence in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Court Says Miranda Ruling Doesn't Cover Minor Crime
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 18 (Reuters)The Iowa Supreme Court has ruled that persons arrested for minor crimes do not have to be advised of their rights.

title: News of The Camera WOrld
description: THE Miranda Auto Sensorex EE recently introduced by Allied Impex Corporation, 168 Glen Cove Road, Carle Place, N. Y. 11514, is an easy tohandle fully automatic 35mm single lens reflex cam era that sets the aperture (f/opening) automatically after the user sets the shutter speed that will best suit the amount of action in the scene. Thus, as the action shifts from a blight area to a shaded area, the camera's metering system will auttmatically compensate by changing the aperture to match the light.

title: Cargo Flights Are Predicted For LighterThanAir Craft
description: LONDON, Dec. 18 (Reuters) Fleets of lighterthanair craft will soon be ferrying cargo across the Atlantic at costs one third cheaper than those of con ventional air freight, according to a British reference authority on cargo transport.

title: Dog Shows
description: A birthday gift to Dr. Milton E. Prickett, an English springer spaniel he never intended to show, was the top show dog in America in 1971. Even more, Ch. Chinoe's Adamant James, or D.J., as he is more familiarly known, made canine history, with 47 top awards in one year. The previ ous record for all breeds (45) was held by his sire, Ch. Salilyn's Aristocrat. Included among D.J.'s victories was the triple crown Westminster (3,031 dogs), Chicago In ternational (3,638) and Beverly Hills (3,062).

title: Jesse Jackson Forms New Black Group for Economic and Political Action
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 18The Rev. Jesse L., Jackson, addressing some 4,000 cheering blacks, announced today the founding of a new organization for eco nomic development and poli tical action.

title: Thant Given Peace Award
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., De cember 18 (UPI)Representa tive Bella Abzug. Democrat of Manhattan, presented Secretary General U Thant of The United Nations today with a peace scroll and dove emblem on be half of Women Strike for Peace. Mr. Thant was given the award for his unceasing service to world peace at ceremony held in the General Assembly Building.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Have a Very Merry Christmas holiday and good harvests and flowers in the New Year.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Priceproductionquality control. These are the things that count in a children's dress company that makes unbranded merchandise for chains and budget depart ments.

title: Storm Trysail Club Modifies Two Parts of Its Ratin Limitation
description: Modifications of the Interna tional Offshore Rule, which wereproposed by the Storm Trysail Club last month for its own sailing regattas, were slightly affected by the recently announced changes in the I.O.R. (Mark III). New Storm Trysail alterations were announced this week with only two parts of the proposed rule revised.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: IF Arthur Parris's reply to Harold Schonberg's arti cle about good and bad music reflects his uni versity teaching, I am sorry for his students at Ypsilanti. He asks whether a Bach cantata should be considered commercial music. The answer is no: Bach wrote his music as part of his duties as a director of music, and for the glory of Almighty God.
