Commercial music is written or improvised (the mode of transmission is of little Importance) by decom posers as part of their duties as corrupters of public taste, and for the glory of the Al mighty Dollar. Billions of these necessary monetary units are being sucked from the pockets of world youth, year in and year out, in ex change for live or recorded nonmusie which the Greek philosophers would immedi ately recognize as capable of exerting immoral influences on everyone, especially the young.

title: Some old Greek routines
description: Voltaire claimed that Dante would be a classic forever because nobody read him. Until recently, this was literally true of Menander. Ancient scholars revered him, but through the years his plays vanished, and all that remained were snippets quoted by grammarians. Thus, when Goethe apostrophized the unattainable charm of Menander, it was solely on the basis of a collection of aphor isms. In the 19th century, George Meredith had no more on which to justify admitting only Menander and Moliere to the empyrean of comic writers. Of course, there were the Roman adaptations of Plautus and Terence, but this was hardly the same as having a real play or even a complete scene by Menander himself. He seemed destined to remain an unattainable classic.

title: To THE EDITOR
description: To THE EDITOR: Bravo to Rabbi Kahane. He said a mouthful. I've said the exact same things in about 50 to 70 letters to The Times over the past six yearsnone of which saw print. Which proves Kahane's theory. No one respects anything but strength and the prospect of the trouble your strength could cause. And trouble makes news. Now suddenly the views of nondocile Jews have become news that is fit to print by The Times.

title: Et Al.
description: A Yank in England. Gen. (then Col.) Raymond E. Lee was a military attach in Lon don during 194041. (He ar rived home on Dec. 7, 1941.) His job was to assess British defenses, weapons, morale, etc.; and most of his evalua tions proved to be right: he understood that the odds against a successful German invasion of England would go up as time went on. Lee, who died in 1958, was a literate and observant man. He knew Churchill and a passel of oth er dignitaries and in general Got Around. An interesting portrait of England under the Blitz.

title: 1971: A Year of Hits and NearHits
description: On a March evening in 1971, two men slugged each other earnestly for 45 minutes, and split a purse of $5 million. In May, a Venezuelan horse bred in Kentucky earned $282,900 for something less than four minutes work, sold in June for something more than $1million, and hasn't run since. Also in 1971, a MexicanAmerican golf hustler from the hardpan public links of El Paso set an alltime record by winning $231,000 but did not lead the money list.

title: The mental set of an elderly absolute monarch
description: This is not a traditional biography that tells a political narrative from the cradle to the grave, for it jumps about with studied disrespect for chronology. Nor is it a modern study in psychohistory on Eriksonian lines, for it says nothing whatever about the subject's childhood or adolescence and nothing much about his subse quent sexlife. It is rather a neo romantic essay on personality con veyed in a series of dazzling vignettes of the King in his later years, a probe into the mental set and the motiva tional drives of an elderly absolute monarch in the early 16thcentury. Very stylish, very mannered, some what idiosyncratic, it is controlled and illuminated by a wide knowledge of the primary sources, and driven forward by a vivid historical imagination. It makes a good deal more sense than some of, the interpre tations of Henry's character and policies that have been put forward recently by more sobersided histor ians.

title: Et Al.
description: Profusely illustrated survey of the Englishspeaking theater and some schools of drama that influenced it. Included is a special chapter on Russian theater (mainly because of Stanislaysky's importance), but virtually ignored is the French theater of Anouilh, Montherlant and Arrabal. The impact of Ionesco and Beckett gets only passing attention. On the whole, there's more nos talgia here than information.

title: The World
description: President Nixon put a comforting arm around the skipper's tearful wife at his Key Biscayne retreat Thursday and promised he'd do all in his power to get her husband back from cap tivity in Cuba. A few hours later, the State Department issued a tough statement saying the Government is prepared to take all measures under international law to protect U. S. citi zens and freedom of the seas.

title: Villagers in Pakistan Resentful
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 18It's peace but I cannot be happy about it, a sadfaced historian said when word of President Agha Mo hammad Yahya Khan's ac ceptance of the Indian cease fire proposal began to spread in this city.

title: Golf
description: Lee Trevino did a lot of ad libbing but he adhered to a victory script in winning three major 1971 golf cham pionships.

title: The World
description: Prince Philip started the row. He said a while back that unless the British Parliament came to the rescue, the Buckingham Palace budget would soon to be in the red. Then Queen Eliza abeth formally asked Parliament for an increase in the Civil List, the eu phemism for what the British pay their royalty.

title: The World
description: At a White House cocktail party recently, Paul Volcker, Under Secre tary of the Treasury for Monetary Af fairs, asked the president of a major company: What would be the public reaction to a devaluation of the dollar? Said the executive: 1 don't know anyone who gives a damn.

title: Museum ReCreates Past Living
description: Museum visitors generally swarm to the paintings and sculpture. The teaching of art has given us a hierarbhy that places aloft these two modes of esthetic expression. But there are a few and they are mostly in the know a few in the know who are aware of the power of period rooms.

title: Christmas Prices Up From Last Year
description: Phase Two and price sta bilization notwithstanding, the cost of Christmas cheer has gone up.

title: Impressive Impresario on L. I.
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. I. the result might possibly be If Sol Hurok were also Ar thur Miller and Joseph Papp and if this unlikely mixture were shipped to Long Island, Robert Bernstein.

title: Old Shoppes Fading as Forest Hills Gets With It
description: Behind this rather worn, conservative looking and ex tremely dignified facade there beats the heart of a swing ing youth.

title: Movies
description: NOW that novelist Mario Puzo has received hts cinematic bap tism with Paramount's version of The Godfather, he has de cided that what he really digs is being a scriptwriter. Following his efforts as scenarist on The Godfather due for release early next year Puzo has thrown himself into the penning of sequel, which he vows will not be called Son of Godfather. Once that's out of the way, he will begin rumbling on The Earthquake. based on a story idea by Sidney Beckerman, who will produce the film for Universal.

title: Editorial Cartoon 3  No Title
description: Editorial Cartoon 3  No Title

title: Wildlife Experts Call Call for 10Day Season on Deer on Long Island
description: According to state officials, deer once again are becom ing one of their own worse enemies on Long Island.

title: St. John's Drops Final, 110107
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Dec. 18Marshall University won its memorial invitation tourna ment tonight with a 110107 overtime triumph over eighth ranked St. John's before a capa city crowd of 6,500.

title: Music: A Mystery Piece by Brahms
description: The Beaux Arts Trio played a mystery work on its Hun ter College program at the Playhouse on Friday evening. On the program it was listed as Trio in A major (Op. posth) by Johannes Brahms. This caused some eyes to blink. Trio in A major? By Brahms? There ain't no such thing.

title: Royal Owl, Shoemaker Up, First In Race on Coast by 3 Lengths
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 18 (UPI)Royal Owl, one of the year's top 2yearolds, pulled away from his stablemate, D. B. Carm, on the stretch turn at Bay Meadows today and scored a 3length victory in the $108,400 California Juvenile Stakes.

title: 500,000 New Jobs Are Expected to Result in U.S. From the Monetary Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 The Administration believes that at least 500,000 new jobs will be created in this country as a result of the currency re valuation.

title: Charles T. Bruce, Poet And Canadian Press Aide
description: TORONTO, Dec. 19 (AP) Charles T. Bruce, novelist., poet, and journalist, died in his sleep at his home today. He was 65 years old.

title: Ukrainians Goalie Assists Blue Star To a 11 Stalemate
description: Although they played a team that used half its firststringers, the New York Ukrainians had to settle for a 11 tie with tslue Star yesterday in a German American Soccer League game at Metropolitan Oval in Mas peth, Queens.

title: Ford Fund Reports Grant of $680,000 For Urban Fellows
description: The Ford Foundation an nounced yesterday the award ing of a $680,000 grant for the thirdyear funding of the Na tional Urban Fellows program. The program is designed to in crease the number of minority group members in administra tive posts in state and local governments.

title: TRAVELERS MEETING NO MONETARY CRISIS
description: LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP)  Travelers in Europe with dol lars in their pockets found them suddenly worth a bit less today but seemed to have no trouble cashing them at the re duced rate.

title: GONORRHEA TESTS URGED FOR WOMEN
description: For the first time, the Pub lic Health Service is recom mending that doctors routine ly test women for gonorrhea as part of regular physical ex aminations. The aim is to help stem a rising epidemic of the venereal disease in this coun try.

title: Canadians Call Up Arnasson
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 19 (Cana dian Press)  The Montreal Canadiens called up Chuck Arnasson, a wing, from the Nova Scotia Voyageurs to re place Guy Lafleur, a rookie, who suffered a knee injury in Friday night's game against Vancouver.

title: DONALD C, M'GEACHIN
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Dec. 19Donald C. McGeachin, president of the Larchmont Federal Savings and Loan As sociation and former president of Witcombe & McGeachin, New York fabric converters, died here on Friday of a heart attack. He was 74 years old and lived at 113 Delancy Ave nue.

title: MONETARY FUND APPROVES WORLD CURRENCY MOVES;
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 The International Monetary Fund approved today the new pattern of exchange rates among the world's leading cur rencies.

title: Soviet Says Mars Signal Lasted 20 Seconds
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 19 The Soviet Union disclosed today that its space probe that made the first soft landing on Mars Dec. 2 transmitted television pictures for only 20 second's before contact suddenly ceased.

title: 32 ARE APPOINTED RHODES SCHOLARS
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Dec. 19Rhodes Scholarships for a minimum of two years study at Oxford University in Eng land were awarded today to 32 young American men from 21 colleges and universities.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The gross distortions of the letter How Slums Are Made (Dec. 10), unfortunately dramatized with a photo, should riot be allowed to go unchal lenged. The letter is riddled with untrue statements, such as the one that private capital can provide de cent housing for every income group. All homeseekers except the most affluent, every builder and every study group beginning with the Presidential Commission on Housing, know this to be completely false. The danger of the letter lies in that many of the condi tions cited are characteristic of the slums, but they are more often the result, not the cause, of the miserable living conditions.

title: Hard Line on Pay Inflation
description: After weeks of chipping away at its own antiinflation standards, the Pay Board has finally come up with rules designed to make evasion of wage controls much more difficult. Some element of flexibility is unquestionably needed to guard against unfairness in the administration pf wage controls, but when flexibility becomes a wide open door for oversize increases as it did in the board's early decisions both the credibility and the practicality of the antiinflation program are undermined.

title: Copter Corners 2 in Hijacking, Guided by Mark on. Truck Roof
description: The police used a helicop ter yesterday to track and seize at gunpoint a secretly marked truck that had been stolen from a New Jersey depot.

title: India Says Negotiations Await a New Regime in Pakistan
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 19  The western front between India and Pakistan remained quiet again today, on the second day of the ceasefire, as India awaited word from Rawalpindi on who would lead the Paki stani Government in negotia tions.

title: Eddie Standing Dies at 60; Squash Pro at Yale Club
description: Nathaniel Edward Standing, who as Eddie Standing had been squash professional at the Yale Club since 1928, died there Saturday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 60 years old and lived at 237 Elm Street, West Brighton, S.I.

title: CITYGETS$2.9MILLION AS REFUND ON DRUGS
description: A check for $2,966,063 was handed over to the city yes terday as its share of almost $100million in refunds from five major drug companies that had been accused of over charges.

title: After Six Years, Drive to Ban Torture Toys in California Is Successful
description: SAN DIEGOThis will be the last Christmas that California youngsters can expect Santa to bring them a toy guillotine, a battlefield strewn with hor ribly wounded soldiers or a doll that Screams when she is tortured by Frankenstein monster.

title: EDWIN M'NALLY
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 19  Ed win McNally, political cartoon ist for The Montreal Star since 1960, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Franklin Center, Quebec. He was 55 years old.

title: VOLCANO WORRIES WEST INDIAN ISLE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 19A restless West Indian volcano has local inhabitants worried and scientists baffled, accord ing to a volcanologist just back from St. Vincent Island where a 3,864foot peak shows signs of eruption.

title: Linda Wolfe Bride Of Dr. Max Pollack
description: The marriage of Miss Linda Wolfe, a contributing editor of New York magazine, to Dr. Max Pollack, a professor of psychology at Queens College and a psychologist with the Mental Health Ser vice of the Health Insurance Plan, took place here yester day. Rabbi Marshall Hurwitz performed the ceremony at the bride's apartment. Pre vious marriages for the couple ended in divorce.

title: PAPAL STATEMENT ON ULSTER URGED
description: ROME, Dec. 19  Appeals from Irelandand also from some Irish groups in the United Statesreaching the Vatican urge Pope Paul Vi to speak out on the civil strife in Ulster in his forthcoming Christmas mes sage.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: LAKELAND TAKES WORCESTER BEST
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 19 A grizzle and tan Lakeland terrier, Ch. Special Edition, owned by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Farrell Jr. of Darien, Conn., wound up the Eastern dog show season today on a winning note. He was named best of 1,507 dogs at the Worcester County Kennel Club show in the Memorial Auditorium.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The credentials offered by The Times on Graham MacKenzie Gordon [Dec. 7 letter The Case for VestPocket Hous ing] are impressive, but our experi ence with largescale development does not bear out his conclusions.

title: Her Home Is Also Her Studio And She's Very Happy About It
description: You would think that a person who helped establish embroidery as a na tional pastime through her books, kits and lectures would prefer the office in her apartment or her studio headquar ters as her base of operations.

title: Eban Receives Award Here
description: Abba Eban, Israel's Foreign Minister, was given the Judaism and World Peace Award last night by the Synagogue Council of America at the council's annual award dinner in the WaldorfAstoria.

title: M'CLENDON OF L.S.U. SPURNS RICH OFFER
description: EL PASO, Tex., Dec. 18 (UPI)  Charles Y. McClendon headed today for San Francis co, where he will coach the East squad in the Shrine Bowl, with his mind made up to stay as head football coach at Louisiana State.

title: SOPRANO LIMNS CHARM OF LIEDER
description: Judith Raskin Is one of the few American singers who cul tivate a truly idiomatic ap proach to German lieder. Her light soprano limits her choice somewhatsongs about elves, nightingales and abandoned maidens are bound to dominate as they did at her Tully Hall re cital yesterday afternoonbut within this special area she is a charming and intelligent in terpreter.

title: Screen: Whitney Series
description: Saturday marked the last new videotape program in the Whitney Museum's series that ends today with a re peat of an earlier batch. And how was it? Pretty good. Some of the stuff, about 10 minutes out of 90, was a knockout.

title: Leaders Personalities Are Classified
description: Minimum Man and Maximum Man appeared before the Ameri can Psychoanalytic Association meeting here yesterday, intro duced by Abraham Zaleznik, CahnersRabb Professor of So cial Psychology Management at the Harvard Business School.

title: Oilers Houston Steals Way to Record
description: Everyone knows that Tex ans do things in a big way, so it was only natural that Houston's Oilers should beat the San Diego Chargers, 4933, yesterday and that Ken Houston, a Houston safety, should set two Na tional Football League rec ords in the process.

title: City Hall Notes
description: Mayor Lindsay could take scant satisfaction from the resignation last week of the Democratic state chairman, John J. Burns, who already was serving as Mr. Lindsay's political envoy throughout the state and in dealings with other state chairmen across the nation. Richard R. Aurelio, manager of Mr. Lindsay's Presidential pre campaign, put the best face on the resignation when he promptly appointed Mr. Burns as national coordina tor of the Lindsay for Presi dent movement. He explained that Mr. Burns would have access to Democratic circles that might be suspicious of recent converts such as the Messrs. Lindsay and Aurelio.

title: Levitt Charges U.S. Workers Cheat City Oat of Income Tax
description: ALBANY, Dec. 19State Controller Arthur Levitt said today that thousands of Fed eral employes in New York City were apparently cheating the city of several million dol lars a year in unpaid city in come taxes.

title: Cambodian Bridge Blown
description: PNOMPEN1, Cambodia, Dec. 19 (AP)The Cambodian high command reported tonight that enemy forces had struck early today at one of Cambodia's supply lines, knocking out the Spean Slot Bridge on Route 1, 35 miles southeast of the Cam bodian capital.

title: Israeli General Is Pessimistic
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 19 (AP) Israel's military Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Haim BarLev, sug gested today that chances for peace in the Middle East were slightly more than zero and that the odds on war were even.

title: Chargers Will Keep Svare As Coach for Next Season
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 19 (AP) Harland Svare, interim head coach of the San Diego Chargers, was named head coach today following their 4933 loss to the Houston Oil ers in the season's finale for the two teams.

title: Ferd Schupp, ExPitcher; Set Season E.R.A. Mark
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 (AP) Ferdinand (Ferd) Schupp, former major league pitcher with a career record of 62 vic tories and 39 losses, died Thursday after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: HANOI CHALLENGES AIR POWER OF U.S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 19The American air war in Indochina has entered a new phase, with direct confronta tions between American and North Vietnamese planes.

title: HARVARD'S OARSMEN TRIUMPH IN EGYPT
description: LUXOR, Egypt, Dec. 19 (Reu ters) A Harvard University crew defeated eights from Ox ford and Cambridge Universities in a race on the River Nile at this ancient Egyptian capital today.

title: Now a 35Cent Fare What Comes Next?
description: The Governor's plan to hold the fare at 35 cents for two years is based on the use of $200 million of borrowed funds. The same money can keep the fare at 30 cents for one year. But what I find most troublesome is the absence of any program to contain the fare after the borrowed money runs out.

title: Dacca Reported Quiet
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 19  This city looked normal today after three days of euphoric celebration, punctu ated yesterday by grisly in cidents.

title: HUSSEIN DISMISSES HIS AIR FORCE CHIEF
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 19 King Hussein has removed his air force commander, Maj. Gen. Saleh alKurdi, in what diplo matic quarters here believe to be a quiet purge of the Jor danian armed forces.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Dec. 10 letter from Irwin M. Stelzer is astonishing. What world is he writing about? Surely not this one.

title: 49ers Subdue Lions, 3127, And Take N.F.C.West Title
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19 The San Francisco 49ers won the National Football Confer ence Western Division title and a playoff spot by defeating the Detroit Lions today, 3127, John Brodie passed for three touchdowns and ran for a fourth score.

title: Jets Win, Giants Lose
description: The regular pro football season ended yesterday with the Jets beating the Cin cinnati Bengals, 3521, and the Giants losing to the Philadelphia Eagles, 4128. The playoffs begin Saturday when Dallas faces the Vikings at Bloomington, Minn., and Miami plays the Chiefs at Kansas City. Details, Page 49.

title: PALMER IS VICTOR IN WORLD SKIING
description: SESTRIERE, Italy, Dec. 19 (AP)  Tyler Palmer, of Kear serge, N. H., posted the first triumph for the United States in the 1972 World Cup com petition today by winning the special slalom.

title: Seals Tie Canadiens
description: OAKLAND, Dec. 19 (AP) Wayne Carleton's 40foot slap shot early in the final period gave the California Golden Seals a 33 tie with the Mont real Canadiens tonight.

title: News Analysis
description: ALBANY, Dec. 19The veil of civility between Governor Rockefeller and Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea gets more diaphanous by the day as the two powerful Republicans near a test of wills a week from tomorrow.

title: Rabbi James G. Heller Is Dead; leader in Reform Judaism, 79
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 19The Rev. Dr. James G. Heller, eader in Reform Judaism, the Zionist movement and the Jnited Jewish Appeal and an Author and musician, died here today at the age of 79.

title: CAPTURED SKIPPER INJURED, CUBA SAYS
description: HAVANA, Dec. 19 (Reuters) The captain of the Panama nian freighter Johnny Express, attacked and captured by a Cuban Navy gunboat Wednes day in the Bahamas, was wounded slightly during the ac tion, the Cuban press said to day.

title: Foe Claims 4 Planes Downed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 19 (AP)  Military spokesmen disclosed today that American fighterbombers exchanged mis sile fire with antiaircraft de fenses deep inside North Viet nam yesterday.

title: Outgrowthof War: Major Loss Is Seen For U.S. Influence
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19The war that brought victory to India and dismember ment to Pakistan has profound ly damaged the moral influence and bigpower leverage of the United States in Asia, a survey by New York Times correspond ents in seven capitals and at the United Nations indicates.

title: I.R.A. Warns Lynch
description: DUBLIN, Dec. 19 (UPI) Both wings of the outlawed Irish Republican Army said to day that they would resist with force any legislative attempt to curtail their activities.

title: Buddhist Patriarch Dies In Thai Auto Accident
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 19 (UPI)Sorndej Phra Maha Vire wong, patriarch of Thailand's 30 million Buddhists, died yes terday of injuries suffered in a traffic accident. He was 73 years old.

title: Rickles's Resignation Expected Today
description: Robert N. Rickles, who has tilted with Mayor Lindsay, Governor Rockefeller, Consoli dated Edison, big business, landlords and the ubiquitous automobile in his 21 months as New York City's Commissioner of Air Resources, will resign his $35,000ayear post today, according to Lindsay adminis tration officials.

title: Pay Board May Clear Raises of 7% to 8%
description: The Pay Board may allow second and thirdyear wage increases in existing con tracts to go into effect with out challenge if they are within a range of 7 to per cent, according to one of the business members of the panel.

title: Johnson Plays Full Game As Giants Lose to Eagles
description: The football season came to an end in Yankee Staduim yes terday with the Philadelphia Eagles administering the coup de grace to the New York Giants with a 4128 victory.

title: JAMES E. DENNING, HEADED MCA UNIT
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 James E. Denning, president of MCA Technology, Inc., an MCA subsidiary that develops and markets communications equip ment, died Friday of a heart attack. He was 59 years old and lived here.

title: Six Killed in Bus Plunge
description: SARAGOSSA, Spain, Dec. 19 (Reuters)  A bus carrying about 50 Spanish workers and their families home for Christ mas from West Germany and Switzerland plunged off a bridge into the Ebro River here early today. At least six persons were killed and about 40 were in jured. Most of the passengers escaped through a rear exit.

title: Nation's Collegians Turning to Courses Keyed to Job Goals
description: BOSTON, Dec. 19Students at American colleges and uni versities are showing unusual interest this fall in courses of study that are closely keyed to vocational goals.

title: Jane Lee Callomon Wed to Leon Arkus
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 19 Miss Jane Lee Cailomon, vice president and creative direc tor of Lando, Inc., an ad vertising agency here, was married this afternoon to Leon Anthony Arkus, director of the Museum of Art at the Carnegie Institute.

title: Margaret L. Williams Is Married
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 19  Miss Margaret Lawrence Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mansfield Wiggin Williams, was married here this afternoon to Jack Hamil ton Prochison, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Prochison of Butler, Pa. The ceremony in the chapel of the First Pres byterian Church was per formed by the Rev. Donald M. Meisel.

title: Pep Rally at Penn State
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Dec. 19 (UPI)The Penn State foot ball squad returned to the campus today after a final examination break and held pep rally before beginning prac tice for its Cotton Bowl date with Texas Jan. 1.

title: Hawks Beat Royals, 10199
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 19 (AP) The Atlanta Hawks held off Cincinnati Royals rally tonight to record a 10199 victory.

title: S.E.C. Nears Policy Findings
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19The Securities and Exchange Com mission is expecting to reach its decisions by midJanuary on all of the broad issues it has under review concerning the future structure and regulation of the various stock markets.

title: HUGH REILLY
description: NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 19 Hugh Reilly, a former New York lawyer, died on Friday in Norwalk Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Wilton.

title: WISCONSIN BACKERS AND LINDSAY CONFER
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 19 Mayor Lindsay of New York met with Wisconsin supporters today to determine what kind of strength he would have if he entered the states Presi dential primary next April 5.

title: Personal Finance
description: Early retirements are be coming more popular. If that cannot be proved by obser vation of friends recently re tired, the word of the Confer ence Board can be taken.

title: Utah State Eleven Notches A Sizable Victory in Japan
description: TOKYO, Dec. 19. (AP)  Utah State, the first United States football team to visit Japan in 36 years, posted a 506 victory over the Japanese College AllStars today.

title: Rockets Strike Saigon
description: SAIGON, Monday, Dec. 20 (UPI)Two rockets struck the Saigon waterfront area early today in the first such guer rilla attack since the Presiden tial election Oct. 3.

title: Arts Abroad
description: PARISThe most exciting book to have appeared in France this fall is the two volume monument devoted by Louis Aragon to Henri Matisse. In a burst of sin cerity rather than singularity, he calls it a novel. Any resemblance between it and any, known brand of art history is in deed purely co incidental. This book resembles nothing except its own disorder, it drags through twentyseven years, writes Aragon. He met the painter in 1941, during the occupation of France by the Nazis, began to write about him almost at onceparts of the novel had been published earlier and has been writing about him ever since.

title: Soviet Accuses Israel of BuildUp in Sinai
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 19  The Soviet armed forces newspaper said today that Israel had re cently bolstered her military installations on the Sinai Pen insula and charged that influ ential forces in Israel were striving to provoke the Arab countries into a new war.

title: Holiday Cooky Ideas
description: The buttery nut cookies made now, following these recipes, will keep all through the holiday season if stored in a tightly covered tin or wrapped in aluminum foil.

title: 16 INDICTED ON L.I. FOR BOOKMAKING
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Dec. 19 District Attorney George J. Aspland of Suffolk County an nounced today the smashing of two bookmaking rings that took illegal bets on sports estimated at a total of $4million a year.

title: CHAPS SINK CONDORS ON BALANCED ATTACK
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 19 (AP) The Dallas Chaparrals got bal anced scoring from Don Free man, Steve Jones and. Rich Jones tonight and went on to defeat the Pittsburgh Condors, 137121, in an American Bas ketball Association game.

title: RISE IN STEEL PRICE IGNORED BY BUYERS
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 19 In creases in steel prices seemed to be producing a negative market reaction last week.

title: Dick Tiger Rites in Nigeria
description: ABA, Nigeria, Dec. 19 Reu ters)  Nigeria's boxing idol, Dick Tiger, was buried today at his hometown in East Nigeria. Mourners from miles around crowded the hot, dusty streets of the remote township as the 42yearold former world champion was laid to rest. Tiger held both the world middleweight and lightheavy weight titles in his long career.

title: The Man of La Paz
description: MABTON, Wash.I am owner of onehalf of Yakima Chief Ranch, a 600acre hop ranch in the Yakima Valley. Hundreds of seasonal farm workers are employed in this valley to harvest the numerous crops. For thirty years many of these seasonal workers have come from the lower Rio Grand Valley in Texas.

title: Birds Abound in City in Freezing Cold
description: For cardinals, mocking, birds and titmice, New York City is a better ecological niche than it was 20 years ago and even the native mourning dove is adapting more successfully to the city, birdwatchers confirmed yes terday in the annual Christ mas count of the National Audubon Society.

title: Rams Score By 2344  To No Avail
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 19The Los Angeles Rams had another game on their minds today but managed enough concentration to beat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 2314. The other game was the 49ersLions contest that began in San Francisco 21 min utes after the Rams had fin ished their work here.

title: Met to Hold Verdi Congress
description: The Third International Verdi Congress will be held at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts during the Metropolitan Opera's threeweek Verdi Festival, June 524. The Metropolitan invited the Institute of Verdi Studies in Parma, Italy, to hold the event here in the week beginning June 12. About 60 musicians, scholars, critics and American opera company managers will attend.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Until I read Mr. Gordon's letter, I never knew that vestpocket housing had been considered by the city.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: Front Page 2  No Title

title: F.D.A.'s Delayed Warning
description: The Food and Drug Administration recently issued a warning against daily body bathing of babies and adults with antibacterial solutions containing 3 per cent hexa chlorophene. The F.D.A. reveals that hexachlorophene applied to the skin can enter the bloodstream in amounts that may reach levels that have produced brain damage in monkeys. Since hexachlorophene is an ingredient in several hundred widely used products ranging from soaps and shampoos to deodorants, the possibility ex ists that millions of Americans have unknowingly been exposed to and are being exposed to appreciable hazards.

title: Rangers Tie Stars, 1 to 1, On Ratelle's 200th Goal
description: A tired bunch of Rangers, frustrated by the acrobatics of Gump Worsley, used a little bit of luck to skate away with a 11 tie against the Minnesota North Stars last night.

title: Cowen, Former Nixon Aide, Will Head A.B.C. Division
description: Eugene S. Cowen, a former aide of President Nixon, was elected yesterday a vice presi dent of the American Broad casting Company.

title: CHIEFS DEFEATED BY JOLTERS, 3938,
description: The Chiefs, Madison Square Garden's roller derby team, were defeated by the Jolters, 3938, yesterday afternoon in an International Roller Derby League game at the Garden.

title: ISADORE MARK
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Dec. 19  Isadore Mark, owner of Mark & Son Metal Products, Inc., and former president of Bet Torah Synagogue, died Thursday in Northern West chester Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived here.

title: Nahum Goldmann Opposes Urging of Jews to Quit Soviet
description: LONDON, Dec. 19 (Reuters) Dr. Nahum Goldmann, presi dent of the World Jewish Congress, today called on Jews throughout the world to stop urging Jews in the Soviet Union to leave for Israel.

title: A Weekend With the Nixons in New York
description: President Nixon finished a brisk 18hour sampling of the city's holiday delights yester day and declared that he had enjoyed it thoroughly.

title: Text of the I. M.F. Communique on Exchange Margins
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI)Following is the text of a communiqu issued to day by the International Mon etary Fund announcing the official adoption of foreign exchange margins of 2.25 per cent:

title: ZACHARY BUCHALTER OF LESLIE FAY DEAD
description: Zachary Buchalter, president of Leslie Fay, Inc., 1400 Broad way, manufacturer of women's and men's apparel, died Friday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 53 years old and lived at 415 East 52nd Street.

title: U.S. Science Aides Must Tell Biases
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  The National Academy of Sci ences, possibly the nation's most prestigious intellectual body, is requiring that its thou sands of consultants file state ments of their biases and pos sible conflicts of interest if they are to serve on commit tees that advise the Federal Government.

title: Nations Seek to Persuade China To Join in Disarmament Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19The General Assembly has concluded its annual disarma ment debate with 14 new reso lutions but with no hint that China wants to sit down at the negotiating table either here or in Geneva.

title: Trail Blazers Win, 114113
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 19 (AP)The Portland Trail Blaz ers, led by Sidney Wicks with 26 points and 17 rebounds, built an early lead and then held off the Detroit Pistons for a 114113 victory tonight.

title: What a Dollar Will Buy Under New Realignment
description: The following are some examples of what one dollar would buy in a number of foreign currencies under the new realignment:

title: Adviser to U.S. Panel Asserts Catholic Schools Survival Depends on Reforms
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19An adviser to the President's Com mission on School Finance has told Roman Catholic Bishops and edubators at six regional meetings that the survival of their schools depends not so much on obtaining Federal aid as on making internal reforms.

title: Bridge:Italians Find Effective Way To Strike It Rich in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 19 The superstars of the Italian Blue Team won the $15,000 Open Knockout Team Championship today by a margin of 68 points.

title: MRS. SAM MILLER
description: Mrs. Lee Stern Miller, labo ratory cytologist at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital and widow of Sam Miller, a lumber dealer, died Friday in Kings County Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived at 3310 Avenue H, Brooklyn.

title: Knapp and Lindsay Agree Mayor Should Not Testify
description: Mayor Lindsay has been pri vately questioned by the chair man of the commission inves tigating police corruption in New York and the alleged fail ure of high city officials to act on specific reports of corrup tion.

title: Penn Central Adds Dissidents to Board
description: PHILADELPHIA. Dec. 19 (AP)The Penn Central Com pany, impoverished parent firm of the railroad, has doubled its board to 10 directors in an effort to satisfy dissident stockholders who had blocked adoption of a controversial fi nancing plan.

title: Private Burial for Jones
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 19 (AP) Bobby Jones, whose death Sat urday evoked a deluge of eulogies from the golf world, will be buried at 2:30 tomorrow afternoon in private services at Oakland Cemetery here.

title: Detroit to Replace Pull Boxes With Phones for Fire Alarms
description: DETROIT, Dec. 19The 3,300 street pull fire alarm boxes in Detroit will all be removed to reduce false alarms, which account for most of the fire calls in this city.

title: ALICE D. FRANKLIN
description: Alice D. Franklin, research librarian at the Metropolitan Museum of Art from 1928 to 1960, who had charge of the reference collection of art photographs, died Friday in New York Hosptal. She was 77 years old and lived at 106 East 81st Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Mr. Fireman, in his letter of Nov. 24, has posed a question I have been asking myself for some time (and I thank him for bringing it out Into the open): Now is one to pronounce the abbreviation Ms. before a lady's sur name? I have, privately, tried manu script, millisecond and Missis sippi; but none of these, followed by Smith or Jones, has seemed quite right.

title: TIMES UNIT TO OFFER TV SERIES FOR YOUNG
description: The New York Times Teach ing Resources Pilm Division, which produces and distributes educational sound filmstrips and recordings for use in el ementary schools and libraries, announced yesterday that it would expand its activities to include the production of chil dren's television programs.

title: Reporter Is Killed
description: Nizamuddin Ahmed, a part time correspondent of the New York Times in Dacca, has been identified as one of about 100 Bengali intellec tuals who were killed before the war ended.

title: Moscow Assays Devaluation As Blow to American Prestige
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 19The So viet Union said today that the devaluation of the dollar was a blow to United States pres tige that demonstrated a new power balance in the capitalist world, but gave no indication of how the devaluation would affect the exchange rate of the ruble.

title: Theater: The New York of Inner City
description: Masochism is New York's way of life and you will find a groat deal of the most heroic masochism in Inner City, which opened last night at the Ethel Barrymore Theater. All New Yorkers who adore to be told how fantastically wonderful it is that they can survive the cruel, harsh rigors of New York City can here be told precisely how fantastically wonderful it is.

title: Wolstenholme Triumphs
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 19 (AP)Guy Wolsten holme, a British golfer now liv ing in Australia, took the top prize of $2,800 today in the City of Auckland open golf tournament. He carded a 73 for a 275 total.

title: Importers Applaud End of 10% Surtax As Spur to Trade
description: Removal of the 10 per cent import surtax was applauded yesterday by Gerald O'Brien, executive vice president of the American Importers Associa tion, representing more than 900 companies.

title: ISADORE PACHT
description: Isadore Pacht, owner of a clothing store at 492 Claremont Parkway in the Morrisania sec tion of the Bronx, died Satur day night after he was shot in an attempted holdup at his store. Mr. Pacht, who was 56 years old, lived at 8017 Bogart Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Police Get Dictionaries
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 19 (UPI) The St. Louis Police Academy has bought 180 dictionaries in an effort to improve the lan guage and spelling used by po licemen in writing reports. I hope never again to read in a report that an accident victim had his foot decapitated, said Police Chief Eugene J. Camp.

title: BLATCHFORD EQUALS SPEED SKATE MARK
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 19 (AP)  Neil Blatchford, of North brook, Ill., was timed in 39.1 seconds for 500 meters today in the United States Olympic speed skating trials, equaling the fastest time recorded On American ice.

title: Chess: A NonEmotional Method for Ranking of Players
description: The International Chess Federation's newly adopted ranking system, based on the procedure long in effect in the United States and pre viously described in this col umn, continues to occupy the pages of chess magazines throughout the world.

title: MARKET DEMAND SEEN FOR DOLLAR
description: The United States dollar is expected to become one of the strongest currencies in the weeks ahead as speculators and corporations, having now made paper profits in the foreign exchange markets, seek to nail them down by buying dollars back.

title: Credit Markets Facing Heavy Financing Volume
description: While the money and capital, markets slipped into the usual yearend lull over the weekend, a substantial volume of new financing was announced.

title: Divided Christian Democrats Caucus on the Voting in Italy
description: ROME, Dec. 19The 17th in conclusive ballot in Italy's presi dential election this morning was followed this afternoon by a Christian Democratic party caucus to discuss further strat egy.

title: Phase 2 Markups Baffle Shoppers, Who Cannot Check Legality of Increases
description: All these price Increases the shopper encounters in the su permarkets, are they legal?

title: D.C.Bell Weds Miss Currier

title: Man in the News
description: As he flew home to Pakis tan yesterday to form a new government, Zulfikar All Bhutto, now Foreign Minis ter and Deputy Prime Min ister, held airport news conferences, stressing his conviction that the west wing and the secessionist east wing of Pakistan are still one Sum moned from the United Nations, where he headed Pakistan's dele gation during the Security Council debate on the IndiaPakistan conflict, Mr. Bhutto, 43 years old, was not eager to discuss his own political future. It is not relevant, he said at London's Heathrow Airport.

title: Swiss Delay Likely
description: GENEVA, Dec. 19The Swiss Cabinet will possibly defer a decision until Tuesday or Wednesday on whether to com ply with the decision by the Group of 10 and revalue the Swiss franc upward by 4.61 per cent, Alexandre Hay, director of the Swiss National Bank, said tonight in a television broadcast.

title: ' A Clockwork Orange' Dazzles the Senses and Mind
description: On the soundtrack we hear Henry Purcell's almost comically elegant "Music Composed for Queen Mary's Funeral." On the screen we see a closeup portrait of Alex (Malcolm McDowell), who, for a moment, is uncharacteristically still. The face looks floodlit, as if caught by one of those automatic photo machines in a bus station.However, the eyes, one of which is ringed by false lashes, reveal an intelligence that is no less alive for being occupied, momentarily, with the kind of drug fantasies that Alex and his droogs are able to buy at the Kerova Milkbar, before going out into the London night in search of the old ultra-violence. There's always the chance they'll find a dirty old man to beat up, or some frightened devotchka for a malenky bit of in-out, in-out.Thus begins "A Clockwork Orange," Stanley Kubrick's adaptation of Anthony Burgess's perversely moral, essentially Christian novel about the value of free will, even if the choice exercised is to tear through the night robbing, raping and battering the citizens until they lie helpless, covered with what Alex describes happily as "the real red vino," or krovvy.In both English and Nadsat, the combination of Anglicized Russian, Gypsy, rhyming slang and associative words spoken by Alex and his teenage friends in what seems to be 1983, "A Clockwork Orange" is a great deal more than merely horror showthat is, Nadsat for good. It is brilliant, a tour de force of extraordinary images, music, words and feelings, a much more original achievement for commercial films than the Burgess novel is for literature, for Burgess, after all, has some impossibly imposing literary antecedents, including the work of Joyce.The film, which opened yesterday at the Cinema I, is cast in the form of futurist fiction, but it is no spinoff from Mr. Kubrick's "2001," nor is it truly futurist, if that means it is one of those things-to-come fantasies. More correctly it contemplates the nightmares of today, often in terms that reflect the 1950's and 1960's, out of which the Burgess novel grew. It is also  at least it seems to me  an essentially British nightmare (while "2001" was essentially American) in its attentions to caste, manners, accents and the state of mind created by a kind of weary socialism.The movie shows a lot of aimless violencethe exercise of aimless choicebut it is as formally structured as the music of Alex's "lovely lovely Ludwig Van," which inspires in Alex sado-masochistic dreams of hangings, volcanic eruptions and other disasters.Alex is a terrifying character, but also an intelligent, funny and pathetic one, whose spiritual crucifixion comes when, having been jailed for murder, he is subjected to the Ludovico Treatment. Alex is one of the early guinea pigs in a rehabilitation program that involves the conditioning of his responses, via the nonstop viewing of sex, horror and atrocity movies. At the end of two weeks, he is left as dumb and defenseless as a defanged, declawed animal.Impulses to hate, anger, lust make him physically ill. He has become a model of good, "as decent a lad as you would meet on a May morning," but, as his fundamentalist prison chaplain points out, he is without a soul.Under these circumstances, Alex's eventual return to his original "free" state becomes an ironic redemption, yet not much attention is paid to the fact that Alex the hood is as much a product of conditioning as was the denatured Alex, the product of aversion therapy.However, I won't quibble over the point. "A Clockwork Orange" is so beautiful to look at and to hear that it dazzles the senses and the mind, even as it turns the old real red vino to ice: Alex and his friends having a rumble with a rival gang to the tune of Rossini's "The Thieving Magpie," or preparing a gang rape in the home of a definitely upper-class writer as Alex does a lyric soft-shoe (into the stomach and face of the writer), singing "Singin' in the Rain." That's the sort of thing that makes Alex feel all nice and warm in his guttywuts.McDowell is splendid as tomorrow's child, but it is always Mr. Kubrick's picture, which is even technically more interesting than "2001." Among other devices, Mr. Kubrick constantly uses what I assume to be a wide-angle lens to distort space relationships within scenes, so that the disconnection between lives, and between people and environment, becomes an actual, literal fact.At one point in his therapy, Alex says: "The colors of the real world only become real when you viddy them in a film." "A Clockwork Orange" makes real and important the kind of fears simply exploited by other, much lesser films.

title: 2 Newark Policemen Shot By 3 Men in a Stolen Auto
description: NEWARK, Dec. 19  Three armed men in a stolen car shot two policemen who sought to question them here today. One of the patrolmen returned the fire and is believed to have wounded at least one of the fleeing assailants.

description: BUFFALO, Dec. 19 (UPI) Mike Byers scored two goals and assisted on a third tally in his home debut tonight as the Buffalo Sabres beat the Vancouver Canucks, 51.

description: About 125 firemen battled a fouralarm fire early today in a sixstory apartment building under construction in the Fox Hills section of Staten Island. The fire was reported under control at 2:30 A.M.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Dec. 19It would be pleasant to turn to some other subject, but this one will not go away. We shall be living indefinitely with the con sequences, human and political, of all that has happened in India and Pakis tan over the last nine months.

description: In 1954, friends of Fred Russell converged on Nashville, Tenn., to help readers of The Nashville Banner celebrate Russell's silver anniversary on the paper, which he serves as vice president and sports editor. Bobby Jones had al ready undergone surgery twice for the spinal disorder that would one day leave him helpless, yet he made his painful way up from Atlanta.

title: Intelsat 4 Spacecraft Is Lofted; Will Be Stationed Over Atlantic
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 19 (UPI)A commercial com munications satellite owned by 81 nations was fired into space tonight to open thousands of new telephone circuits between North America and Europe next month.

title: LAKERS TOP 76ERS FOR Ell N ROW
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Dec. 19 (UPI)  Wilt Chamberlain scored 32 points, hauled down 34 rebounds and blocked 12 shots tonight to pace the Los, Angeles Lakers to a record 25th straight National Basketball Association victory, 154132, over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In explaining why the city will soon buy only recycled paper [news story Nov. 15], Purchase Commissioner Marvin Gersten is dealing with com plicated data in a very simplistic man ner. He is announcing a goal that he and other purchasersindeed most purchasers of paper  have already achieved: the purchase of paper that contains 20 per cent recycled fiber. By definition of the General Services Administration, recycled or reclaimed paper includes all waste, or broke, generated by a mill's operations with the exception of roll trimmings. There is hardly a mill in the United States that does not recycle its own broke, and most industry spokesmen claim that any of their products contain at least 20 per cent of waste so defined.

title: An Entrepreneur's Trucks Bring Southern Soul Food to Harlem
description: It's a sure sign that winter has come when Grady C. Houston's big trucks make the 1,000mile run from Macon, Ga., to Harlem with the kind of Southern soul food that's hard to come by in the North.

title: Forest Hills Protest Moves to 5th Ave.
description: Fifth Avenue resounded yes terday to chanted choruses of Down with Lindsay, as some 700 residents from the Forest Hills section of Queens demon strated in midManhattan for nearly two hours against the lowincome housing project get ting under way in their middle class community.

title: PANEL ASKS REVIVAL OF LABOR BRIEFINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) A House subcommittee re port released today urges the Labor Department to reinstate its monthly news briefings on unemployment and Consumer Price Index figures.

title: U.S. Economists Hail Monetary Accord
description: Economists and businessmen in the United States greeted the international monetary agree ment reached in Washington over the weekend as an im portant first step in rebuilding a healthy world economic en vironment.

title: Marlene Cooperman Wed
description: LYNBROOK, L. I., Dec. 19 Miss Marlene Joy Cooper man, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul P. Cooperman of New York, was married here this evening to Richard A. Lessmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack J. Lessmann of Teaneck, N. J. Rabbi Emanuel Green performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth David. The bride's father is mer chandise manager of the men's clothing department of Korvette's, a division of Ar len Realty and Development Corporation. Mr. Lessmenn's father is president of Syntax Mills, Inc., New York.

title: The Talk of Hyden, Ky.
description: HYDEN. Ky., Dec. 17 When strangers drive into town and see the signHy defl, Population 800they often remember the pictures from a year ago: The snow falling, the crowd waiting by the mouth of the mine, and then the funerals. Now it is Christmas time againa bad time for poor peo ple everywhere, but particularly for the families that remember last Christmas, and Dec. 30, when 38 miners were killed in the explosion at Hurricane Creek.

title: Light in the Tunnel
description: Despite years of political promises and intensifying controversy, the nation's transportation is still more of a tangle than a system. Yet a few recent scattered events suggest that in Congress and among the traveling public, progress is being made toward a more balanced, orderly and less wasteful pattern.

title: Sordid Spectacle in Italy
description: In their sordid maneuvers for election of a new Presi dent, Italy's politicians are eroding the country's demo cratic system at a critical time. The heaviest responsi bility for turning this solemn constitutional exercise into a farce rests with the Christian Democratic party, which has headed every Italian Government for 26 years.

title: Eskimo Display Spurs Demand for Stone Carvings
description: VANCOUVER, Dec. 19In six weeks an exhibition of 405 pieces of Canadian Eskimo stone sculptures, the largest ever assembled, attracted 32. 775 persons to the Vancouver Art Gallery.

But before you allow your at tention to wander, consider some of the re marks made by Wallace Hildick and John Rowe Townsend, two English writers of children's books, in their respective critical studies.

description: Dozens of Chinese in the United States have visited China since the dramatic change in relationship between Washington and Peking. These persons, allowed to see their ancestral homeland for the first time in more than 20 years, have had experiences far more intimate than those of other foreigners.

title: FOREIGN MARKETS CLOSE
description: PARIS, Dec. 19  Financial observers see a trying period ahead for the managers of the major Western economies as they gear operations to absorb the shock of the depreciated dollar while attempting to keep unemployment from rising.

title: Syria Talks Softly, Hardens Defenses
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 19 Syria is quietly reinforcing her defenses around this vulnerable capital and other important cit ies, but there is no evidence of eagerness to provoke hos tilities with Israel.

title: PAKISTAN ASSERTS PRESIDENT YAHYA IS QUITTING TODAY
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 19An official spokesman said here tonight that Pakistan's President, Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, had decided to re sign as soon as he hands over power to representatives of the people tomorrow.

title: Moscow Deftly Allows Armenia Its Nationalism
description: ERIVAN, U.S.S.R.There is more sausage in Moscow than in Erivan, said a dark haired Armenian intellectual, acknowledging that living con ditions here are not on a par with the distant Soviet capi tal. But one doesn't live by sausage alone. I would rather live and work here among my own people, even for 50 rubles less a month.

title: 2STROKE VICTORY POSTED BY MOODY
description: RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 19 (AP) Orville Moody, coming off a lean golfing year and long vacation, won the Morocco international golf Grand Prix today by two strokes.

title: 3 Children Die in Pyramid
description: CAIRO, Dec. 19 (Reuters) Three children were crushed to death inside the Great Pyramid of Cheops today when school children on a tour panicked and rushed down a staircase after the electric lights failed, the Middle East News Agency re ported.

description: TOKYO, Dec. 19The Japa nese response to the steep re valuation of the yen hung like a pall over Tokyo today, much like the gray, dreary smog that covered the city this Sunday afternoon.

description: Historic St. George's Episco pal Church on Stuyvesant Square faces extinction un less its current deficit of more than $400,000 is met, accord ing to Henry H. Moulton, sen ior warden.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your correspondent who wrote re questing a pronunciation of Ms., the female equivalent of Mr., erred in say ing that it was an abbreviation of nothing [letter Nov. 24]. Ms. is in fact an abbreviation of Mistress, formed by combining and shortening the two earlier abbreviations, Mrs. and Miss.

title: Physician Marries Miss Jane H. Miniszek
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Dec. 19 The marriage of Miss Jane Haight Miniszek to Dr. Peter Lawrence Weingarten, son of Dr. and Mrs. Berthold Wein garten of New York, took place here today. Justice of the Peace David Corey per formed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. James H. Miniszek.

title: GOVERNOR OF OHIO WILL BACK NO
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 Gov. John J. Gilligan of Ohio, which will send the fifth largest delegation to the Democratic National Convention next year, has decided to endorse Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine for President.

description: BOSTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) Me Pittsburgh Penguins, trail ing by two goals after one peri od, rallied on goals by Greg Polls and Jean Pronovost to night for a 22 tie with Bruins that kept Boston three points behind the New York Rangers.

title: Foes Criticize Greek Democracy Pledge
description: ATHENS, Dec. 19 Oppo nents of the Government today accused Premier George Papa dopoulos of planning to per petuate the military rule im posed in 1967.

description: The Washington agreement among the ten leading nonCommunist nations fulfills the promise of the Rome conference and the NixonPompidou summit meeting in the Azores that the major currencies of the world would be realigned and the threat of a protracted monetary crisis ended.

title: Navy Wins Aztec Bowl, 479

title: Democratic Representative Wins Runoff for Louisiana Governor
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 19 (AP)  Representative Edwin Edwards, a relative political newcomer whose campaigning emphasized his background as the son of a sharecropper, will carry his call for reform of state government into the race to become Governor of Loui siana.

description: To the Editor: Two recent items in The Times in dicate again the critical role that trans portation plays in the lives of New Yorkers and the insensitivity of the political leaders to the real needs of our people in this area.

description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y. Now Dasher, now Dancer, Prancer and Vixen. The words echo around the moun tain here twice a day when four of Santa's reindeer are hitched to a sleigh on wheels for a lively pull around the meadow in front of the Bear Mountain Inn.

title: Santa Fe Outlay to Rise

Most of the in creases for 1972 is for the Santa Fe Railway, which plans to spend about $100million in 1972, up from an estimated $89million in 1971.

description: Black parents and community leaders, angry because their neighborhoods have not been given high priority for the con struction of new schools, used yesterday's hearings by the City Planning Commission to de nounce busing.

description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 20 (Reuters)About 15,000 North Vietnamese troops, backed by tanks and heavy artillery, have overrun the strategic Plaine des Jarres in northern Laos, offi cials said today.

description: GUILFORD, Conn., Dec. 20 Frank Tweddell, an actor who appeared often on Broadway, died today in GraceNew Haven Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 444 Mulberry Point.

title: College Yearbooks Quietly Expire as Student Interest Wanes

title: American Motors Chief Predicts Economic Gains
description: DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) A good economic year, even better than predicted by most eco nomic forecasters, was pre dicted today by the chairman of the American Motors Corpo ration.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Bobby Jones was buried in the red clay of his native Georgia yesterday and it would seem indecent not to add one more fond farewell to a man who long has been one of the most admired and beloved figures in sports. It more than four decades since Bobby retired from the ex citements of major golf tournaments, and yet his magic has endured to today. Nor will the legend of Robert Tyre Jones Jr. ever grow less. He truly belongs to the ages.

title: Sadat's Wife Tours Canal
description: CAIRO, Dec. 20 (Reuters) President Anwar al Sadat's wife visited the Suez Canal front today and watched armored units carrying out watercross ing excercises, and visited military hospitals.

title: STATE'S ATTORNEY DROPPED BY DALEY
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 20In the face of mounting pressures from other Democratic candidates and leaders of Chicago's black community, the Cook County Democratic organization de cided today that it could no longer endorse State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan for re election.

title: Hanoi Lists 4 Captives
description: PARIS, Dec. 20 (UPI)North Vietnam said today it had cap tured four United States airmen from three Phantom jets shot down Saturday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Fred C. Simmons recent OpEd article A Woodland Fantasy serves to defeat his own argument. He cor rectly points out that with no logging, hemlock and beech become the domi nant species in the Adirondack hard wood forest to the detriment of cherry, birch and other shadeintolerant species. However he then describes the susceptibility of beech and hemlock to pests and disease, as indeed are all mature stands of single species. When he describes the patches of dead beech  already evident to anyone who flies over the Adirondacks, we can rest assured that within these patches are growing the lightdemand ing birch, ash and similar species that fortunately maintain the dynamic qual ity of any unmanaged forest.

title: TRANSIT WORKERS PRESS FOR 30%, RISE
description: Negotiators for the city's transit workers, in presenting their case for a 30 per cent pay increase, cited data yes terday showing that the wages and benefits of bus and sub way workers had fallen far be hind those of other city em ployes in comparable jobs.

title: W ebster Plans to Toughen Giant Camp And Himself
description: Setting up priorities in the player draft, taking more re sponsibility off his assistants by putting it on himself, operat ing a tougher training camp and preparing for an ear operation.

title: Price Commission's Statement Outlining. Its Decision on Housing Units Under Rent Control
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20, Following is the text of the announcement of the Price Commission of its decision on rentcontrolled housing units:

title: Tennessee Tops Arkansas, 1413
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 20 (AP)Curt Watson raced 17 yards for the tying touchdown with 1 minute, 56 seconds re maining and George Hunt kicked his 62d straight extra point to night lifting Tennessee to a 14 13 victory over Arkansas in the Liberty Bowl football game.

title: Accord Reported On U.N Resolution For a Withdrawal
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20Informed sources said to day that. Security Council mem bers had reached agreement on a resolution endorsing the cease fire between India and Pakistan and calling for eventual but not immediate withdrawal of Indian armed forces to their own side of the border.

title: College Sports Notes
description: Indiana University basket ball fans were skeptical to ward an emphasis on defense when they heard last spring that Bobby Knight was leav ing Army to become the Hoosiers head coach. Defense was the name of Knight's game at Army and he fully intended to carry on that approach at Indi ana. By the third game of this season, the big crowds in the new Indiana field house had lost their distaste for defense and were up yell ing, Defense, Defense, as the Indiana team permitted Kansas, defending Big Eight champion, only 56 points and Miami of Ohio, defending MidAmerican champion, 50 points.

title: Belfast Racked by 13 Bombings;
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 20A wave of bombings struck downtown Belfast today, leaving the city terrified and arousing fears of widespread violence by the Irish Republican Army.

title: HEARINGS ENDED ON CITY HOUSING
description: The chairman of the City Council committee investigating the Municipal Loan Program ended public hearings into the program yesterday and charged that its former director was deliberately ducking service of a subpoena to appear before the committee.

title: President and Heath Confer for 5 Hours in Bermuda
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec, 20President Nixon conferred with Prime Minister Heath of Britain today on a wide range of issues. Both sides said after ward that they had given spe cial attention to the war be tween India and Pakistan and to the future of South Asia.

title: DOWDY'S ACCUSER SCORED AT TRIAL
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 20A de fense witness testified today that a principal witness against Representative John Dowdy had boasted of falsifying evi dence against the Representa tive avoid prosecution on charges of fraud.

title: About Pro Football
description: The No. 1 phenomenon of the pro football playoffs is that the Minnesota Vikings, one of the strongest of the eight Super Bowl contenders, do not know who their quar terback will be and have been taught not to care. The choices are threeGary Cu ozzo, Bob Lee or Norman Snead. Coach Bud Grant, who en joys small jokes, was asked after his team beat the Bears Sunday who it will be on Saturday against the Dallas Cowboys.

title: A Girl, 20, Is Slain by Gunfire
description: LISBURN, Northern Ireland, Dec. 20What happened in the Conway Hotel in Dunmurry this morning is a textbook ex ample of the urban guerrilla warfare waged by the Irish Re publican Army.

title: 16 SPEED SKATERS ON OLYMPIC TEAM
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 20 (AP) Ten men and six women, in cluding six with previous Olym pic experience, were named to day to the 1972 United States Olympic speedskating team.

title: New Delhi Termed Willing To Negotiate With Bhutto
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 20An authoritative Indian source said today that their Government was willing to negotiate with Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the new President of Pakistan, though he is a longtime adversary of India.

title: Screen: 'Harold and Maude' and Life:Hal Ashby's Comedy Opens at Coronet Ruth Gordon, Bud Cort Star as Odd Couple
description: Harold is 20, very rich and very suicidal. Maude is 79, very poor and so full of a sympathetic life-force that she grieves for a small tree, suffocating in the city's pollution. Harold and Maude meet at one of the anonymous funerals they like to attend, fall in love while transplanting the tree, and marry on the eve of Maude's birthday.Even if this idea strikes you as immensely comic, you might well want to miss Hal Ashby's "Harold and Maude," a comedy that pretends to be as thoroughly in favor of life as "You Can't Take It With You," whereas it's quite as much about death as it appears to be.Like Harold, the movie is fascinated by the mechanics of simulated suicide  by hanging, by slashed wrists and throat, by a shot in the head, by drowning, by harakiri and, most hilariously, by immolation. Harold enacts them all, not really to kill himself (gulp, guffaw), but to get a rise out of his mother. When Mrs. Chasen comes from Harold dangling by the neck from a chandelier, her first reaction is to say something on the order of "Now, Harold, I suppose you think that's funny."Because Vivian Pickles is an actress who is particularly gifted at exaggerating understatements, many of Mrs. Chasen's reactions to Harold's bleak pranks are as funny as they are meant to be. There are, indeed, some other funny things in "Harold and Maude" (an airy confrontation between Maude and the cop who stops her for speeding in a stolen truck), but they are all terribly incidental to the movie's main concern, which is apparently that there is a time to live and a time to die (when you reach 80.)As Harold and Maude, Bud Cort and Ruth Gordon are supposed to appear magnificently mismatched for the purposes of the comedy. They are mismatched, at least visually. Mr. Cort's baby face and teen-age build look grotesque alongside Miss Gordon's tiny, weazened frame.Yet, as performers, they both are so aggressive, so creepy and off-putting, that Harold and Maude are obviously made for each other, a point the movie itself refuses to recognize with a twist ending that betrays, I think, its life-affirming pretensions. These reach an embarrassed low when Miss Gordon sits down at the piano, in the railroad car where she makes her home, and sings a rousing chorus of a song that starts: "Gimme an 'l'/Gimme an 'i'/a 'v' and an 'e'/l-i-v-e/Live!" It's even worse than the scene in which Harold sets fire to himself by the swimming pool.The movie opened yesterday at the Coronet.

title: William L. Spearman Dies; Negro College Fund Aide
description: William L. Spearman, direc for of research for the United Negro College Fund, died Sat urday at his home, 295 St. John's Place, Brooklyn. He was, 53 years old.

title: Advertising:
description: To its jampacked liquor cabinet, Smith/Greenland is adding John Begg Scotch.

title: PRICE UNIT BACKS LOCAL RENT RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20The Price Commission said tonight that landlords could raise rents in line with state and local guidelines pending a review by the commission to determine whether those controls met Federal objectives.

title: Ohio State Beats Brown, 6256, On Hornyak's 3 Points in Clutch
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 20 (UPI)Allan Hornyak, making his first appearance of the season, scored 3 points in the last 15 seconds tonight to help sixthranked Ohio gain a 6256 victory over Brown.

title: MRS. RALPH SUSSMAN
description: Mrs. Frances Goldberg Suss man, a teacher in the public school system here from 1949 to 1969, who specialized in remedial reading and science, died Sunday at the age of 61. She lived at 15 East 91st Street.

title: market Place: Lofty PE Ratio Of Inco Studied
description: Here's a paradox for you. Why does the International Nickel Company command a priceearnings ratio of about 20far above that which some of the world's finest oil companies boastat a time when the Ontariobased nat ural resource concern's earn ings have been cut almost in half?

title: U.S. Confirms the Loss Of Four Jets Over Laos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 20Four United States jet fighterbombers were shot down over northern Laos this weekend, and the American command here said at least one of them was ap parently destroyed in an air toair engagement with a North Vietnamese MIG21 that flew across the border to chalienge them.

title: Stocks Climb in Heavy Trading
description: The stock market went on a rollercoaster ride yesterday, as investors responded to the weekend's news about the re alignment of world currencies; including the devaluation of the dollar in terms of gold.

title: judges Allow Sale of Gulf Oil Leases, but Order Bids Impounded
description: WASHINGTON; Dec. 20A threejudge panel of the United States Court of Appeals de cided today to allow a sale of Federal oil and gas leases in the Gulf of Mexico to be held tomorrow. But it ordered that all bids submitted by oil com panies be impounded pending disposition of a lowercourt in junction won by environmental groups.

description: Meets at 10:30 A.M., 3 P.M. and 8:30 P.M.

title: EARNINGS ARE UP AT DEERE & CO,
description: Deere & Co., the largest do mestic manufacturer of farm equipment reported yesterday a 69.8 per cent rise in fourth quarter earnings ended Oct. 31 on a sales gain of 1.7 per cent. For the full fiscal year earn ings rose 37.5 per cent on a 5.3 per cent sales increase.

title: Universities in Jeopardy
description: The presidents of six of the state's leading private universities have performed a painful but necessary service by dramatically placing before the public the bleak reality of higher education's fiscal crisis. The disas trous impact of inflation, along with the reduction in Federal student aid and a temporary leyeling off in enrollments, threatens a number of these institutions with financial collapse.

description: Obituary 1  No Title

description: Senator Edmund S. Muskie has come back to within strik ing distance of President Nixon, according to the latest Louis Harris Poll, released yes terday.

description: To the Editor: Your recent editorial Now, Remem ber Rahway appropriately compares the disaster of Attica with the con structive solution worked out by the officials of New Jersey, The experience at Rahway again gives evidence of prison reforms that are immediately available without further tax burdens. For example, the following suggestions could change the negative environment of the New York State prison system dramatically:

title: rough Talk by Israeli Army Leaders Is Seen as Aimed at Deterring Arab YearEnd Military Moves
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 20Is raeli Army spokesmen are in dulging in tough talk these clays, underlining this country's armed strength as an apparent deterrent to any Arab military moves at the end of 1971, which the Egyptian President, Anwar elSadat has declared to be a year of decision.

description: Edward M. Kennedy, com menting on public reaction to the Chappaquiddick in cident, said it would not affect his political decisions, even though the incident will probably have a continuing impact on his career.

description: John W. Mecom, one of the most famous of the Texas wildcatters, appears to have salvaged much of his vast oil and real estate empire. It had been under threat of disinte gration for more than a year.

title: Grechko, III With Flu, Gains
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 20 (UPI)  The Soviet Defense Minister Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, who is confined to bed in Baghdad with a severe case of influenza, showed remarkable improvement to day, the official Iraqi news agency said. There is a pos sibility that he may call off scheduled visits to Syria and Somalia, the agency dispatch said.

title: Brooklyn Funeral Uses A HorseDrawn Hearse
description: Mrs. Angelina Mazzella rode to her funeral, yester day Italian style, in a horse drawn hearse that may he the last of its kind in Brook lyn's Little Italy.

title: Art Season: A New Realism Emerges
description: A few months ago, at one of those country retreats where artists gather, a mid dleaged composer only re cently into electronic tape approached an art critic and, with an air of puzzled irrita tion, put the following ques tion to him: What's the story on all these young guys around here making realistic paintingsis it a fad or something?

title: McKneally Gets a $5,000 Fine And Probation on Tax Charge
description: ALBANY, Dec. 20 (UPI)  Former Representative Martin B. McKneally of Newburgh was placed on probation for a year and was fined $5,000 today on a charge that he filed no in come tax in 1965 on income of $24,000. A oneyear sentence was suspended.

title: Queens College Five Wins
description: Queens College rallied from an 18point deficit at halftime last night to defeat Pottsdam State University, 9285.

title: SOUTH KOREA SEES ADVANCE IN TRADING
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 20 South Korean officials pre dicted today that the country's exports to the United States and Japan would increase con siderably as a result of the yen revaluation and the removal of the United States import sur charge.

title: Murphy Indicts the Courts For Rise in City's Crime
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that the courts must accept the giant share of the blame for the continual rise in crime in the city. Urging reforms. Mr. Murphy said the courts let too many criminals go free and gave others sentences that were too light. He said the whole judicial system was lax, unjust, inefficient and in bankruptcy.

title: Sadowsky Asks Greater Power For City Administrator's Post
description: The chairman of an influen ital City Council committee ask ed Mayor Lindsay yesterday to refrain from naming a succes sor to Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello unless the office is given increased power and re sponsibility.

title: U.S. and Saigon to Mark 3 Daylong Holiday Truces
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 20President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that his armed forces would observe truces of 24 hours duration at Christmas, the New Year, and Tet, the lunar new year holi day, next Feb. 14. The United States command followed suit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Soon we will once again witness the State Legislature casting about for ways and means of meeting budget deficits in general and holding down transportation costs in particular.

title: ALFRED FERSHT
description: Alfred Fersht, who retired as a classified advertising agency contact man of The New York Times several years ago, died Sunday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 70 years old and lived at 7 Win chester Avenue, Yonkers.

title: THOMPSON CAPTURES DANCE SOLO SPIRIT
description: The solo, that form beloved of modern dancers has proven a congenial vehicle for Clive Thompson. On Sunday after noon, he danced Hermit Songs for the first time during the just ended season of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at City Center.

title: MOSCOW CONDEMNS U.S. PLAN FOR NATO
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 20The Soviet Union, which has wor ried Western strategists with the steady rise of its naval power in recent years, today voiced its own worries about an American proposal for es tablishing a standing NATO naval force beside the American Sixth Fleet in the Mediterra nean.

title: 3 in Peace Corps Killed In Auto Crash in Liberia
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) The Peace Corps reported today that three members of its opera tion in Liberia were killed in an auto accident during the weekend outside the capital city of Monrovia.

title: Article 1  No Title

description: LONDON, Dec. 20 (Reuters) Three more Bengali diplo Imats working abroad for the Pakistani Government defected today to the new government that has been formed in East, Pakistan.

title: PATROLMAN SLAIN BY FLEEING THIEF
description: An offduty Housing Author ity patrolman was shot and killed on a Brooklyn street yes terday as he tried to thwart the robbery of a grocery store.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20A Civil Aeronautics Board ex aminer recommended today re jection of the proposed merger of American Airlines and West ern Airlines.
